Kansas City Southern Railway, and including all property located within two hundred (200) feet east of the line from point F to point G, thence in a southeasterly direction along the north right-of-way boundary line of the Kansas City Southern Railway from point G to point H, point H being where the north right-of-way boundary line of the Kansas City Southern Railway intersects the west right-of-way boundary line of North Bryan Street, thence in a northeasterly direction along the west right-of-way boundary line of North Bryan Street from point H to point I, point I being where the west right-of-way boundary of North Bryan intersects the south right-of-way line of East Airline Highway, thence northeast at approximately an eighty-five (85) degree angle from point I along an imaginary line from point I to point J, point J being where this imaginary line intersects the north right-of-way boundary line of East Airline Highway, thence due east along a certain property line, being more fully described as the south boundary line of the O.J. Daigle property fronting on U.S. 61 Airline Highway, a distance of two hundred fifty (250) feet from point J to point K, point K being an imaginary point two hundred fifty (250) feet along the above described property line from point J, thence in a northwesterly direction along an imaginary line parallel to Airline Highway from point K to point L, point L being where this imaginary line intersects the south shoreline of Bayou Narcisse, thence in a westerly direction along the south shoreline of Bayou Narcisse from point L to point M, point M being where the south shoreline of Bayou Narcisse intersects the north right-of-way boundary line of West Airline Highway, thence south along the north right-of-way boundary line of West Airline Highway from point M to point N, point N being where the north right-of-way boundary line of West Airline Highway intersects the north right-of-way boundary line of Bayou Narcisse Street, thence south along an imaginary line parallel to North Burnside Street from point N to point O, point O being where this imaginary line intersects the south shoreline of New River, thence south along the east right-of-way boundary line of Felicity Street from point O to point P, point P being where the east right-of-way boundary line of Felicity Street intersects the north right-of-way boundary line of West Roosevelt Street, and including all property located within two hundred (200) feet west of the line from point O to point P, thence due south along an imaginary line parallel to South Burnside Street from point P to point Q, point O being where this imaginary line intersects the north right-of-way boundary line of West Cornerview Street, thence east along the north right-of-way boundary line of West Cornerview Street from point Q to point A, point A being the point of beginning. 
(Code 1965, § 5-6) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 5-22. - Building permit-Required. 
(a)  No wall, fence, structure, building or part thereof shall hereafter be built, enlarged or altered until a plan of the proposed work, together with a statement of the materials to be used shall have been submitted to the building official who shall, if in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Ordinances, issue a permit for the proposed construction. 
(b)  Structures hereafter erected without permit or not in conformity with this article and shall be removed. 
(c)  No chimney, flue, furnace, boiler or other heating apparatus shall be installed, repaired or altered without first obtaining a permit from such official, who shall issue the permit only when the proposed change or installation is in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 5-9; Ord. No. 2509, 4-13-98; Ord. No. 2814, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 5-23. - Same-Fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring a building permit shall at the time of filing an application therefor pay to the city a fee based upon the approved permit fee schedule. 
(b)  Where work for which a permit is required by this Code is started or undertaken prior to obtaining such permit, the fees specified in the approved permit fee schedule shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of this Code in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed herein. 
(Code 1965, § 5-10; Ord. No. 1829, 2-23-87; Ord. No. 2341, 11-13-95; Ord. No. 2737, 6-24-02; Ord. No. 2814, 2-14-05; Ord. No. 2933, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 5-24. - Work to be performed by licensed contractor. 
    No wall, fence, structure, building or part thereof shall hereafter be built, enlarged or altered except by a licensed contractor, providing, however, that a bona fide property owner may construct any wall, fence, structure, building or part thereof if the actual construction is performed by such property owner or under his direct supervision, provided that all the provisions of the building code must be adhered to. 
(Code 1965, § 5-11; Ord. No. 2814, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 5-25. - Building contractors must be licensed. 
    All persons desiring to perform any contracting work within the city, prior to performing such work, must first apply in writing to the tax collector, upon forms provided by the city, for a contractor license. All licenses issued will be effective from the date of issuance and shall expire December 31 next following. The license fee for the license shall be in accordance with the general license law of the city. Any person performing work within the city without a license shall be charged a double license fee upon acquiring a license, plus an additional one-hundred-dollar fine. Failure to comply with licensing requirements will result in a general fine citation. 
(Code 1965, § 5-12; Ord. No. 2798, 7-12-04) 
Sec. 5-26. - Building contractors must be licensed and certified by the state licensing board of contractors. 
(a)  No building permit will be issued to any person, firm, partnership, co-partnership, association, corporation or other organization or any combination thereof (hereinafter called contractor) to construct, supervise, superintend, oversee, direct or in any manner assume charge of the construction, alteration, repair, improvement, movement, demolition, putting up, tearing down, or furnishing labor, material, or equipment and installing same for any building, highway, road, railroad, sewer, grating, excavation, pipeline, public utility structure, project, development, housing, or housing development, improvement, or any other construction undertaking for which the cost of same is fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more, unless the contractor has been issued a license by the state licensing board of contractors. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  A residential building contractor which is defined as any person, firm, partnership, co-partnership, association, corporation, or other organization, or any combination thereof, whose services are limited to construction, remodeling, repair, or improvement of single-family residences, duplexes, triplexes, or fourplexes; 
(2)  Owners of property who supervise, superintend, oversee, direct, or in any manner assume charge of the construction, alteration, repair, improvement, movement, demolition, putting up, tearing down, or maintenance of any building, railroad, excavation, project, development, improvement, plan facility, or any other construction undertaking, on such property, for use by such owner and which will not be for sale, rent, public use, or public assembly. 
(3)  Persons donating labor and services for the supervision and construction of churches. 
(c)  If an individual homeowner is issued a building permit to build or remodel a residential house, the house may not be sold or rented for a period of one (1) year after the certificate of occupancy is issued. 
(Ord. of 2-13-84; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-27. - Bond required. 
    Prior to engaging in any contracting work within the city all building contractors shall furnish to the city 
(1)  A five thousand dollar ($5,000.00) surety bond, a copy of which must be kept on file with the city clerk. 
(2)  Proof of general liability insurance. 
(Code 1965, § 5-13; Ord. of 2-13-84; Ord. No. 2536, 3-22-99; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-28. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this article and such person having violated or failed to comply with any provisions of this article shall be punishable as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 10-8-79; Ord. of 2-13-84) 
Sec. 5-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-29, which pertained to places where installation of a satellite dish is unlawful and derived from Ord. No. 1711, adopted Feb. 11, 1985. 
Sec. 5-30. - Buildings damaged by fire. 
    In the event of damage by fire, natural disaster, or other cause, in whole or in part, of any building or other structure, the owner of the building or his agent shall within forty-eight (48) hours secure the structure from unauthorized entry and remove loose debris from the property, and shall within six (6) months after such event either remove or cause to be removed the structure and all debris resulting therefrom or repair any and all damage and restore said structure in accordance with the city's building code. 
(Ord. No. 2417, 4-14-97; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-31. - Building(s) unoccupied for sixty days or more. 
    Any commercial or residential building within the city remaining unoccupied for a period of more than sixty (60) days shall be required to have an inspection performed by the city inspector prior to the restoration of electrical service. The inspection shall encompass all aspects of the building code, including but not limited to electrical, plumbing, mechanical, and any other issues affecting the safety of the structure. The property owner will be responsible for correcting any deficiencies and code violations cited under the current building code. 
(Ord. No. 2735, 5-28-02) 
Sec. 5-32. - Building facade standards. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official or his authorized designee to ensure that, on all commercial and residential construction, building facade materials and colors are consistent and in conformity with the surrounding area so as not to cause a distraction and hazardous situation for the motoring public. The building official or his authorized designee shall enforce this provision as part of the permit review process and the police department shall enforce this provision thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 2898, 10-8-07) 
Secs. 5-33-5-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-41. - Adoption of National Electrical Code. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city that certain electrical code known as the National Electrical Code as recommended by the National Fire Protection Association, and being more particularly the 1996 edition thereof, as the minimum standards allowed for all electrical installations, construction and materials and appliance used in connection with all electrical work and the operation of all electrical apparatus within the city. All electrical work and the operation of all electrical work of any nature shall conform to such special rules as may be adopted by the city council, and to the rules and requirements of the National Fire Protection Association for the installation of wiring and apparatus for electrical purposes as they are now established or may hereafter be amended, and such rules and regulations are hereby made a part of this article the same as if the entire code above mentioned were written out in its entirety. 
(Code 1965, § 6-18; Ord. No. 2403, 10-28-96; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt electrical code by reference, R.S. 33:1368 et seq. 
Sec. 5-42. - Aluminum wire. 
    All aluminum wire of a size smaller than #8, but not to include #8, shall be banned for use in the city and the aluminum wire when used shall not be spliced and shall be in one continuous run from the thermally protected device to the appliance or device to which it is to serve. 
(Ord. of 1-14-74) 
Sec. 5-43. - Fuses. 
    Every fuse or overcurrent protective device must be plainly marked with the number of amperes it is designed to carry, and it shall be unlawful for anyone to bridge a fuse block. 
(Code 1965, § 6-23) 
Sec. 5-44. - Old wire to be removed. 
    Electric contractors wiring old buildings or structures for electric light, heat or power where electric or gas lighting systems have been used are required to remove all old superfluous wires, pipes, fixtures, etc., before wiring the building or structure. 
(Code 1965, § 6-24) 
Sec. 5-45. - Pipe close to wires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any plumber, gas or steam fitter or other person to install, fix or place any metal pipe in a building nearer than three (3) inches from an electric light or power wire, unless such light or power wire is insulated under such requirements as may be imposed by the electrical inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 6-25) 
Sec. 5-46. - Metal conduit required. 
    Without regard to location, all buildings except strictly private residences, such as factories, hotels, churches, theatres, schoolhouses, office buildings, elevator shafts, hospitals, asylums or sanitoriums of any kind designed for the care and treatment of persons, assembly houses or public buildings, stores, warehouses, mills, grain elevators, oil or service stations garages, stables, dairies, and all buildings of a commercial and public character, and all other buildings where electrical installation would be generally subjected to mechanical injury wherein electrical wiring or conductors are installed and for service entrances for commercial and residential buildings, such wiring and conductors must be protected by approved metal conduit, and in all such existing buildings where renewals or extensions of the electrical wiring are made, the wiring whether concealed or open must be protected by approved metal conduits, or schedule 80 PVC with proper strapping required. 
(Code 1965, § 6-27; Ord. No. 2708, 11-12-01) 
Sec. 5-46.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2708, adopted Nov. 12, 2001, deleted § 5-46.1. Former § 5-46.1 pertained to restricting the use of a PVC conduit and derived from Ord. No. 2231, adopted Jan. 10, 1994. 
Sec. 5-47. - Public buildings. 
    In all buildings where the general public has access, the corridors, stairways, lobbies and exits must be sufficiently lighted to allow the safe and ready egress from such buildings at such time as the general public has access to same. No person shall install wiring of a temporary or decorative character in or about any building or structure without first having obtained permission in writing from the electrical inspector to install such work, and the inspector is authorized to grant written and limited approval for any temporary installation which may in his opinion be necessary. 
(Code 1965, § 6-29) 
Sec. 5-47.1. - Lighting fixtures. 
    When lighting fixtures are installed in suspended ceilings, they shall be attached to the building structure at two (2) corners, diagonally from each other. 
(Ord. No. 2232, 1-10-94) 
Sec. 5-48. - Signs. 
    Before any electrically illuminated sign shall be erected or placed in position upon any building or structure, full specifications giving size of chains, size of guys, size of bolts and nuts, inscriptions of sign, owner's name, the number of lights and wattage of same, proposed location where the sign is to be installed, name of contractor making installation, the manufacturer's name and the approximate overall dimensions of the sign must be submitted for approval. Such applications must also be accompanied by an approval from the building inspector as to its structural safety and conformity with the requirements of the building code for signs. The erection of any signs other than approved signs is strictly prohibited. All signs of a billboard type shall be treated as buildings and all electrical installations thereon must be in conformity thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 6-30) 
Sec. 5-49. - Meter loops. 
    All meter loops which are to supply electric current to combination stores and residences shall be placed in that part of the building which is to be used as a store and at a point readily accessible to representatives of the electric company and no one shall hang a calendar, picture or any other object over a main entrance switch or electric meter. No obstruction such as shelving, store fixtures, etc., shall be permitted over or under a main entrance switch and meter, nor within one (1) foot of the sides or immediately in front of same. 
(Code 1965, § 6-31) 
Sec. 5-50. - Liability. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to relieve or lessen the responsibility or liability of any person for injury or damage to any person or property caused by or resulting from any defects of any nature in any electrical work performed by the person, or in any electrical equipment owned, controlled, installed, operated or used by them. Nor shall the city, or any officer, agent or employee thereof incur or be held assuming any liability by reason or in consequences of any permit, permission, certificates of inspection, inspection or approval authorized herein, or issued or given as herein provided or by any reason or consequence of any things done or acts performed pursuant to any provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 6-12) 
Sec. 5-51. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article for which no specific penalty has been provided or shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any order of the electrical inspector given in pursuance of and by the authority of this article, and the rules embraced herein, shall be punishable as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1965, § 6-32; Ord. of 10-8-79) 
Sec. 5-52. - Ground fault circuit interrupter. 
    All electrical GFCI circuits are to be installed in bathrooms dedicated for the bathroom exclusively and that GFCI circuits are not allowed to service any other room. 
(Ord. No. 2647, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 5-53. - Microwave hoods. 
    Microwave hoods installed over a kitchen stove must have a dedicated 20 amp circuit servicing the microwave hood only. 
(Ord. No. 2744, 12-2-02) 
Secs. 5-54-5-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 5-66. - Electrical inspector. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of chief electrical inspector. The person chosen to fill the office of chief electrical inspector shall be possessed of such executive ability as is requisite for the performance of his duties, and shall have a thorough knowledge of the standards, materials and methods used in the installation of electrical equipment, shall be well versed in approved methods of construction for safety to persons and property, the status of the state relating to electrical work, and any order, rules and regulations issued by the authority thereof, and the National Electrical Code. 
(b)  The chief electrical inspector shall be appointed by the mayor and city council. 
(c)  The salary to be paid the chief electrical inspector shall be determined by the mayor and city council. 
(d)  Before entering upon the discharge of his duties, he shall duly file a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) payable to the city. He shall be removed from office only for cause after a full hearing by the mayor and city council, at which time he shall be entitled to appear and produce evidence in his behalf. 
(Code 1965, § 6-11; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-67. - Authority of chief electrical inspector. 
(a)  The chief electrical inspector shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building or premises in the discharge of his official duties, or for the purpose of making an inspection, reinspections or tests of the electrical equipment contained therein for its installations. When any electrical equipment is found by the chief electrical inspector to be dangerous to persons or property because of its being defective or defectively installed, the person responsible for the electrical equipment shall be notified in writing and shall make any changes or repairs required in the judgment of the chief electrical inspector, or any of his deputies to place such equipment in safe condition, and if such work is not completed within fifteen (15) days or any longer period that may be specified by the chief electrical inspector in the notice, the chief electrical inspector shall have authority to order the discontinuance of electrical service to the electrical equipment. In case of emergency, where necessary for safety of persons or of property, or where electrical equipment may interfere with the work of the fire department, the chief electrical inspector, or any of his deputies, shall have the authority to immediately disconnect or cause the disconnection of any electrical equipment. 
(b)  He shall have the right to remove or compel the removal of any obstruction, such as lath, plastering, ceiling or flooring, which may hinder a full and complete inspection of such wires or apparatus. 
(c)  He may remove or compel the removal of any such conductors which are enclosed in conduits or otherwise inaccessible for complete inspection when said conductors or appliances are not in accordance with the requirements of this article, or found to be unsafe to life or property, he shall have the right to condemn such conductors or appliances as hereinafter provided. 
(d)  He shall have the power to compel the suspension of any electrical work being done in a manner prohibited by this article. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder or interfere with the chief electrical inspector or any of his deputies in the discharge of their duties under this article. 
(f)  The chief electrical inspector may delegate any of his powers or duties to any of his assistants. 
(Code 1965, § 6-13) 
Sec. 5-68. - Placing of wires. 
    It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to regulate and determine the placing of wires or other appliances for electric lights, heat or power in all buildings in the city, and to cause all such wires or appliances to be placed, constructed and guarded as not to cause fires or accidents endangering life and property. No wires are to be attached to the top of the ceiling joist outside a vertical height of eighteen (18) inches. This is from the top of the ceiling joist to the bottom of the rafters. 

Wires Above Ceiling Joists
(Code 1965, § 6-14; Ord. No. 2041, 7-23-90) 
Sec. 5-69. - Inspector to have access. 
    The inspector shall have the right to the discharge of his duties to enter any building for the purpose of examination and testing the electrical appliances therein or thereon contained and for that purpose he shall be given access to all buildings, public or private, on application to the individuals or company owning or in charge of same. 
(Code 1965, § 6-15) 
Sec. 5-70. - Inspection on completion. 
    Upon completion of the wiring of any building for light, heat or power, there shall be the duty of the person doing same to notify the electrical inspector, who shall without unnecessary delay inspect such wiring and appliances, and if approved by him, he shall issue a certificate of satisfactory inspection, which shall contain the date and an outline of the results of his inspection, but no such certificate shall be issued unless such electrical wiring and appliances be in strict conformity with the rules and regulations prescribed or required by this article, nor shall any current be turned on such installations until such certificate is issued. 
(Code 1965, § 6-16) 
Sec. 5-71. - Reinspection. 
    Where reinspection of workmanship or material, or both, is made necessary through the failure of any person, their agents or employees, to comply with the provisions of this article in regard to workmanship and material and where, in the opinion of the electrical inspector, such failure is the result of negligence or carelessness, the reinspection fee shall be charged in accordance with the approved permit fee schedule. Failure to properly locate the place where inspections are requested causing the inspector to fail to be able to find the place and making it necessary that a second trip be made or causing him undue loss of time shall be charged for at the time rate as for reinspection mentioned above. The charge in each case shall be made against the contractor in whose name the electrical permit for the job was issued. Charges for reinspection and undue loss of time in attempting to locate jobs shall be paid at the end of each month upon receipt of notice from the permit clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 6-17; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06; Ord. No. 2933, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 5-72. - Records. 
    The inspector shall keep or cause to be kept a full and complete daily record of all work done, permits and licenses issued, examinations made and other official work performed, as required by this article, and shall make a report thereof to the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 6-19; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-73. - Permits. 
    No alterations shall be made in the wiring of any building for light, heat or power, or increases in the load carried by such wires, nor shall any building be wired for electrical lights, motors, or heating devices without a written permit therefor from the inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 6-20) 
Sec. 5-74. - Approval before covering required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, his agents or employees to cover or conceal or cause to be covered or concealed any electric light or power wiring without first obtaining a certificate from the inspector certifying that the wiring has been approved. 
(Code 1965, § 6-21) 
Sec. 5-75. - Notice of removal of wiring. 
    Whenever builders or persons engaged in repairing, painting, etc., find it necessary to remove wires from buildings in prosecuting their work, the owner and/or occupant of such building shall serve the inspector with written notice twenty-four (24) hours before such contemplated work is begun and the inspector shall have authority in his discretion to direct the owners of such wires to remove the same. 
(Code 1965, § 6-22) 
Sec. 5-76. - Work to be done under direction of electrical inspector. 
(a)  Whenever wires, now or hereafter erected, are moved under permission of section 5-44, work shall be done under the direction of the electrical inspector and by competent electricians at the expense of the person procuring the change. 
(b)  The provisions of the article shall govern for any and all temporary services and a license and permit shall be required to install any temporary equipment to provide temporary electrical energy to a dwelling, place of construction or area of remodeling. 
(c)  Failure of any person within the meaning of this article to take out a permit prior to providing any services governed hereby or making any installation or repair, shall be subject to a penalty of double the amount of the fixed fee of the permit for the type of service furnished, repair or installations made, and this shall be in addition to any and all other penalties provided for herein. 
(Code 1965, § 6-26) 
Sec. 5-77. - Approval of plans and specifications required. 
    All plans and specifications for electrical installations must be submitted to the electrical inspector or by the builder or architect drawing such plans and specifications for approval as the service location and class of wiring before being submitted to the electrical contractors for the purpose of receiving bids. 
(Code 1965, § 6-28) 
Sec. 5-78. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Any person desiring an electrical permit shall at the time of filing an application therefor pay to the city a fee based upon the approved permit fee schedule. 
(b)  All fees must be paid prior to the issuance of any permit. A double fee shall be assessed if a permit is not obtained prior to starting work. 
(Code 1965, § 6-33; Ord. of 11-8-82; Ord. No. 1827, 2-9-87; Ord. No. 2118, 4-22-91; Ord. No. 2817, 3-7-05; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06; Ord. No. 2933, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 5-79. - Temporary cut-in permit. 
    For an electrician to obtain a temporary cut-in permit either the general contractor, owner, architect, or electrical contractor must submit a letter releasing the city of all responsibilities and stating a need for a temporary cut-in permit. Prior to issuing a temporary cut-in permit all permits for a job must be inspected and approved by the city inspector. This permit shall be valid for thirty (30) days for residential or ninety (90) days for commercial. If all final inspections have not been completed the building inspector will notify the owner that their electrical service will be discontinued within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 1816, 7-28-86; Ord. No. 2345, 2-26-96) 
Secs. 5-80-5-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 5-91. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2980, adopted Nov. 28, 2011, repealed § 5-91, which pertained to the board of electrical examiners, created, composition, appointment of members, term, removal of members and derived from Code 1965, §§ 2-24, 2-25; Ord. No. 2233, adopted Jan. 10, 1994; Ord. No. 2505, adopted Feb. 23, 1998; and Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; boards and commissions generally, § 2-121 et seq. 
Sec. 5-92. - Qualification of applicants; permits. 
    Permits may be issued to the individuals, firms, or corporations when the person to be in charge of the work for the individual, firm, or corporation holds a City of Gonzales license, and only so long as he or a licensed electrician under this division shall remain in charge of electrical work for such individual, firm or corporation. A homeowner may be issued a homeowner's permit. 
(Code 1965, § 6-1; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-92.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-92.1, which pertained to electrical examinations and derived from Ord. No. 2025, adopted Feb. 26, 1990. 
Sec. 5-93. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of installing, maintaining, altering or repairing within the city any electric wiring, devices, appliance or equipment unless such person shall have received an electrical contractors license, nor shall any person, except a person employed by and working under the direction of a holder of an electrical contractors license in any manner undertake to execute any work of installing, maintaining, altering or repairing any electrical wiring, device, appliance or equipment unless such person shall have received an electrical contractors license. Any person performing work within the city without a license shall be charged a double license fee upon acquiring a license, plus an additional one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine. Failure to comply with licensing requirements will result in a general fine citation. No license shall be required in order to execute any of the following classes of work: 
(1)  Minor repair work, the replacement of lamps and the connection of portable devices to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed; 
(2)  The installation, alteration or repair of wiring, devices, appliances or equipment for the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence where such wiring, device, appliance, or equipment operate at a voltage not exceeding fifty (50) between conductors and do not include generating or transforming equipment capable of supplying more than fifty (50) watts of energy; 
(3)  The installing, alteration, or repair of electrical wiring, devices, appliances or equipment installed by or for an electrical public service corporation for the use of such corporation in the generation, transmission, distribution or metering of electrical energy, or for the use of such a corporation in the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence; 
(4)  Any work involved in the manufacture, test or repair of electrical material, device, appliances or apparatus, but not including any permanent wiring other than that required for testing purposes; 
(5)  The assembly, erection and connection of electric apparatus and equipment by the manufacturer of such apparatus and equipment, but not including any electric wiring other than that involved in making electrical connections on the apparatus or equipment itself or between two (2) or more parts of such apparatus or equipment. 
(Code 1965, § 6-2; Ord. No. 2799, 7-12-04; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Cross reference- Occupational license taxes, § 18-16 et seq. 
Sec. 5-94. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-94, which pertained to requirements for a license and derived from Code 1965, § 6-3; Ord. No. 1742, adopted Nov. 11, 1985; and Ord. No. 1827, adopted Feb. 9, 1987. 
Sec. 5-95. - Fees; term. 
(a)  Every person desiring to engage in the business of electrical construction and of the installation of wiring, and apparatus for electrical light, heat or power in the city shall before doing so obtain a license therefor, the fee for which shall be an initial fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and the same shall be paid into the treasury of the city before such license shall become effective. The annual renewal fee thereafter to be one hundred dollars ($100.00). Such license shall be issued by the city after presentation of certificate from the board of electrical examiners and the payment of the fee above mentioned. Any person found doing electrical work in the city without such license shall be guilty of a violation of the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Licenses granted under this division shall be for the fiscal year ending December thirty-first and shall not be transferable, and the full fee shall be charged for any year or fraction thereof provided that any person commencing business any time after July first of any year shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the half year or portion thereof, except that in establishments or buildings having permanently in its employ a man of such mechanical and electrical knowledge and experience as to be able to make electrical installations for light, heat or power may have such employee take the examination herein provided for, and if applicant shall prove to the board his ability to properly install such work only in the establishment or building in which he is employed, upon payment of fifty dollars ($50.00) per annum by his employer. 
(Code 1965, § 6-4; Ord. No. 1827, 2-9-87) 
Sec. 5-95.1. - Inactive electrical license. 
    A master electrician may obtain an inactive license for a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. With an inactive license, the electrician cannot perform any work within the city. In the event that an electrician holding an inactive license desires to do work, he must first obtain a regular license by paying an additional fifty dollars ($50.00) and complying with the insurance and bond requirements as provided in section 5-100. An electrician cannot obtain an inactive license for more than five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 4-24-89) 
Sec. 5-96. - Exceptions for homeowners. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this division, nothing shall prevent an individual from doing electrical work within his own home; provided that prior to engaging in such work he present to the examining board a plan or sketch of the work to be undertaken, and the board, provided such plan or sketch demonstrates his ability to put in the job in accordance with the provisions of this article shall issue a permit for same. Such work on its completion shall be subject to inspection by the chief electrical inspector, and shall not be tied into any source of electrical current, except for reasonable test purposes, until a certificate of approval has been issued. Failure to comply with this or any other applicable provisions of this article, shall subject such individual to the same penalties as provided herein for persons duly licensed. 
(Code 1965, § 6-4(c); Ord. of 12-10-73) 
Sec. 5-97. - Revocation of licenses. 
    Any license granted under this division may be revoked by the board if the holder of same violates any ordinance or laws relating to electrical wiring, or is guilty of electrical construction which is a hazard to life and property, or for transferring or allowing, directly or indirectly, a person other than the lawful holder to operate or obtain permits to do work under the license provided the holder of same to be found guilty of such violation by a court of competent jurisdiction. When a license is revoked, a new license will not be granted to the same person for a period of thirty (30) days, or more, nor until such person shall have fully corrected the faulty construction or other violations of the provisions of this article, and shall have made application and paid the fee as required for the original license. The board of electrical examiners shall have discretionary power to withhold the granting of a new license subsequent to the revocation of license for cause for a period not to exceed three (3) months. 
(Code 1965, § 6-5) 
Sec. 5-98. - Failure to correct defect. 
    Any person who shall fail to correct any defect in his work, after having been duly notified for ten (10) days by the electrical inspector, shall not receive any further permit until such defect has been corrected, and any case in which any person shall continue to or persistently violate this article or the orders of the board of electrical examiners as transmitted through the inspector touching the same, the permit of such reissuance of any permit so forfeited shall be only after recommendation to that effect shall have been made by the board. 
(Code 1965, § 6-6) 
Sec. 5-99. - Established place of business required. 
    Every licensed person must have and maintain an established place of business, and have a sign displayed, and have someone in attendance to receive complaints from the electrical inspector or other persons concerned. 
(Code 1965, § 6-7) 
Sec. 5-100. - Bond required. 
(a)  Every person licensed under this division shall give surety bond to the city in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned upon faithful compliance with the ordinances and laws relating to the safe construction and the agreement to pay all damages, costs and expenses that may be caused by negligence of such person through failure to comply with the ordinances and laws. 
(b)  Every person licensed under this division shall provide proof of general liability insurance. 
(Code 1965, § 6-8; Ord. No. 2536, 3-22-99; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-101. - Responsibility for defects. 
    Every person licensed in accordance with this division shall be responsible for any and all defects of any construction installed by them until such time as a certificate of approval has been issued and also for any and all defects that may have been concealed by such person and discovered by the electrical inspector and/or his duly authorized agent, after a certificate of approval has been issued by the electrical inspector approving the construction. After the issuance of the certificate of' approval, the person in whose name the miter is contracted shall be responsible for all defects caused by themselves. 
(Code 1965, § 6-9) 
Sec. 5-102. - Sign required. 
    Each person operating under license granted in accordance with this division shall have displayed in a conspicuous place in front of each and every place where work of an electrical nature and character is being done by them a sign giving the name and address of the person doing the work and the words "licensed electrician" in letters not less than two (2) inches high, and the display of such sign by other than a duly licensed electrician shall constitute a violation of this article and shall be punishable as such. 
(Code 1965, § 6-10) 
Secs. 5-103-5-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Gas, § 20-16 et seq.; water, § 20-41 et seq.; sewage, § 20-66 et seq.; storm sewers and drains, § 20-101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-116. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Gas fittings means that branch of plumbing which deals solely with the installations of gas piping and gas fixtures and the proper venting of same. No work shall be classified as gas fitting which involves connections either to the public water or sanitary sewer system. Gas fitting shall be treated as a branch of plumbing work throughout this article. 
    Plumbing and/or gas fixture means any receptacle, vessel or contrivance which receives water and/or gas from its respective main and which disposes its waste and impure water into the proper city drainage system, and its products of combustion into the air in an improved manner. Examples of some of the more common plumbing and gas fixtures are: all types of both tubs, sinks, lavatories, urinals, water closets, washing machines and laundry trays, air-conditioning units, gas stoves, heaters, ranges, refrigerators, boilers and floor furnaces, ice boxes, floor drains, etc. 
    Plumbing inspector shall mean the chief plumbing inspector of the city. 
    Plumbing work means the proper manual manipulations which are required in the installation, venting and repair of all plumbing and gas fixtures and of all property of house sewers within the property line of all residences, office buildings, hotels, schools, business establishments, etc. 
(Code 1965, § 12-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-117. - Floor drains. 
(a)  Floor drains when connected to house drains must be trapped and vented near the inlet like a fixture. When it is not practicable to connect the vent near the inlet, a running trap may be used at a convenient point along the line vented on the sewer side, with an air inlet on the house side. The latter need not be extended to the roof but may be ended outside the building away from any opening. This does not eliminate traps at inlets. 
(b)  All commercial buildings must have a trap primer on all floor drains. 
(Code 1965, § 12-25; Ord. No. 2601, 5-17-99) 
Sec. 5-118. - House drain. 
    Where a house drain passes through a wall, it shall not be built in solid. The pipe shall be cast-iron. 
(Code 1965, § 12-27) 
Sec. 5-119. - Sewer connections. 
    Every house shall be separately and independently connected with the city sewer, except in cases where there are two (2) buildings on the same lot. In that case, the sewer connection of the one may be connected with that of the other. Where several buildings adjoin each other, side owner or owners of same may connect all of them on their own responsibility in one (1) sewer line across the rear of buildings or through an open space to the street by special permission from the inspection division when, in his opinion, connections justify same being done. In such cases, the pipe shall not be less than six (6) inches in diameter. However, the connection for each lot shall be made to the sewer properly serving that lot and not carried to another street except in cases where this is not practicable. Saddle connections for sewer tie-ins are not permitted. 
(Code 1965, § 12-28; Ord. No. 2633, 5-8-00) 
Sec. 5-120. - Sewer to property line. 
    In connection to the city sewer system, a six-inch line shall be laid to the property line and a four-inch by four-inch (4 × 4) reducer with a four-inch "Y" branch properly capped for a cleanout installed at the property line, the piping and fittings shall comply with sections 5-121 and 5-123. The "Y" branch extensions into a cast-iron or approved plastic, under section 5-124, cleanout for flush with the floor level shall contain a lead-caulked regulation cast-iron or approved plastic, under section 5-124, cleanout plug. The cover of the cleanout shall indicate sewer cleanout. 
(Code 1965, § 12-29; Ord. of 7-9-73; Ord. of 8-11-75; Ord. No. 1719, 4-22-85) 
Sec. 5-121. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2749, adopted March 24, 2003, deleted § 5-121, which pertained to soil pipes under buildings and derived from Code 1965, § 12-30. 
Sec. 5-122. - Pipes defined. 
    That portion of the main drainage system which extends from a point of discharge two (2) feet from the outer wall of the building or residence to the property line is hereby defined as the property sewer. The building or residence drainage system is defined as the combination of all horizontal and vertical soil and water pipes including their vent pipes. Soil pipes are defined as the pipes which receive the discharge of water closets. Waste pipes are defined as the pipes which receive the discharge of any plumbing fixtures other than water closets. 
(Code 1965, § 12-31) 
Sec. 5-123. - Cast-iron pipe; where used. 
    All exposed horizontal drainage pipes beneath residences may be of PVC Schedule 40, or equivalent, unless the property owner specified cast-iron pipe. All vertical and horizontal drainage pipes which are enclosed without free air space in brick, tile, concrete or similar materials may, also, be PVC Schedule 40, or equivalent, and, also, any water pipe so laid as to present opportunity for breakage due to contact with structural elements, although water pipe may be of brass or copper. Where PVC Schedule 40 is used under buildings on piers, the pipe must be supported by straps every three (3) feet. 
(Code 1965, § 12-32; Ord. of 8-11-75; Ord. of 4-25-77; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-124. - Pipe specification. 
    Schedule 40 PVC pipe is required for sewer running under a driveway. 
(Code 1965, § 12-33; Ord. of 8-11-75; Ord. No. 2660, 5-14-01; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-125. - Grade of building or residence; drainage system. 
    The building or residence drainage system shall have a downward inclination of at least one-quarter of an inch for each foot of horizontal piping. 
(Code 1965, § 12-34) 
Sec. 5-126. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-126, which pertained to securing and caulking pipe and derived from Code 1965, § 12-35.

Where the total height of a stack exceeds forty (40) feet the upper forty (40) feet in height only can be standard, all in excess of forty (40) feet shall be extra heavy from the ground up to a point exceeding forty (40) feet. In buildings where the length of the stack is less than above stated, the aforesaid pipes may be standard, and standard fittings, and shall extend nine (9) inches through the roof, full size. 
(b)  All soil, waste and vent pipes shall be sound, free from holes, and of uniform thickness, and shall conform to the following weights and depths of hubs:

Sec. 5-137. - Waste pipe. 
(a)  The waste pipe of every sink, basin, bath, water closet, urinal and each set of wash trays or other fixtures must be separately and effectively trapped and independently connected with the soil or waste lines, and the trap shall be near as practicable to the fixture which it serves. In no case shall a trap be more than two (2) feet from the fixtures except where not more than three (3) wash trays or washstands are set together, then the set may have one and one-half inch connections to trap at the end of fixture, or where especially provided for in the rules. 
(b)  Floor drains and drain lines in commercial buildings shall not be less than three (3) inches. 
(Code 1965, § 12-46; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-138. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-138, which pertained to wastewater from automatic washing machines and derived from Code 1965, § 12-47; Ord. No. 2623, adopted Feb. 14, 2000, and Ord. No. 2749, adopted Mar. 24, 2003. 
Sec. 5-139. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-139, which pertained to connecting refrigerators and derived from Code 1965, § 12-48. 
Sec. 5-140. - Air conditioning systems. 
    The drain pipe for cooling water for air conditioning systems shall be connected to a storm sewer or a sanitary sewer if either such sewer is available within two hundred (200) feet of the property. The connection for this drain shall be as described in section 5-139. If neither a storm or a sanitary sewer is available within two hundred (200) feet, the method of disposal of such waste water must be approved by the director of public works. The requirements of this section shall apply to all air conditioning installations using cooling water whether they have been previously installed or constitute new work. Wastewater shall not be discharged into streets or street gutters without special approval of the department of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 12-49) 
Sec. 5-141. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-141, which pertained to bar counter sinks and derived from Code 1965, § 12-50. 
Sec. 5-142. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-142, which pertained to unused openings and derived from Code 1965, § 12-51. 
Sec. 5-143. - Breaking in joints. 
(a)  Whenever it becomes necessary to remove part of the cast iron soil or waste pipe to obtain an opening, or for other purposes, and both ends are permanently fastened, an insertible joint of approved pattern shall be used. 
(b)  No holes will be allowed to be cut in any cast-iron or wrought iron pipe or sewer connection, for any purpose, that cannot be properly closed by plugs. Where it is necessary to open a pipe, the pipe broken shall be removed and a cleanout put in, that it may be accessible for future use. 
(Code 1965, § 12-52) 
Sec. 5-144. - Hollow stobs for water lines and vent pipes. 
    All hollow stobs protruding through finished concrete shall be filled with tar or polyfoam at the time of the top out inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2809, 1-10-05) 
Secs. 5-145-5-150. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2749, adopted Mar. 24, 2003, deleted §§ 5-144-5-150, which pertained to traps, acids, lead joints, and ferrules, waste or vent pipe encasements, venting and reventing, crown vents and branch vents respectively, and derived from §§ 12-53-12-59 of the 1965 Code. 
Sec. 5-151. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-151, which pertained to the height above the roof and derived from Code 1965, § 12-60. 
Sec. 5-152. - Building moved or burned. 
(a)  Whenever a building has been moved to a new location or partially destroyed by fire or other causes, the tests, inspections and inspection fees, required for same, shall be just as in the case of new work if so directed by the plumbing inspector. If preliminary inspection, however, shall show that all of such tests and inspection are not necessary, the plumbing inspector shall have the authority to omit such as are unnecessary and to prorate the inspection fees required, as in his judgment seems proper. 
(b)  Old house sewer and drains may be used on connection with new buildings or new plumbing only when they are found, on examination and test, to conform in all respects to the requirements governing new sewers, or drains, as prescribed in this article. If the old work is found defective, the plumbing inspector shall notify the owner to make the necessary changes to conform with this article. 
(Code 1965, § 12-61) 
Secs. 5-153-5-155. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2749, adopted Mar. 24, 2003, repealed §§ 5-153-5-155, which pertained to branch vents, soil pipes, and closets respectively and derived from §§ 12-62-12-64 of the 1965 Code and Ord. No. 2411, adopted Jan. 28, 1987). 
Sec. 5-156. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-156, which pertained to vent pipes and derived from Code 1965, § 12-65. 
Sec. 5-157. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-156, which pertained to unventilated rooms and derived from Code 1965, § 12-66. 
Sec. 5-158. - Strainers. 
    All waste pipes from fixtures, other than water closets, must be provided at the inlet with strong metallic strainers to exclude from such waste pipes all substances to likely obstruct them. 
(Code 1965, § 12-67) 
Sec. 5-159. - Grease traps. 
(a)  All commercial establishments which are now or may heretofore be in the business of processing food or any substance of any nature which may contain fat, oil or grease, shall provide either within or without the establishment, a grease trap of a minimum size to be determined the city wastewater supervisor in accordance with state requirements. The minimum grease trap will be three (3) gallons for a triple compartment sink in an existing building. Further, everything will be routed through the building grease trap except toilets, urinals and lavatories, including floor drains in restrooms. 
(b)  Additionally, all such establishments described in paragraph (a) above shall provide a dumpster pad with a floor drain connected to the sewer collection system. Such drain shall be equipped with an approved grease trap system, and the floor drain shall also be fitted with a screen basket to prohibit solids from entering the sanitary sewer system. 
(c)  All multi-family developments shall provide a grease trap of sufficient size to properly service the establishment, said size shall be determined by the city wastewater supervisor in accordance with state requirements. 
(d)  For the design see the drawing on file in the office of the plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 12-68; Ord. No. 2204, 7-27-92; Ord. No. 2510, 4-27-98; Ord. No. 2634, 5-8-00; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-160. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-160, which pertained to vent flashing specifications and derived from Code 1965, § 12-69. 
Sec. 5-161. - Fixtures to be connected to sewer. 
    All connections to the city sewer line from the exterior of the connecting structure to the city sewer main shall be made with the application of purple primer on all joints and connections. 
(Code 1965, § 12-70; Ord. No. 2734, 5-28-02; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-162. - Waste or liquid refuse. 
    All foul or waste or liquid refuse shall be carried into the sewer in each and every building connected with the sewerage system. This includes the discharge from all water closets, sinks, bathtubs, washstands, laundry tubs, dentists' and surgeons' sinks, cuspidors, washing machines and air conditioning systems and foul refuse from manufactories when small in amount. The city council reserves the right, however, to require other means of removal in cases where such manufacturing wastes would overload or damage the sewerage system in any way. 
(Code 1965, § 12-71; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-163. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-163, which pertained to cesspools, vaults, and earth closets and derived from Code 1965, § 12-72. 
(Code 1965, § 12-72) 
Sec. 5-164. - Water supply pipes and shut-off. 
    All water supply pipes should be three-quarter inch up to sixty (60) feet and then one (1) pipe size larger for every sixty (60) feet up to pipe size. 
(Code 1965, § 12-73; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-165. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-165, which pertained to supply pipe specifications and derived from Code 1965, § 12-73 and Ord. No. 1716, adopted Apr. 22, 1985. 
Sec. 5-166. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-166, which pertained to water supply pipes and derived from Code 1965, § 12-75; Ord. No. 1717, adopted Apr. 22, 1985; and Ord. No. 1718, adopted Apr. 22, 1985. 
Sec. 5-167. - Persons allowed to make gas and water connections. 
    No person shall do any work on pipes and appurtenances connected with, or to be connected with, the water service pipe or the gas service pipe nor shall he remove or add any fixture opening, unless he has been licensed to perform such work by the city and has secured a permit to perform the work. This shall not be construed to prohibit a person from disconnecting or reconnecting gas heaters located on his own premises. Any person performing work within the city without a license shall be charged a double license fee upon acquiring a license, plus an additional one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine. Failure to comply with licensing requirements will result in a general fine citation. 
(Code 1965, § 12-76; Ord. No. 2800, 7-12-04) 
Sec. 5-168. - On service. 
    Rules and regulations governing gas pipes, connections and fixtures shall be as provided by the National Board of Fire Underwriters Pamphlet No. 54, titled "Standards of the National Board of Fire Underwriters For the Installation, Maintenance and Use of Piping, Appliance and Fittings for City Gas" as recommended by the National Fire Protection Association. 
(Code 1965, § 12-77) 
Sec. 5-169. - Work inspected. 
    All work connected with or to be connected with the service pipes of the water and gas supply system shall be subject to inspection and approval by the plumbing inspector and any person who does or has done such work in violation of this article shall be subject to the penalties specified in section 5-182. 
(Code 1965, § 12-78) 
Sec. 5-170. - Shut-off. 
    All hotels and motels built in the city shall provide a shut-off valve for every hotel/motel room constructed. 
(Code 1965, § 12-79; Ord. No. 2609, 5-24-99; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-171. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-171, which pertained to stop cocks and derived from Code 1965, § 12-80. 
Sec. 5-172. - Ball valves. 
    Where attic or roof tanks feed directly from the service pipes and are used to supply fixtures, such tanks will be equipped with substantial ball valves of approved pattern. 
(Code 1965, § 12-81; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-173. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-173, which pertained to temporary water service and derived from Code 1965, § 12-82. 
Sec. 5-174. - Fixtures installed below street levels in flood prone areas. 
    No water closet or other fixtures shall be installed in any basement, cellar or area, the top of which closet bowl or fixture is below the level of the natural grade of the streets abutting the property, provided, however, a permit shall be issued conditioned that the owner or owners take all risk or damage that may result from water setting back into the premises from the main sewers, and in order to prevent as much as possible the setting back of water, the owner is hereby required at his own risk and cost, to put in a self-acting or other valve in all cases where the back flow from the sewer is to be apprehended, and it shall be the duty of the owner to keep the valve in order, and he shall be responsible for its action in all cases. This valve must be arranged so as to not interfere with the operation of the plumbing system above the street level. 
(Code 1965, § 12-83; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-175. - Rejectors ventilated. 
    The soil or waste pipe leading from an ejector or other appliance for raising sewerage or other waste matters to the street sewer shall, where a water closet or water closets are installed, be ventilated, by a vent pipe not less than two (2) inches in diameter. When fixtures other than water closets are installed, the waste pipe shall be ventilated by a vent pipe of the same diameter as the waste pipe. Soil vent, vents and revents for ejector systems shall be installed according to the provisions of these rules governing soil waste, vent or revent pipes. The pump into which the above discharges shall be approved size to accommodate the discharge of all waste entering same and shall be constructed with a cast iron or concrete receiving tank, with air tight iron cover. Where ejectors are being installed in buildings where the gravity system of sewerage is also in use, the two (2) systems must be separately and independently ventilated as hereinabove prescribed for soil, vent and waste pipes. 
(Code 1965, § 12-84; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-176. - When drainage or private property connects to city storm sewer. 
    Only persons qualified to do plumbing work in the city are permitted to do work connected or to be connected to any storm sewer, and shall be subject to inspection and approved by the plumbing inspector. Storm draining inside to two (2) feet outside of the building, and two (2) feet above ground level outside, shall be constructed the same as sanitary plumbing. Any person who shall interrupt or resist an inspection of his work, shall be liable to a forfeiture of his certificate and deposit. 
(Code 1965, § 12-85) 
Sec. 5-177. - Wash racks. 
    All public and private wash racks for vehicles shall be trapped as per design or drawing on file in the office of the plumbing inspector, and shall drain in a city storm drain unless otherwise ordered. 
(Code 1965, § 12-86) 
Sec. 5-178. - Cutting streets. 
    All sewer, water, and gas connections crossing streets in the City of Gonzales shall be made by boring only. In cases where boring is otherwise prohibited, no cuts shall be made in any streets in the city by any person for the purpose of installing sewer, water, gas, or other service to any property abutting on or near the street or streets, without first making application to the inspection division of the city, and obtaining a permit therefore. Any street cut for this purpose shall be repaired and returned to its original condition within five (5) days after the initial cutting. 
(Code 1965, § 12-87; Ord. No. 2757, 5-12-03) 
Sec. 5-179. - Water service connections. 
(a)  Water service is defined as that portion of the water line from the main in the street to and including the meter. 
(b)  Reserved.

Under such conditions as outlined by exceptions, the meter may be located in the sidewalk after having obtained the approval of the inspection division. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  Reserved.
