Sec. 5-180. - Emergency provisions. 
(a)  Wherever in this article, a type of material or metal is required to be used in connection with a plumbing installation, any by reason of war emergency or otherwise, such type of material or metal is unobtainable or obtainable in limited quantity, then in that event, the city council may authorize other types of available material or metal for plumbing use. 
(b)  Wherever in this article, a type of material or metal is required to be used in connection with a plumbing installation, and by reason of new developments, other types of material or metal are developed having comparable qualities, then in that event, the city council may, on its own initiative or upon petition, and after investigation, authorize the institution of such new material or metal. 
(Code 1965, § 12-90; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-181. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-181, which pertained to plastic pipes and derived from Code 1965, § 12-92; an ordinance adopted Feb. 88, 1971; and Ord. No. 1702, adopted Dec. 10, 1984. 
Sec. 5-182. - Violations. 
    Any master plumber, journeyman plumber, property owner, or any other person in violation of the provisions of this article or any of the rules and regulations thereof shall be punishable as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1965, § 12-89; Ord. of 7-9-73; Ord. of. 10-8-79) 
Sec. 5-183. - Hose bib requirements. 
    A minimum of three (3) hose bibs on all residential buildings is required, effective January 1, 1997. 
(Ord. No. 2404, 10-28-96) 
Sec. 5-184. - Cross-connection control 
devices. 
(a)  The city of Gonzales shall maintain records of cross-connection hazard surveys along with records of the installation, testing, and repair of all backflow prevention assemblies installed for containment purposes. The City of Gonzales may take additional actions which may not be specifically covered herein that are deemed necessary to protect the City of Gonzales's water supply from potential or actual cross-connections in accordance with the requirements of the Louisiana State Plumbing Code, latest edition. 
(b)  New water services. 
(1)  The City of Gonzales shall approve the type of backflow-prevention assembly or method required for containment. 
(2)  The City of Gonzales shall require the installation of the appropriate backflow prevention assembly or method for containment before the initiation of water service. 
(c)  Existing water service. 
(1)  Any changes of, or additions to, existing water services shall be treated as new water services for the purpose of the ordinance. 
(2)  Each customer shall survey the activities and processes which receive water service and shall notify the City of Gonzales if cross-connections exist along with the degree of hazard. Upon the identification of a cross-connection hazard, the customer shall cause the appropriate backflow prevention assembly or method to be installed in a timely fashion. 
(3)  For existing water services, the City of Gonzales may inspect the customer premises to determine the degree of hazard. The City of Gonzales shall have the right to enter, with the consent of the customer, or upon the basis of a suitable warrant issued by a court of appropriate jurisdiction, any property to inspect for cross-connections. Upon identification of a hazard, the customer shall cause the appropriate backflow prevention assembly or method to be installed in a timely fashion. 
(4)  When high hazard cross-connections are found the City of Gonzales shall: 
a.  Develop a schedule of compliance which the customer shall follow, or 
b.  Terminate the water service until a backflow-preventer assembly or method for containment required by the City of Gonzales has been installed. 
(5)  Failure of the City of Gonzales to notify a customer that the customer has a high hazard cross-connection and should install backflow-prevention assemblies or methods for containment in no way relieves the customer of the responsibility to comply with all requirements of this section. 
(d)  Utility customer responsibilities. 
(1)  Utility customers shall be responsible for ensuring that no cross-connections exist without approved backflow protection within the customer's premises starting at the point of service from the public potable water system. 
(2)  Utility customers shall, at the customer's own expense, cause installation, operation, testing, and maintenance of backflow prevention assemblies required by the City of Gonzales. The customer shall advise the City of Gonzales in advance of when a device is to be tested to allow the city the opportunity to witness the test. 
(3)  Utility customers shall test the backflow prevention assembly using a certified, registered tester annually. If the customer fails to test the assembly within the annual testing period, as defined by the City of Gonzales, the city shall have the authority to terminate water service until the required inspection is complete and a report of the inspection is submitted to the City of Gonzales. 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) days after testing and/or repairs are completed, the customer shall provide the City of Gonzales with copies of records of the installation and of all tests and repairs made to the backflow prevention assembly. 
(5)  In the event of a backflow incident, utility customers shall immediately notify the City of Gonzales of the incident and take steps to confine any contamination or pollution. Water service will not be restored until corrective action is taken and approved after inspection by the City of Gonzales. 
(6)  In accordance with Section D108.3.4 of the LSPC, 2000 Edition, utility customers shall maintain records of installation, tests, repairs, overhauls, or replacements of backflow prevention devices or methods for at least five (5) years and, upon request, such records shall be made available to the City of Gonzales. 
(Ord. No. 2986, 1-10-12) 
Secs. 5-185-5-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 5-196. - Building plans to be submitted. 
(a)  Before any construction, alteration or repair, except as hereinafter provided, of any portion of the plumbing work of any building is begun the plumbing contractor, or property owner when doing his own work, shall submit suitable plans and specifications covering all of the proposed work to the plumbing inspector for his approval. Such plans shall show clearly the kinds and sizes of pipes and fittings, location of rooms containing water closets, the location of the main sewer "Y" to be connected to, and any other information requested by the plumbing inspector. 
(b)  Plans will not be required in cases of removal of stoppages, repairs, or leaks, broken fixtures, tanks, range boilers or faucets. 
(c)  Plans and specifications will be approved or rejected within twenty-four (24) hours when practicable. 
(Code 1965, § 12-11) 
Sec. 5-197. - Changes in plans, etc. 
    If the work is not begun under the approved plans within six (6) months from the date of approval, such plans must be again presented for approval, as the plans are approved under the condition that such approval expires by its own limitation of six (6) months from the date of approval, and where one plan has been submitted for more than one building, the rule shall supply to each of such buildings as if such plan had been filed for such building only. 
(Code 1965, § 12-12) 
Sec. 5-198. - Life of a permit. 
    No change or modification of approved plans will be permitted unless such change or modification be authorized by the master plumber or property owner, submitted to and approved by the plumbing inspector and placed on file, as in the case of original work, and further, no variation of rules not especially authorized by the city plumbing inspector, although it may be shown on plans and has passed inspection, will be permitted. The city plumbing inspector always reserves the right to compel the master plumber to rectify any infraction of the rules even though the work has been passed upon and a final certificate of inspection issued, and the master plumber's deposit will be held the same. If this article is amended all work commenced after the amendment becomes effective shall conform to the amended code regardless of the date of the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 12-13) 
Sec. 5-199. - Condemned plumbing old work. 
(a)  Whenever any plumbing fixtures in any building are condemned by the city plumbing inspector on account of their foul, unwholesome, imperfect or unsanitary condition, they shall be replaced by such installations as is required by these regulations. 
(b)  Whenever any gas piping, fixtures or vents are condemned by the plumbing inspector because they constitute a hazard to fire, life or public safety, they shall be replaced by installations which conform to the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The city inspector shall be required to write a letter to the property owners, or his agent, demanding that these unsanitary conditions be rectified. A carbon copy of the letter shall also be submitted to the city council. 
(d)  Should the property owner, or his agent, fail to comply with this letter or request within thirty (30) days, this property owner, or his agent, shall be subject to the provisions of section 5-182. 
(Code 1965, § 12-14; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-200. - Special permit. 
    Where additional fixtures are required, or alterations are to be made which cannot be practically constructed in accordance with all provisions of these regulations, a special permit, in writing, may be issued by the city planning inspector, upon approval of the city council, for such work, if, in their judgment, the conditions require it. But such additions or alterations shall be of a character that will make the plumbing system actually function in a safe, sanitary and satisfactory manner. 
(Code 1965, § 12-15; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-201. - Workmen must be competent. 
    All plumbing work shall be done by competent workmen for each particular class of work, and the plumbing inspector may stop any workman from doing any class of work in which he is found to be incompetent. Each job involving plumbing work for which a permit is granted shall be done under the actual personal supervision of a journeyman plumber. 
(Code 1965, § 12-16) 
Sec. 5-202. - Inspector to judge quality. 
    The city plumbing inspector is to be the judge of quality of the material and workmanship, and the construing of the regulations to their meaning. Should any difference of opinion arise, appeal from his decision must be made in writing to the chairman of the city council and must state clearly the full particulars of disputed points within twenty-four (24) hours thereafter, otherwise, his judgment shall govern the disputed situation. 
(Code 1965, § 12-19; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-203. - Application blanks. 
(a)  Before any person may perform any plumbing work within the city, an application to do such work shall first be filed at the office of the city plumbing inspector. This application must be made on the proper form and must clearly state the type and scope of work that will be performed, the person who shall perform the work, and the exact location of the property by lot and square number and subdivision, and by street address, at which such work will be necessary. 
(b)  Applications will be required in all the following cases: 
(1)  The installation of any new plumbing fixtures requiring water, gas or sewer main connections; 
(2)  The installation of all plumbing and gas systems within new residences, office buildings, hotels, schools, etc.; 
(3)  The major repairs to existing plumbing fixtures such as water closets, sinks, bath tubs, gas floor furnaces, etc.; 
(4)  The tie-in of existing plumbing fixtures with a new city sanitary sewer system; 
(5)  The remodeling of old works; and 
(6)  All other plumbing and gas installations or connections that are covered by this article which are not termed minor repairs. 
(c)  In case of doubt, the property owner or the master plumber shall first contact the city plumbing inspector before starting any plumbing work, because the property owner or the master plumber shall be held liable to the provisions of this article. No permit shall be issued by the city plumbing inspector until the applicant has fulfilled sections 5-152, 5-167, 5-222 and 5-226. 
(Code 1965, § 12-20) 
Sec. 5-204. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-204, which pertained to roughing-in certificate and derived from Code 1965, § 12-21. 
Sec. 5-205. - Notification of inspection. 
    The inspector must be notified when the work is begun and when the work is roughed-in and is ready for inspection. All work must be left uncovered for examination until inspected and approved. Notice of final inspection shall not be sent until the work is entirely ready for thorough inspection, and all sinks, closets, etc., set and all vaults and cesspools properly cleaned out and filled where premises are connected with the city sewer. 
(Code 1965, § 12-22) 
Sec. 5-206. - Time for inspection. 
(a)  Upon completion of the work the plumber shall so advise the plumbing inspector who shall, within one (1) working day, inspect the work. Should the work meet the requirements of the plumbing code as to both design and workmanship, the inspector shall furnish the plumber a certificate of approval. 
(b)  If the work does not meet the requirements of this article in every way, the work shall be disapproved and a disapproval certificate issued stating that particular section of this article which has been violated. Upon correction of defects the plumber shall apply for reinspection. If the building inspector determines that the reinspection process has been abused, he shall assess an additional charge based upon the approved permit fee schedule for each reinspection. The inspector may, at his option, waive the reinspection charge if in his opinion the plumber has been conscientious in his work, but only if there are extenuating circumstances indicating that the dereliction was not due to negligence. 
(Code 1965, § 12-23; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06; Ord. No. 2933, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 5-207. - New plumbing, tested. 
(a)  All new plumbing work must be tested by the water in the presence of a plumbing inspector, the test shall include all sewer, soil, waste and vent pipes, lead branches, ferrules and traps when under the floor. No hopper closets will be permitted. All gas piping of installation shall be tested by an air test or other test as prescribed by the city plumbing inspector and the test must be made in the presence of a plumbing inspector. 
(b)  The water test may be applied to the drainage system in its entirety or in sections. If applied to the entire system all openings in the piping shall be tightly closed, except at the highest opening above the roof and the systems filled with water to the point of overflow above the roof. 
(Code 1965, § 12-24; Ord. No. 2503, 2-9-98; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-208. - Permit, inspection fees. 
(a)  Any person desiring a plumbing permit shall at the time of filing an application therefor pay to the city a fee based upon the approved permit fee schedule. 
(b)  Where gas piping or gas fixtures are installed independently of other plumbing work or by a different contractor, there shall be a minimum inspection fee charged in accordance with the approved permit fee schedule. 
(c)  All fees must be paid prior to the issuance of any permit. A double fee shall be assessed if a permit is not obtained prior to starting work. 
(Code 1965, § 12-26; Ord. of 8-23-82; Ord. No. 1830, 2-23-87; Ord. No. 2437, 10-27-97; Ord. No. 2818, 3-7-05; Ord. No. 2933, 10-12-09) 
Secs. 5-209-5-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PLUMBERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Plumbers, R.S. 37:1361 et seq. 

Sec. 5-221. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2981, adopted Nov. 28, 2011, repealed § 5-221, which pertained to plumbing board and derived from Code 1965, § 2-26; and Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; boards and commissions generally, § 2-121 et seq. 
Sec. 5-222. - Generally. 
(a)  Applicants desiring to do plumbing contracting work shall first appear at the office of the city plumbing inspector and shall submit an application for a gas, water and sewerage certificate, filling out the forms regularly provided for such applications. These forms set forth the name and residence of the applicant, the number of years in the plumbing business, the name of the last employers and references as to the ability and reliability of the applicant. In addition the applicant must pay all necessary fees and must conform to the rules and regulations of the board as to sewerage, water and gas connections, and the applicant if his application be favorably acted upon, shall be subject to the penalties provided for violations of the provisions of this article. 
All applicants for plumbing and/or mechanical license in the city shall first comply with all state law regulations and then apply for and be scheduled for the City of Gonzales plumbing and/or mechanical test. 
Applicants shall be at least twenty-one (21) years old and shall pass a satisfactory examination given by the city council as to their ability to do plumbing work. The applicant must have not less than five (5) years of practical experience as a journeyman plumber. 
Applicants desiring to do gas fitting work shall first appear at the office of the city plumbing inspector and shall submit an application for a gas fitting certificate, filling out the forms regularly provided for such application. The forms shall set forth the name and residence of the applicant, the number of years in the gas fitting business, the name of the last employer and reference as to the ability and reliability of the applicant. In addition, the applicant must pay all necessary fees and must conform to the rules and regulations of the city council as to gas installation, and the applicant, if his application be favorably acted upon, shall be subject to the penalties provided for violations of the provisions of this article. 
Applicants must be at least twenty-one (21) years of age and shall pass a satisfactory examination given by the plumbing board as to their ability to do plumbing work. Applicants must have not less than one (1) year of practical experience in gas installations. 
Throughout this article a master gas fitter shall be regarded as a restricted type of master plumber, and all requirements, rules, regulations and penalties pertaining to master plumbers shall also apply to master gas fitters if they are pertinent and not specifically waived. A license for a master gas fitter shall be titled to show that the license is for a master plumber restricted to work pertaining to gas installations only. 
(b)  Any person wishing to do business as a master plumber shall file with the plumbing board a statement showing the composition of the firm, or if a corporation, a copy of its charter, and either must have at least one (1) active member or officer who is a qualified master plumber of the city and who must in fact direct the work of the firm. If this master plumber ceases to represent such firm or corporation actively in its negotiations with the plumbing board or does not devote sufficient time to the business, then the certificate of such firm or corporation shall thereby be void until another person has qualified as herein provided. 
All applications for a master plumbers' certificate shall be passed upon by the plumbing board and all master plumbers shall be required to take a master plumbers' test for either A-commercial and/or B-residential. 
Examinations shall be conducted by the plumbing board and shall be oral or written, or both and shall be sufficient to determine the ability of candidates to perform plumbing work, to draw proper plans for plumbing within residences, hotels, office buildings, etc., and to estimate the required materials and labor for the installations of such plumbing. In addition the examination shall be sufficient to test the applicant's knowledge and understanding of the theory and practice of sanitary plumbing and/or the plumbing regulations of the city. Examinations for master plumber's license for gas installations only shall pertain to gas work and the pertinent provisions of this article covering gas installation. 
A percentage of seventy-five (75) shall be required as a prerequisite for passing the examination, and anyone failing to make this percentage shall not be eligible for another examination until the expiration of six (6) months from the date of previous examination. Any master plumber who has not been actively engaged in operating a plumbing business for twelve (12) consecutive months shall be required to retake the master plumber's examination. 
The fee for the original master plumber's certificate to establish and operate a plumbing business shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each calendar year beginning January first and expiring December thirty-first. Certificates must be renewed each successive calendar year. The renewal fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and expiring December thirty-first. 
The fee for the original master plumber for gas installations license only shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each calendar year. 
All other requirements for this license shall be the same as those for the unrestricted master plumber. 
Every licensed master plumber must have and maintain an established place of business within the parish where he may be reached by his patrons, and he must have a sign displayed for identification. There shall be someone in attendance during regular office hours to receive complaints or notices from the city plumbing inspector's office by telephone. However, plumbing contractors from other cities may execute plumbing contracts in the city, after conforming to all ordinances of the city, if they maintain a master plumber licensed in accordance with this article on the job in the city who is empowered to make decisions and to remedy work not conforming to this article on his own responsibility, and who is accessible to the city plumbing inspector by local telephone during working hours from the time plumbing work is started until the date of final approval by the city plumbing inspector. 
The master plumber shall have an adequate supply of tools and shall display certificates that he has paid all city and state licenses required by law. No permit for any type of plumbing work shall be granted unless the master plumber fulfills these requirements. No master plumber shall employ a journeyman plumber who does not have a state journeyman license and a city certificate. 
(c)  A journeyman plumber must have a state certificate issued by the State Board of Examiners of journeyman plumbers. In addition, a journeyman plumber who desires to perform plumbing work for a master plumber within the city shall be required to obtain a city journeyman plumber's certificate from the office of the city plumbing inspector which shall be issued only after application and examination. No journeyman plumber shall be allowed to do plumbing work within the city before he has received such certificate. 
In no case, shall a journeyman plumber be permitted to perform plumbing contracting work. 
A journeyman plumber for gas installations only under a master plumber shall be required to obtain a city journeyman plumber's certificate limited to gas installations only from the office of the city plumbing inspector which shall be issued only after application and examination. In no case shall the journeyman gas fitter be permitted to perform gas contracting work. All requirements, rules or regulations or penalties in this article which apply to journeyman plumbers shall also apply to journeyman gas fitters unless they are obviously not pertinent or specifically waived. 
(d)  Every property owner shall have the right to do his own plumbing work for his own place of residence only upon compliance with the provisions of this section. All applications by property owners desiring to do their own work shall be passed upon by the plumbing inspector. Such applicants shall be required to furnish the plumbing inspector with proof of their reliability and ability to perform their own plumbing work in compliance with the requirements of this article, and in his discretion may be referred to plumbing board for final approval. 
The property owner shall be further required to furnish the plumbing inspector the following: 
(1)  A plan or sketch of the proposed work to be done; 
(2)  Reserved. 
A property owner may install plumbing in any property owned by him after successfully passing the journeyman plumber's examination given by the plumbing inspector and/or the plumbing board and receiving a city property owner's plumbing certificate. The fee for this certificate shall be five dollars ($5.00) per year. Hotels, etc., may qualify a plumber under this paragraph to do plumbing upon their own property. In all cases permits must be secured for work for which a master plumber must secure a permit. 
(e)  No person shall do any plumbing, gas, water or sewer work if he has not qualified under this section. Any person who is found guilty of violating this provision shall be subject to the provisions of section 5-223. 
(Code 1965, § 12-2; Ord. of 3-26-84; Ord. No. 1743, 11-25-85; Ord. No. 1830, 2-23-87; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-222.1. - Inactive plumbing license. 
    A master plumber may obtain an inactive license for a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. With an inactive license, the plumber cannot perform any work within the city. In the event that a plumber holding an inactive license desires to do work, he must first obtain a regular license by paying an additional fifty dollars ($50.00) and complying with the insurance and bond requirements as provided in sections 5-222 and 5-223. A plumber cannot obtain an inactive license for more than five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 2004, 4-10-89) 
Sec. 5-222.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-222.2, which pertained to the plumbing test and derived from Ord. No. 2026, adopted Feb. 26, 1990. 
Sec. 5-223. - Master plumber's deposit; license and bond. 
(a)  No master plumber shall be permitted to solicit or to cause to start any plumbing work until they have fulfilled the requirements of section 5-222 and until they have complied with this section. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of every master plumber and every person engaged in the business of plumbing in the city to give bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and in favor of the city, as surety, the bond to be approved by the director of finance and filed by him and to be conditioned that the person engaged in the plumbing business, in the city, will faithfully perform and observe all of the laws of the city, and of the state pertaining to plumbing and all of the rules and regulations established under the authority granted in this article. All plumbing work in the city, done by any person or by the surety under his or its bond, shall be executed in a workmanlike manner and in conformity with all of the laws and regulations applying thereto. The granting and issuance of a certificate for plumbing work shall in no way make the city liable for any work done under the certificate or any claim arising out of same and the city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from any accidents or any damages of any sort or character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such person in doing the work or by any unfaithful, improper or inadequate work done by any master plumber, person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of plumbing, or their agents and employees. 
(d)  The bond provided for herein shall be maintained and kept in full force and effect while the principal is qualified to engage in the plumbing business in the city, and for one (1) year after the expiration of the certificate, no matter whether expired, cancelled or revoked. 
(Code 1965, § 12-3; Ord. No. 2437, 10-27-97; Ord. No. 2536, 3-22-99) 
Sec. 5-224. - Display signs and permit numbers. 
    Every person qualified to do plumbing contracting work shall have displayed a sign in a conspicuous place in front of each and every place at which plumbing work is being done by him. This sign shall give the name and address of the person doing the plumbing work and shall have the words "licensed plumber" in letters not less than two (2) inches in height and will also include permit number of the job. Failure upon the part of any licensed plumber authorized to perform plumbing contracting work to fulfill this provision shall constitute a violation of this article. The city council shall hereby be authorized to revoke the certificate of the plumber for a period not in excess of sixty (60) days for the violation of this section. The display of any sign, as described above, by anyone not duly qualified shall constitute a violation of this article. Such violation shall be governed by section 5-223. 
(Code 1965, § 12-4; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-225. - Suspension of certificates. 
(a)  The certificate issued or granted to any master plumber or to any person engaged in plumbing work within the city may be suspended at any time by the city council or upon the recommendation to the board by the city plumbing inspector, for any violation of the rules and regulations of the city council and of this article. Wherever any improper plumbing work has been done by any master plumber or any person engaged in a plumbing business within the city, this plumber's certificate may be revoked by the city council. The city plumbing inspector's recommendation and proof of such improper work by a master plumber shall be submitted to the city council for its consideration. If a master plumber has been found guilty for any violation of the provisions of this article by the city council this board shall hereby be authorized to suspend the certificate of the master plumber for a period of not less than six (6) months, or revoke same as provided above, depending on the nature of such violation and the facts relative to same. Prior to such suspension or revocation the person violating this article shall be given notice in writing by registered mail, and a hearing held thereon by the city council. 
(b)  A city journeyman plumber's certificate may be suspended or revoked for the same reasons and in the same manner as prescribed for the suspension or revocation of the certificates of a master plumber. 
(Code 1965, § 12-5; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-226. - Master plumber. 
(a)  No person doing business as a plumbing contractor shall solicit plumbing work or shall cause, permit or make any connections to any soil, waste, water, gas or sewer pipe and/or pipe connected thereto, until such person has qualified before the city council as provided in section 5-222 and until such person has fulfilled the requirements of section 5-223. The office of the city plumbing inspector shall then issue a permit for each job. 
(b)  The mere fact that said work has been done will be considered sufficient to hold and to render the person in the plumbing business amenable to this article and specifically to section 5-223. 
(Code 1965, § 12-6; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-227. - Journeyman plumber. 
(a)  No journeyman plumber may engage in performing plumbing work until he is qualified. 
(b)  No journeyman plumber may perform any plumbing work for any person that has not qualified as a master plumber of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 12-7) 
Sec. 5-228. - Property owner. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  A property owner's permit shall be confined to the premises of his immediate and permanent residence, and this permit shall not be misconstrued as to cover any rental, commercial or friends' properties. 
(Code 1965, § 12-8; Ord. No. 2437, 10-27-97) 
Sec. 5-229. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-229, which pertained to non-certified persons doing plumbing work and derived from Code 1965, § 12-9. 
Sec. 5-230. - Obtaining permit fraudulently. 
    No person carrying on the plumbing business shall allow his name to be used by any other person directly or indirectly, either to obtain a permit, send in notices, make returns or to do any work under his license, under penalty of having his license revoked. 
(Code 1965, § 12-10) 
Sec. 5-231. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-229, which pertained to journeyman certificates and derived from Code 1965, § 12-17. 
Sec. 5-232. - Maintenance man. 
    Engineers of buildings, firemen or porters, general workmen around hotels, factories, etc., will not be allowed to do any work under this regulation, except the repairing of minor leaks where it is not necessary to remove any part of the work or fixtures, except where permit to do specific work has been granted by the city council, after examination as provided for property owners under the provisions above. 
(Code 1965, § 12-18; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-233. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-233, which pertained to temporary certificates and derived from Code 1965, § 12-91. 
Secs. 5-234-5-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MECHANICAL CODE 

Sec. 5-251. - Permit necessary; fees. 
    No air conditioning, heating, ventilation and mechanical refrigeration equipment shall be installed without first obtaining a permit for such work from the building official. All applicants for a permit shall, at the time of application, pay to the building official a fee in accordance with the approved permit fee schedule. 
(Code 1965, § 12-101; Ord. of 5-12-69; Ord. of 6-26-73; Ord. of 8-23-82; Ord. No. 1830, 2-23-87; Ord. No. 2339, 10-23-95; Ord. No. 2819, 3-7-05; Ord. No. 2933, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 5-252. - Right of entry. 
    The building official, or any of this authorized representatives in the discharge of their duties and upon proper identification, shall have authority to enter any building, structure or premises at any reasonable hour. 
(Code 1965, § 12-102) 
Sec. 5-253. - Air conditioning, heating, ventilation and mechanical refrigeration contractors; city license required. 
    All persons desiring to perform any air conditioning, heating, ventilation and mechanical refrigeration work within the city must first apply in writing to the tax collector upon forms provided by the city. All licenses issued will be effective from the date of issuance and shall expire December 31, next following. The fee for the original license shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Renewals thereafter will be one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any person performing work within the city without a license shall be charged a double license fee upon acquiring a license, plus an additional one hundred dollar ($100.00) fine. Failure to comply with licensing requirements will result in a general fine citation. 
(Code 1965, § 12-103; Ord. of 5-12-69; Ord. of 2-26-73; Ord. of 5-28-73; Ord. No. 1830, 2-23-87; Ord. No. 2801, 7-12-04; Ord. No. 2847, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5-253.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2847, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, repealed § 5-253.1, which pertained to air conditioning, heating, ventilation and mechanical refrigeration tests and derived from Ord. No. 2027, adopted Feb. 26, 1990. 
Sec. 5-254. - Scope of contractors; work. 
    All air conditioning, heating, ventilation and mechanical refrigeration contractors shall connect to an existing gas valve furnished by qualified plumbers, but they shall in no way run gas service itself unless he is qualified as a gas fitter with proper licensure. 
(Ord. of 5-28-73) 
Sec. 5-255. - Contractor's bond to be furnished. 
    Prior to engaging in any air conditioning, heating, ventilation and mechanical refrigeration work within the city all such contractors shall furnish to the city a five thousand dollar ($5,000.00) surety bond, a copy of which must be kept on file with the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 12-104; Ord. No. 2536, 3-22-99) 
Sec. 5-256. - Refrigerant line and condensant drains. 
(a)  For any refrigerant line passing under the slab the tubing must be in casing. 
(b)  On commercial building and condensant drains shall be routed through the sanitary sewer or storm drain. 
(Ord. No. 2511, 4-27-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2511, adopted April 27, 1998, added provisions designated as § 5-255. Inasmuch as there already exists a § 5-255, the editor has redesignated said section as § 5-256 to avoid duplication. 
Sec. 5-257. - Smoke detectors. 
    Smoke detectors shall be required in all commercial air conditioning systems, and when applicable, shall be connected to the fire alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 2790, 6-28-04) 
Secs. 5-258-5-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RELOCATING BUILDINGS 
DIVISION 1. - CITY ROADWAYS 

Sec. 5-271. - Permit required. 
    No person shall move or relocate any building or portion thereof from without to within, within to without, within or through the city, other than on a state maintained roadway, without first obtaining a permit for such work from the city. 
(Code 1965, § 5-23; Ord. of 10-9-72; Ord. No. 2221, 8-9-93) 
Sec. 5-272. - Contractor's license. 
    No permit shall be issued except to a contractor who has paid all licenses due to the city. Such license shall be in accordance with the general license law of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 5-24) 
Sec. 5-273. - Route must be submitted. 
    No permit for moving or relocating any building or portion thereof over any part of a public way, not including state maintained roadways, shall be issued unless the route therefor has been submitted to the public works manager, utilities manager, fire chief, and the chief of police or their authorized representatives, and to an official of the local electric utility company, and the local telephone utility company, and approved by them as not likely to cause unreasonable interference of traffic, or the movement of firefighting equipment, or damages to both private or public property. 
(Code 1965, § 5-25; Ord. No. 2221, 8-9-93) 
Sec. 5-274. - Signatures necessary; forms furnished by city. 
    The moving contractor and/or the owner of the building or portion thereof to be moved or relocated shall be responsible for obtaining the signatures of all the officials as provided for in section 5-273 after having submitted the plans for moving the building or portion thereof, in writing, to such officials upon forms furnished by the city. 
(Code 1965, § 5-26) 
Sec. 5-275. - Private or public property damages prohibited. 
    Before any telephone, electric light or power line or wire cable is cut or moved or any street lamppost or any other property is moved for the purpose of moving a building or portion thereof, the moving contractor and/or the owner of the building or portion thereof shall come to an agreement with the parties owning the same, or shall pay to them the amount agreed upon to cover damages and costs thereof. Only competent linemen shall be employed to do any electrical work. No shade tree or branch thereof shall be cut or trimmed for the purpose of moving any building or portion thereof, except with written consent of the owner of the property on which such tree is located. 
(Code 1965, § 5-27) 
Sec. 5-276. - Application; fee. 
(a)  All applications for moving or relocating permits shall be submitted to the building official after all the signatures required in section 5-273 have been obtained. The permit fee shall be set forth in the approved permit fee schedule. 
(b)  All applicants for a permit issued under this article shall have to conform to all ordinances of the city which govern buildings, plumbing, electrical, streets and other ordinances which will apply while such work is in progress. 
(Code 1965, § 5-28; Ord. No. 2933, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 5-277. - Public liability insurance; bond. 
    Any applicant for a permit under the provisions of this article before such permit is issued, shall secure public liability insurance with personal injury coverage of at least five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) for any person injured, and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for any two (2) or more persons injured in the same accident, and property damages of at least five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). In addition all applicants shall furnish a bond of at least one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) payable to the city to cover the costs of any public property damaged. 
(Code 1965, § 5-29) 
DIVISION 2. - STATE ROADWAYS 

Sec. 5-278. - Moving houses and heavy equipment over state maintained roadways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to move any house or heavy equipment over the state maintained roadways of this city between the hours of 6:00 to 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 to 6:00 p.m. 
(b)  No house or heavy equipment may be moved over the state maintained roadways of this city unless written notification of such movement and the route to be taken is received by the chief of police or his authorized representative at least three (3) working days in advance of such movement. 
(c)  The terms "house" and "heavy equipment" as used above shall refer only to those structures or equipment which require two (2) or more lanes of travel space and/or the raising or removal of overhead lines and wires for movement, provided that such terms shall also apply to any moving vehicle which, under normal city driving conditions, cannot reach and maintain a speed of at least twenty-five (25) miles per hour, assuming no other obstacles require slower speed. 
(Ord. No. 2221, 8-9-93) 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING PERMIT 

Sec. 5-279. - Building permit required. 
    No person shall move or relocate any building or portion thereof from without to within the city, or from one (1) location within the city to another location within the city, without first obtaining a building permit as required by section 5-22 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2416, 4-14-97) 
Sec. 5-280. - Time period for completion. 
    All renovation or repair of buildings or other structures relocated pursuant to this article shall be completed within six (6) months from the date of issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2416, 4-14-97) 
Sec. 5-281. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this article and such person having violated or failed to comply with any provisions of this article shall be punishable as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. 2416, 4-14-97) 
Chapter 5.5 - CHARITABLE BINGO, RAFFLES AND KENO[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1820, adopted Sept. 22, 1986, amended the Code by enacting provisions pertaining to charitable bingo, raffles and keno, designated as Ch. 23. Such provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 5.5 by the editor in order to maintain the alphabetical sequence of chapter titles. 
Cross reference- Charitable solicitations in public places, permit, § ;16-2. 

Sec. 5.5-1. - Lawful activities; use of proceeds. 
    The provisions of any other ordinance or regulation of the city to the contrary notwithstanding, upon being granted a license from the city clerk, it shall be lawful for any bona fide nonprofit veterans, charitable, educational or religious organization which has been domiciled in the city for a period of at least six (6) months prior to its application, holding at least seventy-five (75) percent of its meetings in the city, to hold and operate the specific kind of game or games of chance commonly known as raffle or raffles played by drawing for prizes or the allotment of prizes for chance, by the selling of shares or tickets or rights to participate in such game or games and by conducting the games or games accordingly; and the game of chance commonly known as bingo, defined as a games played for prizes with cards bearing numbers or other designations, five (5) or more in one line, the holder covering numbers, as numbered objects are drawn from a receptacle and the game being won by the person who first covers a previously designated arrangement of numbers on such a card; by selling shares or tickets or rights, the entire net proceeds of such games are to be devoted entirely to educational, charitable, patriotic, religious or public spirited [uses] within the state. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-2. - Electronic bingo unlawful. 
    It shall further be unlawful for such an organization to use electronic or video machines hereafter termed "electronic bingo machines". 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-3. - Pull-tab bingo. 
(a)  No organization, distributor, or manufacturer or any representative licensed hereunder, either with knowledge or circumstances whereunder it reasonably should have known shall possess, display, put out for play, sell, or otherwise furnish to any person any deal of pull-tabs: 
(1)  In which the winning pull-tabs have not been completely and randomly distributed and mixed among all other pull-tabs in the deal; 
(2)  In which the location or approximate location of any of the winning pull-tabs can be determined in advance of opening the pull-tabs in any manner or by device, including but not limited to any pattern in the manufacture, assembly, or packaging of pull-tabs by the manufacturer, by any markings on the pull-tabs or container or by the use of a light; or 
(3)  Which does not conform in any respect to these requirements as to manufacturer, assembly, or packaging. 
(b)  A distributor shall not purchase or be furnished any seals for pull-tabs from a manufacturer of pull-tabs unless all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The manufacturer's label or trademark has been registered with the office of state police; 
(2)  Each individual pull-tab manufacturer has conspicuously set forth on it the name of the manufacturer or a label or trademark which identifies its manufacturer; 
(3)  The pull-tab is of a type approved by the office of state police for use in Louisiana. 
(c)  The entire net proceeds from the use of electronic bingo machines and pull-tabs are to be devoted to educational, charitable, religious or public spirited uses. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Cross reference- Use of electronic bingo machines unlawful, § 5.5-2. 
Sec. 5.5-4. - License application requirements. 
(a)  Each applicant for such license shall file with the city clerk a written application therefor in the form prescribed in rules and regulations hereinafter promulgated, duly executed and notarized, in which shall be stated the name and address of the applicant together with sufficient facts relating to its incorporation and organization to enable the city to determine whether or not it is a bona fide organization or association in accordance herewith; the names and addresses of its officers, a list of all active members, the specific kind of game of chance intended to be held, operated and conducted by the applicant, and the place or places where, the date or dates and the time or times when, such game or games of chance are intended to be conducted by the applicant under the license applied for; the items of expense intended to be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating and conducting of such game or games of chance and the names and addresses of the persons to whom, and the purposes for which, they are to be paid; the specific purposes to which the entire net proceeds of such game or games of chance are to be devoted and in what manner; that no commission, salary, compensation, reward or recompense will be paid to any person for holding, operating, conducting or assisting in the holding, operating or conducting of such games of chance; that no proceeds of such game or games of chance shall be used in any manner for election campaign contributions; and a description of all prizes to be offered and given in all such games of chance to be held, operated and conducted under such license and such other information as shall be prescribed by such rules and regulations. 
(b)  The names and addresses of the owner or owners of the premises where the games of chance are to be operated shall be provided, and if owned by a corporation, the names and addresses of the officers and stockholders of the corporation including a list containing the names and addresses of all of its officers and members. The only exception to this provision shall be in the case of churches or synagogues, which are required to submit the names of those people responsible for the operation of the game of chance and the names of all persons who would be working in conjunction therewith. 
(c)  In each application there shall be designated an active member or members of the applicant under whom the games or games of chance described in the application are to be held, operated and conducted and to the application shall be appended a statement executed by the applicant and by the member or members, as designated, that he or they will be responsible for the holding, operating and conducting of such game or games of chance in accordance with this chapter, if such license is granted. 
(d)  All applicants for permits under this section shall file with their application proof of nonprofit tax-exempt status recognized by the Internal Revenue Service in compliance with Section 26 USCA 501C of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-5. - Investigation of license applicants. 
    The city clerk and city attorney shall make an investigation of the qualifications of each applicant and the application, and shall determine that the applicant is duly qualified to hold, operate and conduct games of chance under the provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations governing the holding, operating and conducting thereof in the city; that the member or members of the applicant designated in the application to hold, operate, conduct or assist in holding, operating or conducting the game or games of chance for which the license is applied, are bona fide active members of the applicant and persons of good moral character and have never been convicted of crime; and that no proceeds of the game will be used in any manner for election campaign contributions. After such investigation, the city clerk and city attorney shall present their report to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86; Ord. No. 2848, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5.5-6. - Hearing on license applicants. 
(a)  A hearing shall be conducted by the city council, held upon due notice to the applicant, at which time the applicant shall be entitled to be heard upon the qualifications of the applicant and the merits of the application. After said hearing, the city council shall vote to issue or deny a license to the applicant for the holding, operating and conducting of the specific kind, or one of the specific kinds, of games of chance applied for accordingly. 
(b)  Any license issued under this chapter may be amended upon application made to the city, if the subject matter of the proposed amendment could lawfully and properly have been included in the original license. 
(c)  No permit for the operation of games of chance under this chapter shall be issued to an organization which is directly associated with or a subsidiary of any organization who, at the time of the application, holds a permit for the staging of games of chance issued by the City of Gonzales. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86; Ord. No. 2848, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5.5-7. - Unlawful to operate without license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any organization whose license has been revoked or which has been denied a permit or license to hold, operate or conduct charitable games of chance within the city to hold, operate or conduct or assist in the holding, operating or conducting of any charitable game of chance on behalf of, in connection with or for the benefit of any other organization. 
(b)  The prohibition contained hereinabove shall extend to the officers and those individuals listed in the application or any organization denied such a permit or license. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-8. - Licenses. 
    Each license shall be in such form as shall be prescribed in the rules and regulations promulgated by the City of Gonzales and shall contain a description of the kind or kinds of game or games of chance authorized to be held, operated and conducted thereunder, a statement of the name and address of the licensee, of the names and addresses of the member or members of the applicant under whom such game or games of chance will be held, operated and conducted; of the number of times or the hours during which such game or games of chance are authorized to be conducted; of the place or places where, the date or dates and time or times when such game or games of chance are to be conducted and for the specific purposes to which the entire net proceeds of such game or games of chance are to be devoted; and any other information which may be required by said rules and regulations to be contained therein. Each license issued for the conduct of any game of chance shall be conspicuously displayed at the place where any game is to be conducted thereunder at all times during the conduct thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-9. - Supervision of licensees by city. 
    The City of Gonzales issuing any license under this chapter shall have and exercise control and supervision of all games of chance held, operated or conducted under such license, to the end that the same are fairly held, operated or conducted under such license, the rules and regulations promulgated by the city and the provisions of this chapter and R.S. 33:4851.1 et seq., governing the holding, operating and conducting of the same. The city shall have the power and authority to suspend any license issued by such governing body and to revoke the same, after hearing, for any violation of any such provision, and shall by its officers and agents have the right of entry at all times into any premise where any such game of chance is being held, operated and conducted or where it is intended that any such games of chance shall be held, operated and conducted, or where any such equipment being used or intended to be used in the conduct thereof is found, for the purpose of inspecting the same. Any organization whose license is suspended hereunder shall have the right to appeal to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86; Ord. No. 2848, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 5.5-10. - License permit fee. 
    Each organization receiving a bingo permit shall pay an annual fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each organization receiving a special event bingo permit shall pay a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-11. - License permit term. 
(a)  No permit for the holding, operating or conducting of any game or games of chance issued under this chapter shall be effective for a period of more than one (1) year from the date of issuance of the permit. 
(b)  Any organization showing a loss for three (3) consecutive months or any five (5) months in a calendar year shall forfeit its license for a period of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-12. - Maximum games allowed. 
(a)  No game or games of chance shall be held, operated or conducted under any license issued under this chapter more often than six (6) sessions per month. In any event, no games of chance shall be held more often than six (6) days per month. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-13. - Door prizes. 
    Door prizes may be given away and not included in total dollar amount of prizes awarded, but door prizes must be listed on the game report by description, value, name of donating entity and the name and address of the winner provided that said prizes awarded at a game of chance shall not be purchased or leased by that organization. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-14. - Prohibitions. 
    No person shall hold, operate or conduct or assist in holding, operating or conducting any game or games of chance under any license issued under this chapter, except an active member of the organization or association to which the license is issued, and no such game of chance shall be conducted with any equipment except such as shall be owned absolutely or used without payment of any compensation therefor by the licensee. No item of expense shall be incurred or paid in connection with the holding, operating or conducting of any game of chance held, operated or conducted pursuant to any license issued under this chapter, except such as are bona fide items of reasonable amount for goods, wares and merchandise furnished or services rendered, which are reasonably necessary to be purchased or furnished for the holding, operating or conducting thereof, under any circumstances whatever. No commission, salary, compensation, reward or recompense whatever shall be paid or given, directly or indirectly to any person holding, operating or conducting or assisting in the holding, operating or conducting, of any game of chance so held, operated or conducted. Any such game or games shall be held, operated or conducted only on or in premises owned and occupied by the licensee hereunder, unless a waiver is granted by the bingo committee upon written request of the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-15. - Reports. 
(a)  On the 20th of the month following the month in which any such game of chance is held, operated or conducted, the organization or association which held, operated or conducted the same and its member or members who were in charge thereof, shall furnish to the city clerk a duly notarized statement showing the amount of the gross receipts from the sale of shares, tickets or rights in any manner connected with participation in said game or the right to participate therein; each item of expense incurred, or paid; and each item of expenditure made or to be made; the name and address of each person to whom each such item has been or is to be paid, with a detailed description of the merchandise purchased or the services rendered therefor; the net profit derived from each such game of chance and the uses to which such net profit has been or is to be applied; and a list of prizes offered or given, with the respective values thereof. It shall be the duty of each licensee to maintain and keep such books and records as may be necessary to substantiate the particulars of each such report. 
(b)  Any organization or association failing to timely file a report as required in the first paragraph of this section shall automatically be assessed one hundred dollars ($100.00) as a late fee. Failure to either subsequently file the required report or pay the one hundred dollars ($100.00) penalty for filing late shall result in the revocation of the license held by the organization or association. Additionally, any organization or association failing to timely file required reports for any three (3) months during a calendar year shall thereby forfeit its license to operate in this city. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-16. - Audits by city. 
(a)  The City of Gonzales shall have power to examine or to cause to be examined the books and records of any organization or association to which such license is issued so far as they may relate to any transactions connected with the holding and conducting of any game of chance thereunder and to examine any manager, officer, director, agent, member or employee thereof under oath, in relation to the conducting of any such game of chance under any such license, but any information so received shall not be disclosed except so far as may be necessary for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Additionally, the city clerk, or his designee shall conduct a full annual audit of each licensee's books and records and inspect each licensee's property leases, so far as they may relate to any transaction connected with the holding and conducting of any game of chance thereunder. 
(c)  The city clerk may bill each licensee for the cost of auditing the licensee's books and records. These charges may be paid by the licensee from the bingo proceeds. Failure to cooperate with the city clerk and/or his designee in conducting the annual audit, or failure to pay the cost of the annual audit as determined by the city clerk, shall result in the revocation of the license of any organization or association. 
(d)  A signed statement consenting to such full annual audits shall be required on a form provided by the city tax collector prior to the granting or renewal of any license. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-17. - Immunity from prosecution. 
    No person, association or corporation: 
(1)  Possessing, selling or in any manner disposing of, in the city, any shares, tickets or rights to participate in any game or games of chance conducted or to be conducted under any license lawfully issued pursuant to this chapter; 
(2)  Lawfully, conducting or participating in the conduct of any such game of chance; or 
(3)  Permitting the conduct of any such game of chance upon premises owned by him or it, or any game of chance conducted or to be conducted under any license lawfully issued pursuant to this chapter; 
shall be liable to prosecution or conviction for violation of any provision of Louisiana Revised Statutes, 14:90. However, this immunity shall not extend to any person or corporation knowingly conducting or participating in the conduct of any game of chance under any license obtained by any false pretense or statement made in any application for such license or otherwise, or possessing, selling or disposing of shares, tickets, or rights to participate in, or permitting the conduct upon any premises owned by him or it of any game of chance conducted upon any premises known to him or it to have been revoked or to have been obtained by any such false or fraudulent pretense or statement. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-18. - Forfeiture of license. 
    Any person who or which shall make any false statement in any application for a license under this chapter, or shall fail to keep such books and records as shall fully and truly record all transactions connected with the holding, operating or conducting of games of chance under any such license, or shall falsify or make any false entry in any books or records so far as they relate to any transaction connected with the holding, operating and conducting of any game of chance under any such license, or shall permit unlicensed bingo on the premises of the licensee, or shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or of any terms of such license, shall be a disorderly person and if convicted as such shall, in addition to suffering any other penalties which may be imposed, forfeit any license under this chapter and shall be ineligible to apply for a license under this chapter for one (1) year thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-19. - Payment of license fees. 
    The licensee shall pay to the city clerk all license fees due hereunder, which license fees shall be paid, in advance, on or before the 1st day of January, 1987, and annually thereafter. Any activities conducted requiring such license by the proposed licensee who has not obtained such license for the current year shall subject the conductor or conductors of such activities to the criminal penalties to which the conductors or unlicensed bingo games, etc., as described in this chapter are subject. In addition to those criminal penalties, if payment for such license is not received by the city clerk by the 1st day of January in the year for which said license would be applicable, then in such event an additional sum of five (5) percent of the total due may be imposed as a penalty for a delinquency not exceeding thirty (30) days, with an additional penalty of five (5) percent of the total amount then due for each additional delinquency of thirty (30) days or fraction thereof, such penalties not to exceed in the aggregate more than twenty-five (25) percent of the total delinquency. In addition, interest in the amount of one-half percent per month may be added on the total amount then due, not to exceed the maximum amount of eight (8) percent of the total amount then due. All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be for the fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) regardless of the period of time remaining in the current calendar year for which the same are issued. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-20. - Authorization to sell supplies. 
    All commercial hall operators intending to sell bingo supplies shall present to the city clerk proof of authorization to sell supplies or equipment as required under Revised Statutes, 33:4861, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86) 
Sec. 5.5-21. - Bingo hall violations. 
    Bingo halls in violation of the rent provisions of this chapter shall lose their authorization to operate. 
(Ord. No. 1820, 9-22-86)

ARTICLE II. - CIVIL DEFENSE[2] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2849, adopted Jan. 30, 2006, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 6-16-6-20, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from §§ 1-5 of an ordinance adopted Apr. 28, 1969. 

Sec. 6-16. - Local organization established. 
    There is hereby established a local organization for civil defense pursuant to the provisions of R.S. 29:737 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2849, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 6-17. - Director. 
    An appointee of the mayor subject to the approval of the city council shall be the director of the local organization for homeland security and emergency preparedness who shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of the local organization for homeland security and emergency preparedness subject to the direction and control of the governor acting through the state homeland security and emergency preparedness agency. The director shall execute and enforce such orders, rules and regulations as may be made by the governor through the state homeland security and emergency preparedness agency. 
(Ord. No. 2849, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 6-18. - Acceptance of gifts, grants or loans. 
    When the federal or state government or any agency or officer thereof shall offer the city services, equipment, materials, supplies or funds by way of gift, grant or loan for purposes of homeland security and emergency preparedness, the director, on behalf of the governor with the consent of the mayor and city council, may accept the offer and is authorized to receive such aid and assistance. 
(Ord. No. 2849, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 6-19. - Detailed plan. 
    The director of homeland security and emergency preparedness is authorized and directed to prepare a detailed plan for civil defense operations in the city and to recruit and train personnel in accordance with the plan to the end that when disaster strikes, each member of the local organization will know his part and duty. 
(Ord. No. 2849, 1-30-06) 
Sec. 6-20. - Use of existing departments, equipment and agencies. 
    The director of homeland security and emergency preparedness is hereby authorized to utilize the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of the city to the maximum practicable and the officers and personnel of all such departments and agencies are directed to cooperate and extend such services and facilities to the director upon request. 
(Ord. No. 2849, 1-30-06)

ARTICLE III. - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Louisiana disaster act, R.S. 29:701 et seq. 

Sec. 6-36. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Civil emergency is hereby defined to be: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force, accompanied by immediate power to execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority of law; 
(2)  Any natural disaster or man-made calamity, including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake, hurricane, or explosion, within the parish or the city, resulting in the potential or actual death or injury of persons, or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew is hereby defined as a prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing, or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, or public property or vacant premises, or otherwise moving about, within the city, excepting persons officially designated to duty with reference to the civil emergency, and physicians, nurses and ambulance operators performing medical services. 
(Ord. of 8-29-69, § 1; Ord. No. 2849, 1-30-06) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-37. - Proclamation. 
    Whenever any civil emergency or the threat of same shall occur in the city, and it is deemed necessary in order to suppress the civil emergency, and to protect the public health, safety and welfare, the mayor, or in the event of his absence or inability to act, the mayor pro tempore of the city, shall forthwith proclaim in writing the existence of such civil emergency. 
(Ord. of 8-29-69, § 2) 
Sec. 6-38. - Curfew. 
    After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the mayor, or in the event of his absence or inability to act, the mayor pro tempore of the city may order a curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the city, or the city as a whole, as he deems advisable, and applicable to such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of the public safety and welfare. 
(Ord. of 8-29-69, § 3) 
Sec. 6-39. - Orders. 
    After the proclamation of any civil emergency, the mayor, or in the event of his absence or inability to act, the mayor pro tempore, may also in the interest of the public safety and welfare make any or all of the following orders: 
(1)  Order the closing of all retail liquor stores; 
(2)  Order the closing of all places licensed to sell liquor and beer under applicable ordinances of the city; 
(3)  Order the closing of all private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor and/or beer is authorized to be sold; 
(4)  Order the discontinuance of the selling, distribution or giving away of gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle; 
(5)  Order the discontinuance of the sale of beer and liquor; 
(6)  Order the closing of gasoline stations and other establishments, the chief activity of which is the sale, distribution, or dispensing of liquid flammable or combustible products; 
(7)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms, or ammunition of any character whatsoever; 
(8)  Order the closing of any or all establishments or portions thereof, the chief activity of which is the sale, distribution, dispensing or giving away of firearms or ammunition; 
(9)  Issue such orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property; 
(10)  Designate any public street, thoroughfare or vehicle parking areas closed to motor vehicles and pedestrian traffic; 
(11)  Call upon regular and auxiliary law enforcement agencies and organizations within or without the city to assist in preserving and keeping the peace within the city. 
(Ord. of 8-29-69, § 4) 
Sec. 6-40. - When proclamation effective. 
    The proclamation of a civil emergency, provided for in section 6-37, shall be effective upon its issuance and dissemination to the public by appropriate news media. 
(Ord. of 8-29-69, § 5) 
Sec. 6-41. - Violations. 
    Any person who fails or refuses to comply with the orders of duly authorized law enforcement officers, or personnel charged with the responsibility of enforcing the proclamation of a civil emergency, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 8-29-69, § 6) 
Chapter 7 - CIVIL RIGHTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 7-1-7-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING 

Sec. 7-16. - Policy. 
    It is the policy of the city to provide, within constitutional limitations, for fair housing throughout the city. 
(Ord. of 9-8-80, § 24-1) 
Sec. 7-17. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Discriminatory housing practice means an act that is unlawful under sections 7-19, 7-20 or 7-21. 
    Dwelling means any building, structure, or portion thereof which is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residence by one or more families, and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon of any such building, structure, or portion thereof. 
    Family includes a single individual. 
    To rent includes to lease, to sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
(Ord. of 9-8-80, § 24-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-18. - Application of prohibitions. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of section 7-22, the prohibitions against discrimination in the sale or rental of housing set forth in section 7-19 shall apply to all dwellings except those exempted by subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Nothing in section 7-19 (other than subsection (3)) shall apply to: 
(1)  Any single-family house sold or rented by an owner; provided, that such private individual owner does not own more than three (3) such single-family houses at one time; provided further, that in the case of the sale of any such single-family house by a private individual owner not residing in such house at the time of such sale or who was not the most recent resident of such house prior to such sale, the exemption granted by the subsection shall apply only with respect to one such sale within any twenty-four (24) month period; provided further, that such bona fide private individual owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved on his behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right to all or a portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of more than three (3) such single-family houses at any one time; provided further, that the sale or rental of such single-family house shall be excepted from the application of this article only if such house is sold or rented (i) without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services or any real estate broker, agent, or salesman, or of such facilities or services of any person in the business to selling or renting dwellings, or of any employee or agent of any such broker, agent, salesman, or person and (ii) without the publication, posting or mailing, after notice of any advertisement or written notice in violation of section 7-19(3); but nothing in this provision shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstracters, title companies, and other such professional assistance necessary to perfect or transfer the title; or 
(2)  Rooms or units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four (4) families living independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of such living quarters as his residence. 
(c)  For the purpose of subsection (b), a person shall be deemed to be in the business of selling or renting dwellings if: 
(1)  He has, within the preceding twelve (12) months, participated as principal in three (3) or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any dwelling or any interest therein; or 
(2)  He has, within the preceding twelve (12) months, participated as agent, other than in the sale of his own personal residence in providing sales or rental facilities or sales or rental services in two (2) or more transactions involving the sale or rental of any dwelling or any interest therein; or 
(3)  He is the owner of any dwelling designed or intended for occupancy by, or occupied by, five (5) or more families. 
(Ord. of 9-8-80, § 24-3) 
Sec. 7-19. - Discrimination in the sale or rental of housing. 
    As made applicable by section 7-18 and except as exempted by sections 7-18(b) and 7-22, it shall be unlawful: 
(1)  To refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion or national origin; 
(2)  To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, religion or national origin; 
(3)  To make, print or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published any notice, statement or advertisement, with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, religion or national origin; 
(4)  To represent to any person because of race, color, religion or national origin that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available; 
(5)  For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry to prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a particular race, color, religion or national origin. 
(Ord. of 9-8-80, § 24-4) 
Sec. 7-20. - Discrimination in the financing of housing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm, or enterprise whose business consists in whole or in part in the making of commercial real estate loans, to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing, or maintaining a dwelling, or to discriminate against him in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration, or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance, because of race, color, religion, or national origin of such person or any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owner, leases, tenants or occupants of the dwelling or dwellings in relation to which such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given; provided, that nothing contained in this section shall impair the scope or effectiveness of the exception contained in section 7-18(b). 
(Ord. of 9-8-80, § 24-5) 
Sec. 7-21. - Discrimination in the provision of brokerage services.
