For the purposes of this requirement, manufactured homes must be elevated and anchored to resist flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This requirement is in addition to applicable state and local anchoring requirements for resisting wind forces. 
b.  Require that manufactured homes that are placed or substantially improved within Zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM on sites: (i) outside of a manufactured home park or subdivision; (ii) in a new manufactured home park or subdivision; (iii) in an expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision; or (iv) in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision on which a manufactured home has incurred substantial damage as a result of a flood, be elevated on a permanent foundation such that the lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated to one (1) foot or more above the base flood elevation and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
c.  Require that manufactured homes be placed or substantially improved on sites in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision with Zones A1-30, AH and AE on the community's FIRM that are not subject to the provisions of paragraph (4) of this section be elevated so that either: (i) The lowest floor of the manufactured home is at one (1) foot or more above the base flood elevation; or (ii) the manufactured home chassis is supported by reinforced piers or other foundation elements of at least equivalent strength that are no less than thirty-six (36) inches in height above grade and be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse, and lateral movement. 
(4)  Enclosures. New construction and substantial improvements, with fully enclosed areas below the lowest floor that are usable solely for parking of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement and which are subject to flooding shall be designed to automatically equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the entry and exit of floodwaters. Designs for meeting this requirement must either be certified by a registered professional engineer or architect or meet or exceed the following minimum criteria: 
a.  A minimum of two (2) openings having a total net area of not less than one (1) square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding shall be provided. 
b.  The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one (1) foot above grade. 
c.  Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves, or other coverings or devices provided that they permit the automatic entry and exit of floodwaters. 
(5)  Recreational vehicles. Require that recreational vehicles placed on sites within Zones A1-30, AH, and AE on the community's FIRM either: (i) Be on the site for fewer than one hundred eighty (180) days; (ii) be fully licensed and ready for highway use; or (iii) meet the permit requirements of section 10-33(a), and the elevation and anchoring requirements for manufactured homes in paragraph (4) of this section. A recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is on its wheels or jacking system, is attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached additions. 
(Ord. of 7-21-82, § 22-8(2); Ord. No. 1908, 12-22-87; Ord. No. 2206, 8-10-92; Ord. No. 4051 , 3-19-18) 
Sec. 10-53. - Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO zones). 
    Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 10-7 are areas designated as shallow flooding. These areas have special flood hazards associated with base flood depths of one (1) to three (3) feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist and where the path of flooding is unpredictable and where velocity may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow; therefore, the following provisions apply: 
(1)  All new construction and substantial improvement of residential structures have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated above the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two (2) feet if no depth number is specified). 
a.  All new construction and substantial improvements of nonresidential structures shall: Have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated above the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least two (2) feet if no depth number is specified), or; 
b.  Together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities be designed so that below the base flood level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads of effects of buoyancy. 
(3)  A registered professional engineer or architect shall submit a certification to the local flood administrator that the standards of this section, as proposed in section 10-33(b)(1), are satisfied. 
(4)  Require within Zones AH or AO adequate drainage paths around structures on slopes, to guide floodwaters around and away from proposed structures. 
(Ord. of 7-21-87, § 22-8(3); Ord. No. 1908, 12-22-87; Ord. No. 2206, 8-10-92) 
Sec. 10-54. - Standards for subdivision proposals. 
(a)  All subdivision proposals, including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions, shall be consistent with sections 10-2, 10-3 and 10-5. 
(b)  All proposals for the development of subdivisions including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall meet development permit requirements of section 10-33, and the provisions of article III of this chapter. 
(c)  Base flood elevation data shall be generated for subdivision proposals and other proposed development including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions which is greater than fifty (50) lots or five (5) acres, whichever is lesser, if not otherwise provided pursuant to sections 20-7 or 10-32(7). 
(d)  All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(e)  All subdivision proposals, including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions, shall have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to minimize or eliminate flood damage. 
(Ord. No. 7-21-82, § 22-84; Ord. No. 1908, 12-22-87; Ord. No. 2206, 8-10-92) 
Chapter 11 - GARBAGE, TRASH, WEEDS AND WASTES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Trash fires, § 8-188; health and sanitation, Ch. 12; utilities, Ch. 20. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Posting of advertising matter prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, tack, nail or otherwise fasten any paper or any advertising matter whatsoever upon any sidewalk, street, gutter edge, rack, telegraph or telephone or electric pole, or upon the posts or columns or any part of any building facing any street within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed so as to prevent any person from posting any advertising matter upon any authorized billboard. 
(Ord. of 2-9-81) 
Sec. 11-2. - Refuse from vehicle service establishments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place or leave upon, or in any ditch, sidewalk, or street in the city any dirt, grease, oil or other refuse obtained from cleaning, washing, greasing, and lubricating automobiles and other vehicles. 
(Code 1965, § 15-9) 
Sec. 11-3. - Littering prohibited; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall throw, drop, deposit, discard, or otherwise dispose of litter upon any public place in the city, upon private property in this city not owned by him, upon property located in rural areas in this city not owned by him or in or on the waters of this city, whether from a vehicle or campground, forest land, recreational area, trailer park, highway, road, street or alley, except: 
(1)  When such property is designated by the state or by any of its agencies or political subdivisions for the disposal of garbage and refuse and such person is authorized to use such property for such purpose. 
(2)  When litter is placed into a litter receptacle in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried away or deposited by the elements upon any parts of such private or public property or waters. 
(b)  Any person who picks, cuts, digs up, or otherwise removes in any manner whatsoever any wildflowers from any wildflower designated area from along an interstate highway or a road in this city shall be considered to have littered and shall be subject to the penalties of this section. 
(c)  If the throwing, dumping, or depositing of litter was done from a motor vehicle, except a bus or large passenger vehicle or a school bus, it shall be prima facie evidence that the throwing, dumping or depositing was done by the driver of the motor vehicle. 
(d)  The offender may be cited for the offense by means of a ticket, summons, or other means provided by law. 
(e)  Penalties for violations. 
(1)  Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall, upon first conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(2)  Upon second conviction, an offender shall be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) and have his motor vehicle driver's license suspended for thirty (30) days. 
(3)  Upon third or subsequent conviction, an offender shall be fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00), have his motor vehicle driver's license suspended for one (1) year, or be imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or all of the aforementioned penalties or any combination of the aforementioned penalties. 
(4)  The judge in his discretion may require an individual convicted of a violation of this section to remove litter from state highways, public playgrounds, public parks, or other appropriate locations for any prescribed period of time in lieu of or in addition to the penalties prescribed in this section. 
(5)  In addition, any person who throws or deposits litter from a water vessel shall be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or be imprisoned for not more than six (6) months or both. 
(f)  A person may be found guilty and fined under this section although the commission of the offense did not occur in the presence of a law enforcement officer if the preponderance of the evidence presented to the court indicates that the defendant has committed the offense. 
(Ord. No. 2038, 7-23-90) 
Sec. 11-4. - Cost allocation. 
    The city, upon receiving the fines imposed by section 11-3, shall reimburse those justice of the peace courts and ward constable offices who handle litter violations for the time spent and expense incurred by the respective justice of the peace and constable, deputy constable, or special deputy constable. In no case shall the expenses reimbursed be greater than fifty (50) percent of the fine collected for a violation of section 11-3. 
(Ord. No. 2038, 7-23-90) 
Secs. 11-5-11-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARBAGE AND TRASH 
DIVISION I. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-16 - Garbage containers-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit the accumulation upon his premises of any garbage except in covered containers approved by the parish health officer. 
(Code 1965, § 8-1) 
Sec. 11-17. - Same-Specifications. 
    Garbage containers shall have a capacity of greater than twenty (20) gallons but less than thirty-five (35) gallons, be constructed of plastic, metal or fiberglass, having handles of adequate strength for lifting, and having a tight-fitting lid capable of preventing entrance into the container by vectors. The mouth of a container shall have a diameter greater than or equal to that of the base. The weight of a container and its contents shall not exceed sixty (60) pounds. 
(Code 1965, § 8-2; Ord. No. 1728, 7-22-85) 
Sec. 11-18. - Same-Minimum one-yard containers required in certain cases. 
    All commercial establishments, institutions and schools which need more than the equivalent of three (3), thirty-gallon containers for disposal of garbage, may have garbage collected and disposed of by a licensed contractor only if it is placed in readily assessable containers of one-yard capacity or greater, equipped with self-closing lids, and designed to be dumped mechanically. 
(Code 1965, § 8-2.1; Ord. of 6-26-67; Ord. No. 1918, 8-8-88; Ord. No. 2624, 2-14-2000) 
Sec. 11-18.1. - Cardboard boxes and containers. 
    All commercial cardboard boxes and containers must be broken down and placed in regulation bins provided for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1730, 7-22-85) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1729 and 1730, adopted July 22, 1985, added provisions designated as §§ 11-18-A and 11-18-B, relative to preparation of cardboard boxes and shrub etc. trimmings for pick-up. Such provisions have been redesignated herein as 11-18.1 and 11-18.2 in order to conform to the numbering system of the Code. 
Sec. 11-18.2. - Tree, brush, and shrub trimmings. 
    All tree, shrub and brush trimmings (or newspapers and magazines) shall be securely tied into a bundle to form an easily handled package not more than six (6) feet in length and not weighing more than seventy (70) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 1729, 7-22-85) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 11-18.1. 
Sec. 11-19. - Garbage collection schedule; holiday schedule. 
    Upon the observance of a legal holiday by city employees, there shall be no garbage collection services. The route regularly scheduled for pickup on the holiday will not be picked up until the next regularly scheduled pickup day for that affected route. 
(Ord. of 9-27-82) 
Sec. 11-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2611, adopted July 12, 1999, deleted § 11-20, burning prohibited, which had derived from § 8-4 of the 1965 Code. 
Sec. 11-21. - Sweepings to be kept out of drains. 
    The owner or occupant of any premises, or his servant, agent or employee shall take up or cause to be taken up all sweepings from the sidewalks or banquettes abutting the premises owned or occupied by him, so that such sweepings shall not under any circumstances reach the drains, gutters or roadway of the streets of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 8-5) 
Sec. 11-22. - Debris from fire or demolition. 
    In the event of destruction or demolition, in whole or in part, of any building or other work by fire or other cause, the owner of the building or his agent shall within six (6) days after such event remove or cause to be removed all debris resulting therefrom, lying in or upon the roadways, sidewalks, banquettes or gutters of the streets of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 8-6) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 11-23. - Dumping of garbage in container of another prohibited. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall intentionally dump, leave or deposit any glass or metallic objects, trash, refuse, or garbage in the garbage containers of another. Any violation of this provision shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days or both such fine and imprisonment within the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 1917, 5-23-88) 
Sec. 11-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3010, adopted April 22, 2013, repealed former § 11-24 in its entirety which pertained to a garbage collection fee subsidy for residential households and derived from Ord. No. 2130, adopted Oct. 28, 1991. 
Sec. 11-25. - Disturbing or taking refuse prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take, handle, or otherwise disturb garbage, trash, or recyclable material, or garbage, trash, or recyclable containers or to remove the contents of garbage, trash, or recyclable containers which have been positioned for pickup by collectors whether on public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 2410, 1-28-97) 
Sec. 11-26. - Solid waste collection times limited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, or contractor to engage in the pick-up or collection of solid waste, residential or commercial, within the City of Gonzales, at any time outside the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2718, 1-28-02) 
Secs. 11-27-11-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - UNLAWFUL DEPOSITS 

Sec. 11-36. - Depositing in city prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall throw, cast, drop or deposit, or permit his servant, agent or employee to throw, cast, drop or deposit any ashes, offal, vegetables, fruit, fruit peelings, garbage, oil and petroleum products, cinders, straw, shavings, paper, glass, crockery, dirt, soiled water, filth, sweepings, including sweepings of any description whatsoever, rubbish or debris of any kind whatsoever into or upon the roadways, banquettes or sidewalks of any street or alley of the city or into or upon any ditch, culvert, drainage facility of any type of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit the accumulation upon his premises of any ashes, offal, vegetables, fruit, fruit peelings, garbage, oil and petroleum products, cinders, straw, shavings, paper, glass, crockery, dirt, soiled water, filth, sweepings, including sweepings of any description whatsoever, rubbish, limbs, tree trunks, bricks, concrete (blocks or slabs), junked auto parts or debris of any kind whatsoever. 
(Code 1965, § 8-3; Ord. of 2-9-81; Ord. No. 1630, 8-27-84) 
Sec. 11-37. - Notice to property owners. 
(a)  If any owner of real estate within the corporation limits of the city fails to comply with the provisions of section 11-36, the clerk is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to notify the property owner, address as shown on the tax rolls of the city, to comply with this section 11-36 within ten (10) days from the date of the letter. 
(b)  If any owner of real estate within the corporation limits of the city fails to receive the notice referred in subsection (a) or fails to comply with the notice given, the clerk is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to further notify the property owner by advertising in two (2) issues of the official journal of the city, a notice to the property owner to comply with section 11-36 within ten (10) days from the date of the notice. 
(Code 1965, § 8-12; Ord. of 5-12-69; Ord. of 109-78; Ord. of 2-9-81) 
Sec. 11-38. - Failure of property owner to comply; removal by city. 
    If, after ten (10) days have elapsed since the last notice as provided in section 11-37, any property owner has still failed to comply with the provisions of section 11-36, the clerk is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to cause the premises to be cleansed by causing removal of any ashes, offal, vegetables, fruit, fruit peelings, garbage, cinders, straw, shavings, paper, glass, crockery, dirt, soiled water, filth, sweepings, including sweepings of any description whatsoever, rubbish, or debris of any kind whatsoever. 
(Code 1965, § 8-13, Ord. of 2-9-81) 
Sec. 11-39. - Cost assessed against property owner. 
    Within ten (10) days after the removal as provided in sections 11-37 and/or 11-38, the clerk shall furnish the owner as shown on the last assessment roll, by certified mail, a written statement showing the cost or expense incurred for the work, and the place or property on which the work was done. If the owner is found to have violated this section more than two times within a six-month period, the city will additionally assess the owner a fine of two hundred fifty ($250.00) upon the third offense and five hundred ($500.00) on every subsequent offense thereafter. These charges include, but are not limited to, any actual costs incurred by the City of Gonzales, fines levied against the owner, any administrative fees incurred, any third party contractor fees, and also expressly includes interest on all sums due from incurrence until payment. In the event the city elects to hold a public hearing before the city council and the nuisance is not remedied as proscribed in the hearing, each day shall constitute an additional offense. Notice of the public hearing shall be provided by certified mail and publication in the newspaper of record at least fifteen days prior to the hearing. If the statement is not paid within one (1) month thereafter, the amount thereof shall be included in and form a part of the taxes due by the property and the owner, and when collected shall be credited to the general fund of the city. The city is authorized to may recover costs of demolition, removal, maintenance, interest or attorney fees as provided in R.S. 33:4766. 
(Code 1965, § 8-14; Ord. of 2-9-81; Ord. No. 4074 , 10-8-18) 
Sec. 11-40. - Records to be maintained, constitutes legal notice. 
    The tax collector shall maintain a record of charges under this division prior to the filing of the tax rolls, which record shall be open to inspection at all times and which shall constitute legal notice to the purchaser of the property or parties lending money thereon of the assessment. 
(Ord. of 2-9-81) 
Secs. 11-41-11-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WEEDS AND GRASS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Weed cutting in municipalities, R.S. 33:5062 et seq. 

Sec. 11-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Lot shall include the sidewalks adjoining such lot or part of such lot. 
    Weeds shall include all rank vegetable growth which exhales unpleasant or obnoxious odors and also high and rank vegetable growth which may be unsightly or may conceal filthy deposits, or may serve as breeding places for reptiles or insects. 
(Code 1965, § 8-7) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-57. - Disposable containers required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee, occupant, or any agent, servant or employee, of any such owner, lessee, or occupant having control of any lot of ground or of any part of any lot of ground to deposit or otherwise accumulate weeds, grass, and leaves for collection by the city in other than disposable containers with lids sufficient to prevent the scattering of such weeds, grass and leaves. 
(Code 1965, § 8-7.1; Ord. of 10-14-68) 
Sec. 11-58. - Maximum height allowed. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee, occupant, or any agent, servant, or employee of any such owner, lessee, or occupant having control of any lot or ground or of any part of any lot of ground to allow or maintain on any lot or part of any lot any growth of weeds or grass to the height of over twelve (12) inches. 
(b)  In the instance whereupon any lot or ground or any part of any lot of ground there exists a residence, structure or building, or in the case of any vacant lot within a residential area, the maximum height of weeds or grass on such lots shall not exceed six (6) inches. 
(Code 1965, § 8-8; Ord. No. 2127, 8-26-91; Ord. No. 2129, 10-14-91; Ord. No. 2645, 7-24-00; Ord. No. 2876, 10-23-06) 
Sec. 11-58.1. - Hay baling. 
    The planting and harvesting of hay shall be limited to areas of a minimum of two (2) acres, which shall be contiguous. The planting, cultivating and harvesting of hay shall be no closer than fifty (50) feet from a residential, commercial or industrial building or structure, other than said structures which are owned or leased by the person or entity planting and harvesting the hay in said area, unless the person or entity planting and harvesting the hay has the written permission of the owners of said structure to do so. Documentation evidencing such permission shall be filed with the city clerk. The hay crop shall be cut at such time as it reaches thirty-six (36) inches in height, and shall be cut a minimum of once per year. 
( Ord. No. 3095 , 6-13-16) 
Sec. 11-59. - Sidewalks to be kept free thereof. 
    It shall be the duty and it is made mandatory of all persons owning property within the corporate limits of the city to keep all sidewalks abutting their respective property free of weeds and grass. 
(Code 1965, § 8-9) 
Sec. 11-60. - Notice to property owners. 
(a)  If any owner of real estate within the corporate limits of the city fails to comply with the provisions of sections 11-57, 11-58(a) and 11-59, the clerk is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to notify the property owners by advertising in two (2) issues of the official journal of the city a notice to all property owners to comply with sections 11-57, 11-58(a) and 11-59 within ten (10) days from the date of the notice. 
(b)  If any owner of real estate within the corporate limits of the city fails to comply with the provisions of sections 11-58(b), the clerk is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to notify the property owners by letter to comply with section 11-58(b) within ten (10) days from the date of the notice. 
(Code 1965, § 8-10; Ord. of 5-12-69; Ord. No. 2876, 10-23-06) 
Sec. 11-61. - Failure of property owner to comply, removal by city. 
    If after ten (10) days have elapsed since the last notice as provided in section 11-60 any property owner has still failed to comply with the provisions of sections 11-57, 11-58 and 11-59, the clerk is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to cause the premises to be cleansed by causing the cutting and/or removal or destruction of all noxious weeds or grass or other deleterious, unhealthy or noxious growth or accumulations from the property or abutting sidewalks. 
(Code 1965, § 8-11) 
Sec. 11-62. - Cost assessed against owner, time of payment, procedure when owner fails to pay. 
    After the cutting or removal as provided in section 11-61, the clerk shall furnish the owner as shown on the last assessment roll, by certified mail, a written statement showing the cost or expense incurred for the work, and the place or property on which the work was done, and any applicable fines and interest as set forth hereafter. If the owner is found to have violated this section more than two (2) times within a six-month period, the city will additionally assess the owner a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) upon the third offense and five hundred dollars ($500.00) on every subsequent offense thereafter. The city is further authorized to charge the owner interest on all sums due from incurrence until payment at a rate that does not exceed the legal interest rate provided in R.S. 9:3500. If the statement is not paid within one month thereafter, the amount thereof shall be included in and form a part of the taxes due by the property and the owner, and when collected shall be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 8-12; Ord. of 5-12-69; Ord. of 10-9-78; Ord. No. 4074 , 10-8-18) 
Sec. 11-63. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2876, adopted Oct. 23, 2006, deleted § 11-63, which pertained to grass-cutting fees and derived from an ordinance adopted Apr. 11, 1977 and an ordinance adopted Oct. 12, 1981. 
Secs. 11-64-11-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HAZARDOUS WASTES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Hazardous waste control law, R.S. 30:2171 et seq. 

Sec. 11-81. - Definition. 
    "Hazardous waste," when used in this article, includes, but is not limited to such items as petroleum waste; paints; plastics; explosives; acids; caustics; chemicals; poisons; drugs; radioactive materials; asbestos fibers; pathogenic wastes from hospitals, sanatoriums, nursing homes, clinics, and veterinary hospitals, offal waste, and the like, which by virtue of their particular composition and inherent dangers, require handling and disposal methods different from those used in other waste materials. In the way of further explanation, "hazardous waste" is solid waste, be infectious, explosive, poisonous, caustic, or toxic, or otherwise dangerous or injurious to humans, plant or animal life. Residential solid waste normally contains some hazardous materials, but because such materials are usually present in very small quantities, their safe disposal either in a sanitary landfill or incinerator presents no special problem. Therefore, residential waste is not considered to be "hazardous waste," as used in this text. 
(Ord. of 9-25-78) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-82. - Unlawful dumping. 
    No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit any "hazardous waste", or any other land contaminants to be dumped, discharged, stored, injected, or otherwise disposed of, within the boundaries of the city, or any land within the confines of the city. 
(Ord. of 9-25-78)

(Code 1965, § 9-1)

(Code 1965, § 9-2)

(Code 1965, § 9-3)

Secs. 13-1-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLAYGROUND AND RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; boards and commissions generally, § 2-121 et seq. 

Sec. 13-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a board to be known as the playground and recreation board for the city, whose authority shall extend within the corporate limits of the city, as those limits are now or may hereafter be fixed and determined. 
(Code 1965, § 2-18) 
Sec. 13-17. - Composition. 
    The playground and recreation board shall be composed of five (5) members, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1965, § 2-18) 
Sec. 13-18. - Terms. 
    The term of members of the playground and recreation board shall be for a period as follows: 
(1)  One (1) member shall be appointed for one (1) year; 
(2)  One (1) member shall be appointed for two (2) years; 
(3)  One (1) member shall be appointed for three (3) years; 
(4)  One (1) member shall be appointed for four (4) years; 
(5)  One (1) member shall be appointed for five (5) years. 
(Code 1965, § 2-18) 
Sec. 13-19. - Compensation. 
    All members of the playground and recreation board shall serve without pay. 
(Code 1965, § 2-19) 
Sec. 13-20. - Removal of members. 
    Any appointed member of the playground and recreation board may be removed at any time, for cause, by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1965, § 2-23) 
Sec. 13-21. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the playground and recreation board occurring otherwise than by expiration of term shall be filled by appointment by the mayor with the consent of the board of aldermen for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1965, § 2-19) 
Sec. 13-22. - Organization; quorum. 
    Immediately after the appointment of the playground and recreation board they shall meet and organize by electing from their members a chairman, a vice chairman and a secretary-treasurer whose term of office shall run for one (1) year, and who shall be eligible for reelection. Three (3) members shall constitute a quorum of the board for all purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 2-20) 
Sec. 13-23. - Powers and duties. 
    The playground and recreation board shall have full power and authority to maintain and equip playgrounds and recreation centers, and to employ recreation officers and employees, and to otherwise supervise recreation, maintain and conduct playgrounds, recreation centers and other recreation facilities and activities. 
(Code 1965, § 2-21) 
Sec. 13-24. - Donations acceptable, disposition of donations, city appropriated funds. 
    The playground and recreation board shall accept any donation of movable or immovable property for either temporary or permanent use for playgrounds or other recreation purposes and any money received for such purposes unless otherwise provided by the terms of the donation, shall be deposited with the treasurer of the board for the account of the playground and recreation board, and the same may be withdrawn and paid out by the board in the same manner as money appropriated for recreation purposes by the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1965, § 2-22) 
Secs. 13-25-13-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GONZALES CIVIC CENTER 

Sec. 13-36. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Gonzales Civic Center means that municipal building located at 219 South Irma Boulevard, Gonzales, Louisiana, 70737. (Rental bookings: 225-647-2841.) 
    Lessee means any person/organization who leases any portion of the recreation center, and is in compliance with section 13-43. 
(Code 1965, § 21-1; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-1; Ord. No. 1744, 1-13-86; Ord. No. 2415, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-37. - Rates, charges and fees. 
(a)  The following rates, charges and fees shall apply to the Gonzales Civic Center: 
(1)  Lessee ..... $1,200.00. 
(2)  Any church or school ..... 800.00. 
(3)  There shall be no charge for use of the building for any recreational or similar purpose sponsored by the city or any agent thereof. 
(4)  Any publicly announced candidate for any political office may lease the building upon a charge of eight hundred dollars ($800.00). 
(5)  Any nonprofit organization with national, state, or regional affiliation and the Ascension Community Theatre may lease the building upon a charge of eight hundred dollars ($800.00). 
(6)  Any governmental agency or the chamber of commerce shall lease the building for a fee of eight hundred dollars ($800.00). 
(7)  A pre/post event rental fee of fifty (50) percent of the standard rental fee shall be charged for use of the building on any evening prior to or the morning after a scheduled event. Regular rent rates apply for Friday, and Saturday events. 
(8)  A security deposit of six hundred dollars ($600.00) is required at the time of booking and is refundable fourteen (14) days after the event provided the building is returned in the same condition as when received. If the lessee does not notify the lessor of a cancellation with a period of ninety (90) days of the scheduled event, said deposit will be forfeited unless cancellation is caused by an act of God or other natural disaster. 
(b)  The above charges include tables and chairs, microphones, utilities and standard clean-up after the event. Excessive cleaning necessitated by the building being returned with excessive trash, debris, and/or otherwise in an unsanitary condition will result in additional charges, with a minimum excess cleaning fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(c)  Access keys can be picked up seven (7) days prior to the event and will be activated at the time the rental period begins. Access keys must be returned to city hall by 5:00 p.m. on the first working day after the event. Failure to return the access keys on time may result in a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per key, or the amount will be deducted from the deposit refund. 
(d)  Lessee is responsible for setting up the tables and chairs prior to the event and returning them to their proper storage location in the same condition as received. If microphones are used, they must be returned to their proper storage location as well. Failure to return tables and chairs to the storage area will result in additional charges, with a minimum fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Code 1965, § 21-2; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-2; Ord. No. 1744, 1-13-86; Ord. No. 1745, 1-13-86; Ord. No. 1814, 6-23-86; Ord. No. 1825, 1-26-87; Ord. No. 2028, 2-26-90; Ord. No. 2042, 8-27-90; Ord. No. 2209, 12-14-92; Ord. No. 2312, 8-2-94; Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06; Ord. No. 3077, 6-22-15; Ord. No. 3094 , 5-9-16; Ord. No. 4054 , 4-23-18; Ord. No. 4076 , 10-22-18) 
Sec. 13-38. - Listing functions or events. 
(a)  The mayor or the manager of the Gonzales Civic Center shall maintain a book wherein there shall be listed, in advance, all events or functions to be held in the building. 
(b)  All events or functions to be held in the building shall be scheduled and said scheduling may be done up to eighteen (18) months in advance during normal working hours. The city shall have pre-emptive rights to schedule city sponsored functions. No other bookings shall be scheduled under this section prior to the noted date. 
(Code 1965, § 21-3; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-3; Ord. No. 1817, 8-13-86; Ord. No. 1919, 8-8-88; Ord. No. 2115, 4-8-91; Ord. No. 2415, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06) 
Sec. 13-39. - Collection of fee or charge. 
    All charges shall be paid no later than fourteen (14) days in advance. Failure to pay fees on time may result in event cancellation and forfeiture of deposit. 
(Code 1965, § 21-4; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-4; Ord. No. 2415, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06; Ord. No. 4054 , 4-23-18) 
Sec. 13-40. - Changes, alterations or attachments to building. 
    Any change, alteration or attachment to the building or any portion thereof shall be made only after the same has been approved, in writing, by the mayor or building manager. 
(Code 1965, § 21-5; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-5; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06) 
Sec. 13-41. - Use for charges not specified. 
    For any use of the Gonzales Civic Center, or any portion thereof, not herein specified, the charge or charges therefor shall be fixed by agreement with the manager of the building, subject to the approval of the mayor. Use for charges less than the amounts specified herein can be made only upon prior approval by the mayor. 
(Code 1965, § 21-6; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-6; Ord. No. 2415, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06; Ord. No. 4054 , 4-23-18) 
Sec. 13-42. - Use of funds. 
    The funds derived from charges, fees, and all other funds collected for the building shall be used exclusively for paying the operating expenses of the building. Any excess funds may be disbursed only with prior approval of the mayor. 
(Code 1965, § 21-7; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-7; Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06; Ord. No. 4054 , 4-23-18) 
Sec. 13-43. - Rules and regulations. 
    The lessee by payment of the fee or charge as per section 13-37 and/or by listing an event or function as per section 13-38 and/or by any actual use of the Gonzales Civic Center does hereby: 
(1)  Admit and agree that the premises are in a tenantable condition and agrees that at the end of use of the Gonzales Civic Center he will deliver up and surrender the premises, including the building and all parking lots, in as good condition as when received; 
(2)  Designate the end of use to be deemed to be no later than 1:00 a.m., which is strictly enforced; 
(3)  Acknowledge that the provisions of section 13-40 prohibit the decoration of the Gonzales Civic Center by any attachments to the walls, light fixtures, ceilings, windows, or any other portion of the building whatsoever; that all decorations must be self-supporting movable objects; and that all such self-supporting movable objects must be prepared at a location other than the Gonzales Civic Center; and that all violations of this policy may result in forfeiture of deposit and/or additional fees assessed; 
(4)  Agree to indemnify the city and hold the city harmless from all damages caused by the lessee's acts or neglect, or those of lessee's invitees or licensees, or other persons for whom lessee is responsible; lessee shall forthwith repair such damage at his own expense, and should he/she fail or refuse to make the necessary and adequate repairs therefore within a reasonable time after the occurrence of the damage, the lessor may, at his option, make the necessary and adequate repairs and charge the cost thereof to the lessee, and the lessee shall thereupon reimburse the lessor for the total cost of such repairs; 
(5)  Agree that if an attorney is employed to enforce or protect any claim of lessor arising from this lease, lessee shall pay, as the fee of that attorney, an additional sum amounting to twenty-five (25) percent of the amount of the claim, or, if the claim is not for money, then such sums as will constitute a reasonable fee, together with all costs, charges and expenses; 
(6)  Acknowledge that these provisions bind lessee and his respective heirs, successors and assigns. All of the terms apply to any persons claiming by or through either party, including, but not limited to, receivers, trustees in bankruptcy and all other persons whomsoever; 
(7)  Acknowledge that use of the Gonzales Civic Center for any function open to the public where admission is charged at the door is prohibited; 
(8)  Agree that smoking is prohibited in the Gonzales Civic Center; 
(9)  Agree that use of the Gonzales Civic Center is limited to individuals residing in Ascension Parish east of the Mississippi River and that proof of residency of lessee must be provided prior to booking with the following documents allowed as proof: valid driver's license, passport, other state issued ID, or utility bill; 
(10)  Agree to hire the appropriate security personnel as required by the Gonzales Chief of Police and the building manager; 
(11)  Agree that if alcohol is served or consumed on the premises, an alcohol permit will be provided to the City of Gonzales no later than fourteen (14) days prior to the event and law enforcement must be hired by the lessee and approved by the Gonzales Chief of Police; 
(12)  Agree that individuals renting the building will provide proper identification and non-profits and other legal entities will provide proof of good standing with the Louisiana Secretary of State's Office and a copy of a corporate resolution authorizing the signatory of the lease to sign the lease agreement; 
(13)  Agree to provide the City of Gonzales with a copy of a liability insurance certificate providing liability coverage for the planned event in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) naming the City of Gonzales as an additional insured; 
(14)  Acknowledge that fog machines are prohibited, because the sensitivity of the smoke alarm system could cause dispatching Police and Fire resources, with violations resulting in forfeiture of deposit and/or additional fees being assessed; 
(15)  Acknowledge that concerts are generally prohibited and exceptions are allowed through the application and approval of a special use permit approved by the city council; 
(16)  Acknowledge that high school graduation, ring night, and other teenage parties are generally discouraged; and 
(17)  Agree that if minors are present, the individual or entity renting the building is responsible for providing appropriate adult supervision. Further, under no circumstances shall alcohol be consumed by anyone on the premises who is not of legal age. 
(Code 1965, § 21-8; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-8; Ord. No. 2412, 1-28-97; Ord. No. 2415, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2807, 11-22-04; Ord. No. 2827, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06; Ord. No. 4054 , 4-23-18) 
Sec. 13-44. - Further use prohibited. 
    The further use of the Gonzales Civic Center shall be denied to any person who knowingly permits or allows any damage to be done to the building or the grounds thereof, or wherein the conduct of any of those in attendance shall be contrary to good morals and decency. 
(Code 1965, § 21-9; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-9; Ord. No. 2415, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06) 
Sec. 13-45. - Operation and management. 
    The operation and management of the Gonzales Civic Center shall be under the direct supervision and charge of the mayor or manager; and the manager shall be responsible to the mayor and councilmen. 
(Code 1965, § 21-10; Ord. of 2-8-82, § 21-10; Ord. No. 2415, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06) 
Sec. 13-46. - Capacity of building. 
    Lessee is aware that the total capacity of the Gonzales Civic Center is recommended by the City of Gonzales Fire Chief is: 
(1)  Standing room only, no tables-Six hundred fifty (650) persons maximum. 
(2)  Minimal tables and chair usage-Five hundred (500) persons maximum. 
(Ord. No. 2702, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2867, 7-24-06) 
Chapter 16 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Keeping sidewalks in good order. 
    It shall be the duty of every proprietor of city lots to keep the banquettes and sidewalks opposite his property in good order. 
(Code 1965, § 15-16) 
Sec. 16-2. - Soliciting donations, permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, association, club, society, firm, partnership or corporation to solicit donations or to partake in any money-making activity on the streets, sidewalks or other public places in the city unless such person has first obtained a written permit from the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2018, 1-8-90) 
Secs. 16-3-16-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-16. - Classification according to surface type. 
    For the purposes of this article relating to the cutting of streets, all streets in the city are classified as follows: 
(1)  Class A: All streets hardsurfaced with concrete, brick or asphalt (blacktop). 
(2)  Class B: All streets graveled with curb and gutter. 
(3)  Class C: All streets graveled but without curb and gutter. 
(4)  Class D: Streets or earth and without curb and gutter. 
(Code 1965, § 15-3) 
Sec. 16-17. - Work to be prompt; backfilling; protection of public liability for damages. 
(a)  Any cut on any street made by any person under the provisions of this article shall be made promptly after the permit is taken out and shall be backfilled without any delay as soon as the work is completed. All trenches shall be backfilled in layers not over six (6) inches thick, thoroughly compacted by tamping. If more than one man is engaged in this operation, there shall not be less than one man tamping to each man shoveling earth backfill in trench and such person shall protect such cut while making same and doing any work thereon and all liability for any damages accruing from such cut and while such work and refilling is being done, shall be on the responsibility of the person obtaining the permit and doing the work. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the person obtaining a permit and doing such work to notify the office of the public works manager when ready to begin backfilling, so that inspection can be called for, and it shall be the duty of the person to keep and maintain such trench and backfill to grade and in good shape in order to afford the least possible obstruction to traffic for a period of thirty (30) days after such backfill has been completed. 
(Code 1965, § 15-7) 
Sec. 16-18. - Bond required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any corporation or contractor to dig or excavate across the public streets or right-of-ways of the city without first furnishing a cash or valid surety bond equivalent to ten (10) per cent of the contract under which he is working, to pay for all damages which may be considered by such digging or excavation. 
(b)  Any bond furnished hereunder shall only be refunded after written release authorizing same is given by the city engineer that all work has been completed satisfactorily and all costs thereof paid. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8; Ord. of 7-13-70) 
Secs. 16-19-16-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 16-31. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, break, dig into, or make any excavation in, through, or under any street, sidewalk, neutral ground, curb or gutter in the city unless such person has first obtained a written permit and paid the fees and charges, as hereinafter set forth in this division. 
(Code 1965, § 15-1) 
Sec. 16-32. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to cut or break any street, sidewalk, curb, gutter or neutral ground or to make any excavation therein or thereunder, shall make written application for a permit on forms provided for that purpose, in the office of the public works manager, which permit shall be issued upon the payment of the fees and charges provided in this division and upon compliance with the conditions herein stipulated. The application for permit shall state: 
(1)  The exact location of the proposed cut, break or excavation; 
(2)  The maximum number of square feet to be broken or cut; 
(3)  The purpose of the cut, break or excavation. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 16-33. - Fees. 
(a)  Before any permit shall be issued by the public works manager's office as provided in this division, the fee for the permit and charge for repair shall be paid by the applicant as follows: 
(1)  Class A streets: A charge of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per cubic foot of the cut, plus a flat fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(2)  Class B streets: A charge of fifty cents ($0.50) per cubic foot of the cut plus a flat fee of five dollars ($5.00). 
(3)  Class C streets: A charge of fifty cents ($0.50) per cubic foot of the cut, plus a flat fee of five dollars ($5.00). 
(4)  Class D streets: No fee, but a permit is required. 
After the work on such cuts has been done as approved for herein, the city will repave or repair and pay the costs for such repaving or repairing the cuts from the fees charged and received thereof as herein provided. 
(b)  Before any permit shall be issued by the public works manager's office as provided in this division, for the breaking or cutting of any sidewalk, curb or gutter, the fee for such permit and charge for repair shall be paid by the applicant, as follows: 
(1)  For breaking or cutting sidewalks, a charge of one dollar ($1.00) per cubic foot of the cut, plus a flat fee of five dollars ($5.00). 
(2)  For breaking or cutting curb and gutter alone a charge of two dollars ($2.00) per cubic foot cut or broken, plus a flat fee of one dollar ($1.00). 
Provided, however, if the break or cut is in the sidewalk for the purpose of building or constructing a driveway, the driveway must be constructed under the supervision and in manner determined by the public works manager, in accordance with the established rules of engineering safety. 
(c)  All cuts in neutral ground require a permit, for which there shall be no charge. 
(Code 1965, §§ 15-4-15-6) 
Chapter 18 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE TAXES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- License required for electricians, § 5-93. 
State Law reference- Authority to impose license taxes, Const. 1974, Art. 6, § 28. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-16. - Annual license tax levied. 
    There is hereby levied an occupational license tax for the year 1988 and for each subsequent year, upon each person pursuing and conducting any business, trade, calling, profession, or vocation, within the corporate limits of the city, subject to license under the Louisiana Constitution and laws of this state. 
(Ord. of 10-26-81, § 10-I; Ord. No. 1832, 5-11-87) 
Sec. 18-17. - Adoption of state laws. 
    The amount of license tax levied in each case is hereby fixed, determined, and ordained to be the same as that fixed, levied, and collectable by the governing authority under, and shall be granted in accordance with the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 47, Sections 341 through 363, inclusive, as amended, and all other applicable laws, all of which for all purposes of this division are made a part hereof by reference as if written herein in extenso , with the following exception: 
(1)  Pawnbrokers and persons lending money on wages or salaries: 
    For each and every pawnbroker, or person keeping a loan office and engaged in lending money on articles pawned or pledged and for each and every money broker, money lender or person lending money on, or purchasing time, wages or salaries of laborers, clerks or other wage earners or other persons, whether the same be earned or unearned, and whether the business is conducted in an office or otherwise, a license based on a flat fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be required. Persons licensed under this category may conduct retail sales, provided that the gross receipts from such sales do not exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). If the gross receipts from retail sales exceed one thousand dollars ($100,000.00), a retail license is required. Such retail license shall be based on the sum of the gross receipts of the retail sales and on one-third of the total amount of the money loaned. The license fee shall be based on the rates listed in the table in Revised Statutes 47:354. 
(Ord. of 10-26-81, § 10-II, Ord. No. 1832, 5-11-97; Ord. No. 1910, 2-8-88) 
Sec. 18-18. - Effective date. 
    This division[, as amended,] shall become effective January 1, 1988. 
(Ord. No. 1832, 5-11-87) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 18-21. 
Sec. 18-19. - Due and payment dates. 
(a)  On January 1 of each year the license tax herein authorized to be levied shall be due and payable to the collector of municipal taxes, who shall commence collecting the tax from each person pursuing and conducting any business subject to taxation under this division, the state constitution, and applicable laws of the state. All license taxes levied hereunder shall be due and payable on January 1 of each calendar year for which the license is due, except that for a new business commencing after January 1 of any calendar year, the first license shall be due and payable on the date the business is commenced. 
(b)  All licenses unpaid prior to March 1 of each calendar year for which they are due, or in the case of a new business, unpaid on the date such business is commenced shall be deemed delinquent and subject to the payment of delinquent penalty at the rate of five (5) percent per month, or any portion of a month, up to a maximum of 25 percent, which shall be added to the amount of tax due and computed from the due date until the tax is paid. 
(c)  All licenses unpaid prior to March 1 of each calendar year for which they are due, or in the case of a new business, unpaid on the date such business is commenced shall be deemed delinquent and subject to the payment of delinquent interest at the rate of one and one quarter percent per month, or any portion of a month, which shall be added to the amount of tax due and computed from the due date until the tax is paid. 
(d)  All licenses issued for building, electrical, plumbing, and mechanical contractors shall expire on December 31 of each year. Upon renewal, the contractors listed in this subsection shall pay the full renewal fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), and shall not be subject to the penalties and interest enumerated in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(Ord. of 10-26-81, § 10-V; Ord. of 9-12-83; Ord. No. 1832, 5-11-87; Ord. No. 2862, 5-8-06; Ord. No. 3081, 12-14-15) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 18-21. 
Sec. 18-20. - Repealer clause. 
    All other ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed in their entirety. 
(Ord. No. 1832, 5-11-87) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 18-21. 
Sec. 18-21. - Severability clause. 
    If any provision of this division or the application thereof is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this division which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or applications, [and the provisions] of this division are hereby declared severable. 
(Ord. No. 1832, 5-11-87) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1832, adopted May 11, 1987, repealed former §§ 18-18, 18-19 and 18-21, and provided for the inclusion of § 18-18, effective date; the renumbering of former § 18-20, due and payment dates, as § 18-19; the inclusion of 18-20, repealer clause, and § 18-21, severability clause. Words enclosed in brackets [ ] in such sections have been added for clarity. Prior to repeal, §§ 18-18, 18-19 and 18-21 had been derived from an ordinance adopted Oct. 26, 1981, §§ 10-III, 10-IV, 10-VI, and an ordinance adopted Nov. 23, 1981. Such provisions had pertained to exemptions, definitions, classifications; license required for each business location and class; and failure to pay tax. 
Sec. 18-22. - Traveling shows. 
    Every person engaged in the business of operating merry-go-rounds, flying horses, mechanical swings, big apples, shooting galleries, or other devices run by machinery, or any type of amusement rides which employs more than one (1) animal shall pay a license fee of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) for each such machine or device, and each concession stand or amusement stand of any nature, a license fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each such stand operated, such license shall be valid for a four-day period only, provided the rides, shooting galleries, concession stands, amusement stands, etc., shall be exempt from the above license tax, if the rides, etc., are being sponsored by a civic, religious or educational nonprofit organization, chartered by the state, for the purpose of raising funds for the nonprofit organization. In case of question, as to if a specific organization qualifies for the above exemption, the decision shall be at the discretion of the mayor and the board of aldermen. 
(Code 1965, § 10-22) 
Sec. 18-23. - Special event defined. 
    The words "special event" shall refer to any temporary event not exceeding thirty (30) days whether indoors or outdoors, or on improved or unimproved property, which is inconsistent with either the zone in which the subject property is located, the uses to which the property may legally be put, or the occupancy levels permitted thereon. "Special events" shall also refer to any activity which may temporarily require the installation of materials or devices using building, electrical, mechanical, plumbing, flammable or similar materials. "Special events" may include, but are not limited to certain outdoor, short-term events such as fairs, festivals, walk-a-thons, fun-runs, or any combination thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2741, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 18-24. - Special event permit. 
(a)  Any person or persons desiring to operate, conduct, or manage a festival, fair, or other special event shall first apply to the city for a permit at least fifteen (15) days before the date on which the event is to be conducted, setting forth the following information: 
(1)  The name of the person or organization wishing to conduct such event. 
a.  If the event is to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of this organization and the authorized and responsible head of such organization. 
b.  If the organization is incorporated, a copy of the articles of incorporation shall be attached to the application. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number(s) of the person or organization to whom the permit is to be issued. 
(b)  Any applicant for such permit shall furnish information relative to its operations as may be required by the city including, but not necessarily limited to, contracts with vendors at such event, plans for security and information about past violations. 
(c)  Alcoholic beverage sales are prohibited at outdoor special events and festivals, with the exception of the annual Jambalaya Festival. 
(d)  All fairs and festivals offering amusements shall pay a license fee in accordance with section 18-22 of this chapter. 
(e)  A written plan shall be submitted setting forth all measures proposed to ensure that adequate traffic control, crowd protection, and security on the premises of such event will be maintained, and that the ages of those purchasing alcoholic beverages will be monitored. 
(f)  Any permit issued pursuant to this section shall be for the duration of the event only. 
(g)  The city shall, as a condition of the issuance of a permit, have the authority to require the applicant to provide additional security or take any other measure deemed appropriate by the city council for the protection of patrons of such event. 
(Ord. No. 2741, 10-28-02; Ord. No. 2831, 6-27-05) 
Secs. 18-25-18-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT VENDORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3023, adopted Oct. 28, 2013, amended the title of Div. 2 to read as herein set out. Div. 2 was formerly entitled "Itinerant Vendors." 
State Law reference- Itinerant vendors of spices, toilet articles, proprietary medicines and other packaged articles, R.S. 47:359. 

Sec. 18-36. - Definitions. 
(a)  Itinerant vendor means and includes and shall be construed to mean and include all persons, as well as their agents and employees, who engage in the temporary or transient business in the city or offering for sale any goods or merchandise, including photographs and portraits, or exhibiting the same for sale or exhibiting the same for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business or conducting such exhibits thereof, either hire, rent, lease or occupy any room or space in any building, structure, or other enclosure, or lot in the city, in, through, or from which any goods, or merchandise may be sold, offering for sale, exhibited for sale, or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof. The word "temporary" as above used means and shall be construed to mean any such business transacted or conducted in the city for which definite arrangements have not been made for the hire, rental or lease of premises for at least six (6) months in or upon which such business is to be conducted. The word "transient" as used above means and shall be construed to mean any such business of any such itinerant vendor as may be operated or conducted by persons, or by their agents or employees who reside away from the city, or who have fixed places of business in places other than the city, or who move stocks of goods or merchandise or samples thereof into the city with purpose or intention of removing them or the unsold portion thereof away from the city before the expiration of six (6) months. 
(b)  House-to-house peddling means the practice of going in and upon private residences in the city, by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, or itinerant merchants and transient vendors of merchandise, not having been required or invited to do so by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants of the private residences, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise, and/or for the purpose of disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same, and/or for the purpose of sale of services. Religious, political, or charitable solicitation is not considered to be peddling. 
(c)  Peddler. For purposes of this section this term is meant to apply to all solicitors, peddlers, hawkers and transient vendors referenced in subsection (b) above. 
(Code 1965, § 10; Ord. No. 3023, 10-28-13) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-37. - Itinerant vendors prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any itinerant vendor to sell, offer for sale, exhibit for sale, or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof any goods or merchandise in the City of Gonzales. 
(Code 1965, § 10-17; Ord. No. 2741, 10-28-02; Ord. No. 3023, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 18-37.1. - House-to-house peddling prohibition. 
    House-to-house peddling is hereby declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such as a misdemeanor except under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Hours. House-to-house peddling shall be allowed between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. with the following exceptions: 
a.  A "No Solicitation" sign has been posted at the residence by the owner or occupant, provided that the sign shall be legible and visible at the entranceway to the premises; or 
b.  By resolution of the board of the homeowners' association, a sign has been posted at each entrance to a recognized single family residential subdivision designating the subdivision as a no peddling area. A certified copy of the resolution shall be provided to the city clerk. The sign shall clearly state that house-to-house peddling is prohibited in the subdivision and shall be legible and visible from the public street. No sign shall be posted pursuant to this subsection without the approval of the city engineer. 
(2)  Meat and poultry. Peddling of meat and poultry products must be in compliance with the requirements promulgated by the parish health department. 
(Ord. No. 3023, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 18-37.2 - Permit required. 
(a)  All those wishing to engage in house-to-house peddling must first obtain a permit from the business license department. 
(b)  All persons engaged in house-to-house peddling, as herein defined, must have a valid permit for the time period in which they are peddling. 
(c)  All persons engaged in house-to-house peddling, as herein defined, must have a valid permit on their person, and produce said permit and suitable identification to demonstrate that the solicitor is the person identified by the permit upon demand by an occupant or law enforcement officer or agent. 
(d)  Minor children engaged in house-to-house peddling, as herein defined, receive permits through their parents or legal custodians. 
(e)  Minor children engaged in house-to-house peddling, as herein defined, must be accompanied by an adult, at least eighteen (18) years of age, while engaging in house-to-house peddling. 
(Ord. No. 3023, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 18-37.3 - Permit requirements. 
(a)  Applicants for a permit under this section shall complete a written application, along with a fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), which shall cover the credentialing and background verification of up to four (4) employees authorized to peddle door-to-door under each permit. Any employee credentialed in excess of four (4) shall incur an additional fee of forty dollars ($40.00) each. The permit application must contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant. 
(2)  Name and address of company, employer, or other commercial enterprise represented. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the peddling. 
(4)  If a vehicle is being used, a description of the make and model vehicle and a license plate number. 
(5)  Certification that the applicant has registered with the parish sales and use tax authority. 
(b)  Applications must include a copy of a valid state or federal identification card, passport, or official school identification (for minors). 
(Ord. No. 3023, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 18-37.4 - Permit issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of the completed application, the business license department shall issue a permit to the applicant. 
(b)  All those issued a permit under this section shall have said permit available upon request by any person or law enforcement officer or agent at all times during the door-to-door peddling, whether on the premises or while in transit from one location to another for purposes of peddling. 
(c)  Permits issued under this section shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 3023, 10-28-13) 
Secs. 18-38, 18-39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2741, adopted Oct. 28, 2002, repealed §§ 18-38 and 18-39 in their entirety. Former §§ 18-38 and 18-39 pertained to itinerant vendors and derived from the Code of 1965 and Ord. No. 2523, adopted Oct. 12, 1998. 
Sec. 18-40. - Same-Display. 
    The license shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises where such sale or exhibit is being conducted and shall remain so displayed so long as any goods or merchandise are being sold or exhibited. 
(Code 1965, § 10-20) 
Sec. 18-41. - Exceptions. 
    This division is not, and shall not be held to be applicable to the: 
(1)  Ordinary commercial traveler who sells or exhibits for sale goods or merchandise to parties engaged in the business or buying and selling and dealing in such goods or merchandise; 
(2)  Vendor of farm produce, poultry stock or agricultural products in their natural state. 
(Code 1965, § 10-21; Ord. No. 2644, 7-24-00) 
Sec. 18-42 - Open-air sales. 
(a)  All tent sales, sidewalk sales, and other sales of an open-air nature shall be restricted to companies with an established permanent business location within the city, no more than twice annually and shall be limited to no more than seven (7) days at a time. 
(b)  Open-air sales shall be restricted to companies with an existing and current occupational license with the city. 
(c)  All sales of goods in an open-air setting shall be related and similar in nature to the goods, products and services normally sold at the established business location. 
(d)  All sales of goods in an open-air setting shall be recorded and reported no different from normal sales of the established business operating the sale. 
(Ord. No. 2741, 10-28-02; Ord. No. 2821, 4-25-05; Ord. No. 4033 , 9-25-17) 
Secs. 18-43-18-47. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GARAGE SALES, YARD SALES, ETC. 

Sec. 18-48. - Definition. 
    As used in this division the term "garage sales" shall mean any sale of what is held out to be or is commonly known as a garage, porch, rummage, backyard, yard, patio sales, moving sale, or flea market or any other type of general sale conducted from or on any premises not located in a zoning district which permits such sales, where goods or articles of any type are held out for sale to the public. This definition shall not include a situation where specific items are held out for sale and all advertisement of such sale specifically names the items to be sold. 
(Ord. No. 2506, 4-13-98) 
Sec. 18-49. - Frequency of sales. 
(a)  No person shall hold, conduct, engage in or participate in any manner or allow a garage sale to be held or conducted on premises under his/her control or ownership more than one (1) time in any three-month period, nor more than three (3) times in any calendar year, and said sale shall not be continued for a period of more than three (3) consecutive days. 
(b)  Garage sales shall be supervised and are the responsibility of the occupant or the tenant who occupies the dwelling unit. This person shall not permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the area of the person's property. 
(Ord. No. 2506, 4-13-98) 
Sec. 18-50. - Signs. 
(a)  No person shall place any cards or placards advertising a garage sale on any property other than property owned by the person conducting the sale without the consent of the owner. Said signs shall not be posted more than forty-eight (48) hours prior to the sale and shall be removed within twelve (12) hours after the close of the sale. 
(b)  The display surface of a sign or device shall not exceed four (4) square feet on each side. 
(c)  No signs may be posted on any utility pole or in any public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2506, 4-13-98) 
Sec. 18-51. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall hold, conduct, engage in, or participate, in any manner, in a garage sale without a permit. A separate permit shall be required for each location at which a garage sale is to be held under the provisions of the article. 
(b)  An applicant for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall furnish the city with the following information: 
(1)  Full name and address of applicant. 
(2)  The location at which the proposed garage sale is to be held. 
(3)  The date or dates upon which the sale shall be held. 
(4)  An affidavit from the applicant to the effect that all goods to be sold at the residential sale are owned by the applicant or that the applicant has written authority from the owner of said goods to sell same at the sale for the owner and have not been obtained for the purpose of reselling them at the sales as a business venture. 
(5)  A statement from the applicant that there will be no more than five (5) families participating in or at said garage sale. 
(c)  A permit shall be issued for a garage sale for a period not to exceed three (3) consecutive days to any person applying who otherwise complies with the requirements of this Code. The following exception will be allowed: 
If the sale cannot be held because of inclement weather or other emergency causes, and upon the submittal of an affidavit stating the particular reasons why the sale was not held, the city may issue another permit to the applicant for a garage sale to be conducted at the same location within thirty (30) days from the date when the first sale was to be held. 
(d)  No fee will be required for this permit. 
(e)  Nonprofit organizations are exempt from the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2506, 4-13-98) 
DIVISION 4. - TREE SURGEONS; TREE SERVICE CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 18-52. - Registration; insurance. 
    Any firm or person engaged in the business of cutting and/or trimming trees and large limbs shall register each year with the city for a contractor license to perform such work and pay an annual license fee in accordance with current fee schedules for contractors. No such license shall be issued until the applicant produces proof that they have a five thousand dollar ($5,000) surety bond in force throughout the duration of said license. 
(Ord. No. 2619, 11-8-99) 
DIVISION 5. - INSURANCE PREMIUM TAX 

Sec. 18-53. - Annual license tax levied. 
    There is hereby imposed and levied an annual license tax on any insurer engaged in the business of issuing any form of insurance policy or contract which may now or hereafter be subject to the payment of any license tax for state purposes, all as authorized by R.S. 22:1076 on risks located in this municipality as follows: 
(a)  On any insurer engaged in the business of issuing life or accident or health insurance policies, other than programs of benefits authorized or provided pursuant to the provisions of Parts I and II of Chapter 12 of Title 42 of the Louisiana Revised Statutes of 1960, or other forms of contracts or obligations covering such risks, or issuing endowment or annuity policies, or contracts, or other similar forms of contract obligations in consideration of the payment of a premium or other consideration for the issuance of such policies, contracts or obligations whether such insurer by operating in the state or through an agent or other representative, or otherwise: 
(1)  Ten dollars ($10.00) on gross annual premiums up to two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) and an additional license thereafter of seventy dollars ($70.00) on each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or fraction thereof, of gross annual premiums in excess of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(2)  The maximum license on such business, payable to this municipality by any one (1) insurer, shall not exceed twenty-one thousand dollars ($21,000.00). 
(b)  On any insurer, engaged in this business of insuring policies, contracts or other forms of obligations covering the risk of fire, marine, transportation, surety, fidelity, indemnity, guaranty, worker's compensation, employers' liability, property damage, livestock, vehicle, automatic sprinkler, burglary, or insurance business of any other kind whatsoever in this state, whether such insurer is operating in this state through agents or other representative or otherwise, not more than the following: 
(1)  1st Class. When the gross receipts are not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), the license shall be forty dollars ($40.00); 
(2)  2nd Class. When the gross receipts are more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), and not more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00), the license shall be sixty dollars ($60.00); 
(3)  3rd Class. When the gross receipts are more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00), and not more than six thousand ($6,000.00), the license shall be eighty dollars ($80.00); 
(4)  4th Class. When the gross receipts exceed six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) the additional license thereafter shall be seventy dollars ($70.00) for each ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or fraction thereof, in excess of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00); 
(5)  The maximum license tax on such businesses, payable to this municipality by any insurer shall not exceed the maximum limit of nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00), as provided by Louisiana Revised Statutes section 22:1076, above referred to; 
(6)  Provided, that plate glass and steam boiler inspection insurers shall pay only one-third of the above rates provided in said subsection (b); and provided further, that the amount of license payable to this municipality as fixed by this section, shall be one-third of the amount so fixed if the payer shall file a sworn statement with the annual report required by Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 22, Chapter 1, Part XXIII, showing that at least one-sixth of the total admitted assets of the payer, less assets in an amount equal to the reserves on its policies issued in foreign countries in which it is authorized to do business and which countries require an investment therein as a condition of doing business, is invested and maintained, either in bonds of the state, or in bonds of municipal, school, road or levee district, or other political subdivisions of this state or in mortgages on property located in the state, or in real property in this state which shall be requisite for the convenient accommodation of the transaction of its own business, or in policy loans, or in the state, or in stock of homestead building or loan associations organized under the laws of this state, to the extent such stock is guaranteed or insured by the federal deposit insurance corporation of other federal or state agency. 
(Ord. No. 2703, 9-24-01) 
Sec. 18-54. - Due and payment date. 
    All license taxes levied herein shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year and all unpaid license taxes shall become delinquent on June 1. A penalty of five (5) percent per month shall be added to the amount of tax due and payable to this municipality along with the tax due. The amount of any monetary penalty assessed pursuant to this section shall not be greater than twenty-five (25) percent of the total amount of the tax due. The collection of delinquent account shall be enforced in accordance with Louisiana Revised Statutes 22:1076 and 47:1601. 
(Ord. No. 2703, 9-24-01) 
Sec. 18-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES AND USE TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to levy sales and use taxes, R.S. 33:2711; state sales tax, R.S. 47:301 et seq. 

Sec. 18-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the content clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business includes any activity engaged in, by any person or caused to be engaged in by him with the object of gain, benefit or advantage, either direct or indirect. The term "business" shall not be construed in this article to include occasional and isolated sales or transactions by a person who does not hold himself out as engaged in business. 
    Collector means the clerk and the marshal of the City of Gonzales, Louisiana, or either, and includes his duly authorized assistants.
