Sec. 18-105. - Tax collector's authority to grant extensions. 
    Upon the written request of the taxpayer and for good cause shown the tax collector may grant reasonable extensions of time for the filing of returns and payment of tax due under this article, provided that such extensions of time shall not exceed thirty (30) calendar days. Whenever such an extension is granted, the return or tax for which the extension is granted shall not become delinquent until the expiration of the extension period; but interest will accrue on the tax during the period of the extension, such interest to be computed in all cases from the date the tax would have become delinquent in the absence of an extension. 
(Ord. of 6-9-59, § 50) 
Sec. 18-106. - Tax collector's authority to require bond. 
    The city may require a bond or other security satisfactory to the tax collector for the payment of any taxes, fees, interest and penalties, or any of them, imposed pursuant to this article, when he shall find that the collection thereof may be prejudiced without such section. 
(Ord. of 6-9-59, § 51) 
Sec. 18-107. - Administrative. 
(a)  The collection of the taxes imposed hereunder shall be made in the name of the city, by the tax collector, who is the collector of all city taxes under the provision of Act 14 of 1914, as amended. 
(b)  The tax collector is duly authorized and empowered to carry into effect the provisions of this article, and in pursuance thereof to make and enforce such rules as he may deem necessary. Such regulation when promulgated shall have the full force and effect of law. Promulgation shall be accomplished by publication at least one time in the official journal of the city. 
(c)  The tax collector may employ such personnel, including legal counsel on a fee or salary basis, as are necessary to assist in the collection of the taxes imposed hereunder. 
(d)  Any duly authorized representative or deputy of the tax collector, when acting under his authority and direction, shall have the same power as is conferred upon the tax collector by this article. 
(e)  The collector may conduct hearings and administer oaths, and examine under oath, any dealer and the directors, officers, agents and employees of any dealer, and any other witnesses, relative to the business of such dealer in respect to any matter incident to the administration of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-9-59, § 52) 
Sec. 18-108. - Cost of forms to be borne by the city. 
    The cost of preparing and distributing the report forms and paraphernalia for the collection of these taxes and of the inspection and enforcement duties required herein, together with any and all expenses of any kind or nature whatever incurred in placing the plan for the collection of these in operation, shall be borne by the city and shall be paid out of the revenue derived from the imposition and collection of the sales and use tax, and the tax collector shall have authority to charge any such costs or expenses to the sales tax fund to be set up and established under the provisions hereof. 
(Ord. of 6-9-59, § 53) 
Sec. 18-109. - Disposition of tax proceeds and revenues. 
(a)  All taxes, revenues, funds, assessments, moneys, penalties, fees or other income which may be collected or come into the possession of the tax collector, as agent of the city under any provision or provisions of this article, shall be promptly deposited by the tax collector for the account of the city in a special fund designated as "sales tax fund", which fund shall be a separate bank account established and maintained with the regularly designated fiscal agent of the city; provided, however, any amount which is paid under protest or which is subject to litigation may be transferred to a separate bank account established by the tax collector with the fiscal agent pending the final determination of the protest or litigation. 
(b)  Out of the funds on deposit in the "sales tax fund", the tax collector shall first pay all reasonable and necessary costs and expenses of collecting the tax levied hereby and administering the provisions of this article as well as the various administrative procedures established herein. Such costs and expenses shall be reported by the tax collector monthly to the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(c)  In compliance with the special election of September 10, 1966, authorizing the tax, after all reasonable and necessary costs and expenses of collection and administration of the tax have been paid as provided for hereinabove, the remaining balance in the "sales tax fund" shall be available for appropriation and expenditure by the mayor and board of aldermen solely for the purposes designated in the proposition authorizing the levy of the tax, to wit: "for the purpose of constructing, repairing, maintenance and operation of streets, sidewalks, drainage and for garbage collection; for the constructing, maintenance and operation of public utilities in the city, including gas, water and sewerage; for the establishment, maintenance, replacement and operation of parks and recreational facilities in the city; for the maintenance and operation of the fire department, as well as the purchase of equipment for the fire department; and for the purpose of constructing, acquiring, maintaining, equipping and furnishing public buildings, including a City Hall and a civic and recreation center building; title to which improvements shall be in the 'public', and the propositions authorizing the issuance of bonds payable therefrom, said propositions having been approved by a majority of the qualified electors of the city voting at a special election held on Saturday, September 10, 1966." 
(Ord. of 3-6-67, § 1) 
Sec. 18-110. - Sales and use tax are in addition to all other taxes. 
    The tax levied herein is declared to be supplemental and in addition to all other taxes levied by and under the authority of the mayor and board of aldermen of any kind or nature. 
(Ord. of 6-9-59, § 56) 
Sec. 18-111. - Short title. 
    This article may be cited or otherwise referred to as the "City of Gonzales Sales and Use Tax of 1959." 
(Ord. of 6-9-59, § 57) 
Chapter 19 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific streets or locations saved from repeal, § 1-5(9); streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 16; vehicles for hire, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles and traffic regulations, R.S. 32:1 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate traffic, R.S. 32:41. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - State highway act adopted. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred by R.S. 32:41(c), the city hereby adopts the provisions of Title 32, Chapter 1, Revised Statutes of Louisiana, being the Highway Regulatory Act, and all regulations of the state department of highways and the director of public safety adopted pursuant thereto, except for such provisions and regulations as by their nature can have no application in the city, and except as otherwise provided in this Code or by ordinance. Any person violating such provisions or regulations shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. of 8-10-70) 
Sec. 19-2. - Reckless operation of a vehicle. 
    Reckless operation of a vehicle is the operation of any motor vehicle, aircraft, vessel or other means of conveyance in a criminally negligent or reckless manner; or in such a manner as to foreseeably endanger persons or property; or in such a manner as to foreseeably alarm the public by causing fear of injury to persons or damage to property, and is unlawful. 
(Code 1965, § 11-58; Ord. of 5-23-66) 
State Law reference- Reckless operation of a vehicle, R.S. 14:99. 
Sec. 19-3. - Hit and run driving. 
(a)  Hit and run driving is the intentional failure of the driver of a vehicle involved in or causing any accident to stop such a vehicle at the scene of the accident, to give his identity and to render reasonable aid, and is unlawful. 
(b)  "To give his identity," for the purpose of this section, shall mean that the driver of any vehicle involved in any accident shall give his name, address and the license number of his vehicle, or shall report the accident to the police. 
(Code 1965, § 11-59) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 14:100. 
Sec. 19-4. - Speed limits generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive any motor vehicle or other vehicle upon the streets of the city at a greater speed than twenty-five (25) miles per hour, except as otherwise posted. 
(Code 1965, § 19-17) 
Sec. 19-5. - Speed limits at school and park zones. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour in a school or park zone or other area appropriately designated by signs. 
(Code 1965, § 19-25) 
Sec. 19-6. - Speed of railroad trains; persons responsible. 
    It shall be unlawful for any conductor, brakeman, engineer, fireman, or any other person in charge of a train of cars or locomotive to run such train of cars or locomotive at a higher speed than twenty-five (25) miles per hour within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 19-20; Ord. of 11-10-80) 
Sec. 19-7. - Obstructing by trains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any conductor, brakeman, engineer or fireman conducting or having in charge and under his supervision any train of cars, locomotive or car to allow such train of cars, locomotive or car to obstruct any street crossing for over a period of ten (10) minutes. 
(Code 1965, § 19-23) 
Sec. 19-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3020, adopted Oct. 14, 2013, repealed § 19-8, entitled "U-turns prohibited" and derived from Code 1965, § 19-52. 
Sec. 19-9. - Load limit on blacktop streets. 
    There is hereby established and fixed concerning all vehicles of any type whatsoever traversing or which may traverse, cross or proceed upon any asphalt surfaced or blacktopped streets of whatsoever character in the city, with the exception of Irma Boulevard, on which load limit shall be three (3) tons gross tonnage, a load limit of five (5) tons gross tonnage, and all vehicles of whatsoever character weighing in excess thereof, whether unloaded or loaded, are hereby prohibited from traversing, traveling on or crossing such types of streets in any manner whatsoever. 
(Code 1965, § 19-6; Ord. of 9-23-68) 
Sec. 19-10. - Load limit on Edenborn Street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any vehicle weighing in excess of ten (10) tons to travel or park on Edenborn Street. 
(Ord. of 5-27-68) 
Sec. 19-11. - Riding on sidewalks. 
    The riding of motor bikes, motor scooters, motorcycles or go-carts upon the banquettes or sidewalks of the city is strictly prohibited. 
(Code 1965, § 19-59) 
Sec. 19-12. - Quiet zones. 
    It shall be unlawful to cause excess noise to occur, over and above what is normally expected and is necessary to promote the orderly flow of traffic and pedestrians in any area where "quiet zone" signs are displayed within the city limits. 
(Ord. of 7-10-72) 
Secs. 19-13-19-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Off-street parking requirements, § 22-9. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 19-26. - Stopping in traveled portion of street. 
    Unless in an emergency to allow another vehicle or pedestrian to cross its path, no person shall permit a vehicle to stop and stand in any public street or way except in designated parking spaces. 
(Code 1965, § 19-39) 
Sec. 19-27. - Abandoned vehicles; leaving on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon any vehicle of any description whatsoever on the streets, and the police officials of the city or any of their designated agents are hereby given the right and authority to impound and pick up such vehicles in violation hereof, to cause same to be done by wreckers or any means necessary at their command and to charge the owners or operators of such vehicles for the costs thereof. Any vehicle which shall remain continuously in the same place for a period of two (2) days shall be presumed to be abandoned. 
(Code 1965, § 19-40; Ord. of 11-14-66) 
Sec. 19-28. - Parking of bicycles and other vehicles on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful to park or cause to be parked on the sidewalks of the city, bicycles or other vehicles of any description. 
(Code 1965, § 15-11) 
Sec. 19-29. - Repairing vehicle on street prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any mechanical repair work on any motor vehicle while such motor vehicle is parked on any street. 
(Code 1965, § 19-44) 
Sec. 19-30. - Parking on streets for sale of vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle dealers, garages or motor vehicle repair shops are hereby prohibited from parking any vehicles of any description held for sale, or for repair, on any of the streets of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 19-45) 
Sec. 19-31. - Time limit for truck-trailers and tank trucks. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any truck-trailer or tank trucks on the city streets for a longer period than two (2) hours during any twenty-four (24) hour period. 
(Code 1965, § 19-46) 
Sec. 19-32. - Parallel parking at all places not otherwise designated. 
    All vehicles when stopping or parking on the streets of the city shall park or stop parallel to the curbing on the right side of the street within the marked space denoted for parking, save and except if specifically directed to do otherwise by sign. 
(Code 1965, § 19-47) 
Sec. 19-33. - Double parking. 
    It shall be unlawful to double park on any street unless the driver of such vehicle shall remain at the wheel and shall park so as not to obstruct approaching traffic. 
(Code 1965, § 19-48) 
Sec. 19-34. - Parking prohibited on Cornerview Road. 
    It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle on either side or state route no. 429 "Cornerview Road," extending from state route no. 44 "Burnside Street" to the westerly city limits. 
(Code 1965, § 19-54) 
Sec. 19-35. - Parking prohibited on designated area of Burnside Street. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on the east side of Burnside Street extending from the point of intersection with the north side of East New River Street to the north side of the St. Theresa Rectory driveway. 
(Ord. of 5-13-68) 
Sec. 19-36. - Four-hour parking limit on certain streets. 
    Notwithstanding any other specific restriction in this section, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any street in Gonzales continuously in the same parking place for a longer period than four (4) hours in any ten-hour period from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Sundays excluded: 
(1)  Both sides of Burnside Street from New River Bayou to Roosevelt Street; 
(2)  Both sides of Burnside Street from Roosevelt Street to a point two hundred seventy (270) feet south of Legion Street; 
(3)  Both sides of Railroad Street from Felicity Street to Alexander Street; 
(4)  Both sides of Ascension Street from Felicity Street to Alexander Street; 
(5)  Both sides of Roosevelt Street from Alexander Street to Burnside Street; 
(6)  Both sides of West Roosevelt Street from Burnside Street to Felicity Street; 
(7)  Both sides of Felicity Street from Railroad Street to Ascension Street; and 
(8)  Both sides of Alexander Street from Railroad Street to Ascension Street. 
(Code 1965, § 19-54.1; Ord. of 11-14-64; Ord. of 8-26-68; Ord. No. 2982, 12-12-11) 
Sec. 19-37. - Handicapped parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle, other than one bearing a license plate, tag or card with the word "handicapped" endorsed thereon issued by the state pursuant to R.S. 47:463.4 et seq., or any other state, in a parking space or area, either publicly or privately owned, which has been designated and marked for handicapped parking in accordance with R.S. 40:1742 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2532, 1-25-99) 
Sec. 19-38. - Parking within a fire zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in a parking space or area, or obstruct a fire apparatus passage on property either publicly or privately owned, which has been designated and marked as a fire zone or fire lane. 
(Ord. No. 2533, 1-25-99) 
Sec. 19-39. - Off-street parking in residential areas. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article of the Gonzales City Code is to control, through nuisance and zoning regulations, certain land uses and activities that have a direct and detrimental effect on the character of the city's residential neighborhoods. As such, the Gonzales City Council finds that, in order to accommodate the off-street parking needs of residents while protecting the interests of the public, regulations and performance standards are desirable and necessary for off-street parking areas in residential zoning districts. 
(b)  Findings. To the purposes listed above, the Gonzales City Council finds that the use and possession of vehicles are an important factor in the lives of many residents of Gonzales. The city council also finds that the number of vehicles, the improper storage of vehicles and the parking of and storage of excessive numbers of vehicles can be a nuisance and can affect the neighborhood character as well as the public health, safety and welfare, property values and the reasonable use and enjoyment of neighboring properties. The city council further finds that the establishment of these regulations furthers the goals in the Gonzales Comprehensive Plan relative to the establishment and enhancement of residential neighborhoods and similar goals. In making these findings, the city council accepts the recommendations of city staff and the planning commission that have studied the experiences of other suburban cities that have reviewed and regulated off-street parking in residential areas. The Gonzales City Council establishes these regulations as a means to balance the interests of the owners of vehicles, nearby residents and the public. 
(c)  Goals. The city council's goals in adopting this ordinance include the following: 
(1)  Preserving neighborhood character, public health, safety and welfare and property values. 
(2)  Allowing all residents a reasonable use of and a chance to enjoy their property. 
(3)  Minimizing the nuisances and the adverse effects of off-street vehicle parking through careful site design standards. 
(4)  Requiring the owners and builders of residential driveways and parking areas to design and build them to reasonable standards. 
(5)  Avoiding nuisances and potential damage to adjacent properties from off-street vehicle parking and parking areas through design standards and setback requirements. 
(d)  Off-street parking standards for single and two-family dwellings. The following standards shall apply to off-street parking for single and two-family residential properties in the R-6, R-8, R-10, R-15 zoning districts: 
(1)  Vehicle parking in the front yard setback area (the area between the front of the residential structure and the street right-of-way line) of single and two-family residences shall only be on a hard surface driveway or on improved and designated parking areas. Such a hard surface shall include bituminous, concrete, brick, gravel or crushed rock or another hard surface approved by city staff, constructed to a depth sufficient to distribute the weight of a vehicle or equipment over such area to preclude deterioration and deflection of the area due vehicle or equipment load, adverse weather, or other conditions. 
(2)  Vehicle or equipment means and includes any motor vehicle, truck, passenger motor vehicle, motor home, camper cabin, motorcycle, trailer, boat, farm machinery or similar equipment. 
(3)  The city prohibits vehicle parking or storage in the front yard on grass, unimproved areas or areas without a hard surface. 
(4)  Driveways and parking areas shall preferably be at least five (5) feet from a side property line, but no less than one (1) foot from a side property line and parking areas may cross, but shall not otherwise be in any right-of-way or on other public property. 
(5)  No owner or operator shall park a vehicle that would block a sidewalk. 
(6)  All vehicles parked or stored outside on a residential property shall not be abandoned (as defined in Chapter 19, Division 2), shall have a current license and registration and shall be in operable condition. 
(7)  The total area in the front yard setback area of a single dwelling lot improved for parking and driveway purposes shall not exceed forty (40) percent of the front yard setback area. The total area in the front yard setback area of a duplex or double-dwelling lot improved for parking and driveway purposes shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the front yard setback area. 
(8)  The city may in limited circumstances approve an increase in front yard driveway coverage, a different driveway setback or a different coverage, a different driveway setback or a different driveway surface for a single or double dwelling by administrative review. As part of such approval, the city may require the property owner or applicant to add screening such as a privacy fences, additional landscaping or other means of screening next to or around the parking area or driveway, subject to inspection and approval of city staff. Any permit considered for an increase in driveway coverage must be consistent with the original architectural design intent for the residence and keeping with the overall characteristics of the surrounding community. 
(e)  Offense. It shall be an offense for any person to park or to cause, suffer or permit the parking of a vehicle or equipment on any surface that is not an improved surface as defined in this ordinance, within any front or side yard of a single-family residence in a residential area subject to this section. It is presumed that the registered owner of the vehicle or equipment is the person who parked, caused, suffered or permitted the vehicle or equipment to be parked in violation of this ordinance. 
    The provisions of this ordinance shall not apply to special events such as family gatherings or parties. This exception is limited to twelve (12) hours. 
(f)  Penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Each day of violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
    The city's goal is compliance. Prohibited parking complaints will be assigned to the city building official or his designee. The city building official will communicate with the violator/homeowner/resident to educate and explain the violation. They will be given the opportunity to correct the violation and advised that future violations may result in a citation and fine from the Gonzales Police Department. The preferred method to address violations of this ordinance is to contact the city building official, NOT calling 911 or the police dispatcher. 
( Ord. No. 4050 , 4-9-18) 
Secs. 19-40-19-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ABANDONED STRIPPED JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, R.S. 32:471 et seq.; abandoned automobiles, major appliances and other junk, R.S. 33:4876. 

Sec. 19-51. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this division. 
    Stripped junked motor vehicle shall mean any motor vehicle which is totally inoperable, left unattended on a public street or public property for more than forty-eight (48) hours, and is so damaged or dismantled as to be a total loss. 
    Total loss shall mean that the cost to repair a damaged or dismantled motor vehicle exceeds the junk value for such vehicle, as determined by any recognized national appraisal book. 
(Code 1965, § 8-26; Ord. of 9-22-69) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 19-52. - Declared public property. 
    The ownership of any abandoned stripped junked motor vehicle left on the streets of the city, and which remains on the streets after notice is hereinafter provided, shall be forfeited to the public. Such vehicle shall be considered public property and disposed of as hereinafter set forth in this division. 
(Code 1965, § 8-27; Ord. of 9-22-69) 
Sec. 19-53. - Removal. 
(a)  The police department shall be responsible for the administration of this division and shall remove or cause to be removed from the streets of the city all abandoned stripped junked motor vehicles in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Prior to the disposition of any such vehicle, the chief of police shall place on an abandoned stripped junked motor vehicle a notice of removal which notice shall be placed on the vehicle at least ten (10) days prior to its removal. The notice shall state that the vehicle, unless claimed within ten (10) days, will be considered public property and removed from the town street and sold for junk. The notice shall further state the following: 
(1)  The date the notice was placed on the vehicle; 
(2)  The date ten (10) days' notice will expire; 
(3)  The authority to be contacted by any person claiming to have an interest in the vehicle. 
Such notice shall be placed in a prominent place on the abandoned stripped junked motor vehicle so as to be plainly in the public view. 
(c)  The chief of police, after the time provided for above has expired, shall remove or cause to be removed the abandoned stripped junked motor vehicle from the city street and is hereby authorized to convey same to a scrap iron dealer, towing service or dismantler, approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(d)  All abandoned stripped junked motor vehicles removed from the city streets in accordance with this division shall be subject to a service charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00), payable to the police department, which charge will be due by the owner of or any person claiming an interest in the abandoned or stripped junked motor vehicle, and the vehicle or watercraft will be towed at the owner's expense. 
(e)  The chief of police shall furnish a report to the director of the motor vehicle division of the department of revenue of the state each month, with the following information: 
(1)  Location where the junked stripped motor vehicle was abandoned; 
(2)  All identification information available; 
(3)  Date of transfer and name and address of scrap iron dealer, towing service or dismantler to whom vehicle was transferred for final disposition. 
(Code 1965, § 8-28; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-54. - Record of sales. 
    The chief of police shall keep a complete record of all abandoned stripped junked motor vehicles removed from city streets, with details as to the date of placing a ten (10) day notice, date of removal from city streets, name and address of scrap iron dealer, towing service or dismantler to whom the stripped junked motor vehicle was taken. 
(Code 1965, § 8-29; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-55. - Towing service agreement, disposition of sale proceeds. 
(a)  For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this division, the city is authorized to enter into a contract with an approved towing service, scrap dealer or dismantler. After compliance with this division and forty-eight (48) hours after removal, title to these vehicles shall pass into the contractor. Such vehicles after compliance herewith shall be disposed of by the contractor, but in no event are these vehicles to be resold as complete vehicles or reconditioned so as to be returned to the streets in an operating condition. Forty-eight (48) hours after vehicle is transferred to the contractor, the city shall be relieved of all liability for the vehicle. 
(b)  All contractors under this article shall carry liability insurance in amounts provided by the city; shall own such equipment as may be required or necessary to properly carry out the contract and shall agree to hold the city free and harmless from any claims arising out of the work performed. The contracts to be so executed shall be approved by the office of the city attorney as to form. 
(c)  If contracts are executed with more than one (1) contractor, the city shall make assignments on an approved rotating basis so that all contractors will be given an equal number of assignments to the extent feasible and practical. 
(Code 1965, § 8-30; Ord. of 9-22-69) 
Secs. 19-56-19-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLE OR WATERCRAFT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, R.S. 32:471 et seq.; abandoned automobiles, major appliances and other junk, R.S. 33:4876. 

Sec. 19-66. - Defined. 
    "Junked motor vehicle or watercraft," as used in this division, is any motor vehicle or watercraft, which does not have lawfully affixed thereto a valid motor vehicle safety inspection certificate, or the condition of which is one or more of the following: 
(1)  Wrecked; 
(2)  Dismantled; 
(3)  Partially dismantled; 
(4)  Inoperative; 
(5)  Abandoned; 
(6)  Discarded. 
The provisions hereto shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any motor vehicle or watercraft in operable condition specifically adapted or constructed for racing or operation on privately owned drag strips or raceways. 
(2)  Any motor vehicle retained by the owner for antique collection purposes rather than for salvage or for transportation; nor 
(3)  Any motor vehicle stored as the property of a member of the Armed Forces of the United States who is on active duty assignment. 
(Code 1965, § 8-36; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2120, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 19-67. - Declared a public nuisance. 
    The presence of any junked motor vehicle or watercraft on any private lot, tract or parcel of land, or portion thereof, occupied or unoccupied, improved or unimproved within the city shall be deemed and is hereby declared a public nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or maintain such a public nuisance by wrecking, dismantling, partially dismantling, rendering inoperable, abandoning or discarding any motor vehicle on the real property of another or to suffer, permit, or allow any junked motor vehicle or watercraft to be parked, left or maintained on his own real property provided that this section shall not apply with regard to: 
(1)  Any junked motor vehicle or watercraft in an enclosed building; 
(2)  Any junked motor vehicle or watercraft on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful manner, when necessary to the operation of such business enterprise; or 
(3)  Any junked motor vehicle or watercraft in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained at a location where such business is authorized under the zoning law and other regulatory ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 8-37; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-68. - Notice to owner or occupant to abate public nuisance on occupied premises. 
(a)  Whenever any public nuisance exists on occupied premises within the city in violation of section 19-67, the chief of police or other duly authorized agent shall order the owner of the premises, if in possession thereof, or the occupant of the premises whereon such public nuisance exists, to abate or remove the same. Such order shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Specify the public nuisance and its location; 
(3)  Specify the corrective measures required; 
(4)  Provide for the compliance with ten (10) days from service thereof. 
Such order shall be served upon the owner of the premises or the occupant by serving him personally or by sending said order by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the premises. If the owner or occupant of the premises fails or refuses to comply with the order of the chief of police or his duly authorized agent within the ten-day period after service thereof, as provided herein, the chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall prepare and file an affidavit charging that the owner or occupant of the premises, as the case may be, has violated the provisions of this division. After service of the warrant, the complaint shall be placed on the docket of the parish court. 
(Code 1965, § 8-38; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-69. - Notice to owner to abate public nuisance on unoccupied premises. 
(a)  Whenever any public nuisance exists on unoccupied premises within the city, and the owner thereof can be found, the chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall order the owner of the premises whereon such public nuisance exists, to abate or remove the same. Such order shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Specify the public nuisance and its location; 
(3)  Specify the corrective measures required; and 
(4)  Provided for compliance within ten (10) days from service thereof. 
The order shall be served upon the owner of the premises by serving him personally or by sending the order by certified mail, return receipt requested, to his address as shown on the current tax rolls. If the owner of the premises fails or refuses to comply with the order of the chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall prepare and file an affidavit charging that the owner or occupant of the premises, as the case may be, has violated the provisions of this division. After service of the warrant, the complaint shall be placed on the docket of the parish court. 
(Code 1965, § 8-39; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-70. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2717, adopted Jan. 28, 2002, repealed § 19-70. Former § 19-70 pertained to preliminaries to trial in court and derived from the Code of 1965 and an ordinance adopted on Sept. 22, 1969. 
Sec. 19-71. - Trial in the city court. 
    Upon a finding that the defendant is in violation of this division, the defendant shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine in accordance with the penalty provision hereinafter set forth. The judge of the parish court shall further order such defendant to remove and abate the nuisance within ten (10) days, the same being a reasonable time, or render such other judgment or order as may be appropriate under the circumstances. If the defendant shall fail and refuse, within ten (10) days, to abate or remove the nuisance, the judge may issue an order directing the chief of police to have the same removed, and the chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall take possession of the junked motor vehicle or watercraft and remove it from the premises. The chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall remove and dispose of the junked motor vehicle or watercraft in the same manner as provided in sections 19-53 through 19-55 for the removal and disposition of abandoned stripped motor vehicles removed from the city streets, and any junked motor vehicle or watercraft removed, as herein provided, shall be subject to a service charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00), payable to the police department, which charge shall be due by the owner or any person claiming same, or an interest herein, and the vehicle or watercraft will be towed at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1965, § 8-41; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-72. - Removal with permission of owner or occupant. 
    If, within ten (10) days after receipt of notice from the chief of police, or his duly authorized agent, to abate the nuisance, as herein provided, the owner or occupant of the premises shall give his written permission to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent for removal of the junked motor vehicle from the premises, the giving of such permission shall be considered compliance within the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1965, § 8-42; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-73. - Removal from unoccupied premises by order of court. 
    If there is a junked motor vehicle or watercraft, on premises that are unoccupied, and neither the owner of the premises nor the owner of the vehicle can be found and notified to remove same, then, upon a showing of such facts to the judge of the parish court, the court may issue an order directing the marshal to have the same removed, and the chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall take possession of the junked motor vehicle or watercraft and remove it from the premises. The chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall there-after dispose of the junked motor vehicle or watercraft in the same manner as provided in section 19-68. 
(Code 1965, § 8-43; Ord. of 9-22-69; Ord. No. 2717, 1-28-02) 
Sec. 19-74. - Evidence of abandonment. 
    If a junked motor vehicle has been situated on the private property of another, without such person's permission, for a period of sixty (60) days or longer, this fact shall be prima facie evidence that the owner of the vehicle has abandoned the same. 
(Code 1965, § 8-44; Ord. of 9-22-69) 
Chapter 20 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; garbage, trash, weeds and waste, Ch. 11; health and sanitation, Ch. 12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 16; subdivision of land, Ch. 17; franchises, App. A. 
State Law reference- Sewage disposal generally, R.S. 33:3911 et seq.; establishment of sewerage system by municipalities, R.S. 33:4001-33:4004; municipal ownership, operation, and financing of public utilities, R.S. 33:4161 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Delinquent utility accounts. 
(a)  All utility bills shall be due when rendered and if not paid by the seventeenth of the month when rendered, a delinquent penalty of ten (10) percent of the net amount due shall be added thereto. If the delinquent bill is not paid within ten (10) days from the delinquent date, it shall be the duty of the utility manager to shut off or cause to be shut off all such delinquent accounts. 
(b)  In addition, all bills will be considered delinquent after the seventeenth of the month, and a delinquent notice will be mailed out within three (3) days requesting full payment. If payment is not received by the designated time on the past due notice, utility service will be disconnected. 
(c)  All accounts shut off for nonpayment shall not be reconnected until all of the amounts due to the utility department for any utility service provided by the city has been paid plus a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(d)  Should an applicant upon requesting a final reading, or move from any premises without notifying the utility department, and fail to pay for any utility service furnished by the city shall not be reconnected to any utility service furnished by the city in the future until all amounts due the utility department have been paid in full. In addition to paying all delinquent amounts due the city, the utility manager's discretion may designate any amount that the applicant must deposit with the city to insure payment of all future bills. 
(e)  Any charges levied therein which remain unpaid for sixty (60) days past the due date shall be subject to collection through the Louisiana Municipal Advisory and Technical Services Bureau Corporation Offset Claims Program (LAMAT). Overdue charges will be offset from the individual income tax refund of the consumer. Should payment be collected through the offset claims program, a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) will be charged to the consumer, in addition to all other charges, interests and penalties collected. 
(Ord. No. 2628, 4-24-00; Ord. No. 2701, 8-27-01) 
Secs. 20-2-20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GAS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 5-116 et seq. 

Sec. 20-16. - City only, authorized to turn on service. 
    No gas from the city supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person other than an employee or some one (1) person authorized to do so by the utility department. 
(Code 1965, § 13-1) 
Sec. 20-17. - Plumbing to conform to Code. 
    No gas shall be turned on for service into any premises in which the gas piping does not comply with the ordinances of the city, provided that gas may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the rules and regulations of the utility department. 
(Code 1965, § 13-2) 
Sec. 20-18. - Application for service; connection fee. 
    Applications to have gas turned on shall be made to the utility department, and it shall be understood by the applicant that he shall abide by and accept all of the provisions of this article as conditions governing the use of the city gas supply system. Any person residing within the city limits desiring to connect to the city's gas system, after having applied, and upon approval of his application, shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) as an installation fee prior to connection thereto. All persons residing outside of the city limits being served by the city gas system shall pay a fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) as an installation fee prior to the connection thereto. Such installation fees shall be nonreturnable. 
(Code 1965, § 13-3; Ord. No. 2745, 12-9-02) 
Sec. 20-19. - Deposits required. 
(a)  A deposit of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) shall be made with each residential application. Commercial applications where the past business has an established account shall be an average of the last twelve (12) months' bill. New businesses shall be set at the discretion of the utility manager, but in no case shall the minimum deposit be less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00). The seventy-five dollar ($75.00) minimum deposit shall also apply to all businesses which shall use the average system to obtain their deposit fee, the sum to be retained by the city to insure payment of all bills, when service to the applicant is discontinued permanently, this deposit shall be refunded without interest. 
(b)  When the applicant is the owner of the premises to be served and the applicant has purchased gas from the city for a period of at least one (1) year, and has an established credit rating with the utility department, such deposit shall be waived, but this clause shall apply only to a residential application. 
(c)  When the applicant is the owner of the premises to be served and has no established credit rating with the utility department, the applicant shall be required to furnish a deposit for a period of at least one (1) year, at which time if all utility bills have been paid to the satisfaction of the utility department the deposit may be refunded at the discretion of the utility manager upon request of the applicant. 
(Code 1965, § 13-4; Ord. of 7-24-72; Ord. of 5-28-79; Ord. of 6-11-79; Ord. No. 2439, 11-17-97) 
Sec. 20-20. - Applicable service rates. 
    The rate shall be calculated on the basis of fixed operating cost (annual basis) plus cost of gas (monthly basis). The mayor and board of aldermen shall fix the per MCF charge on an annual basis based on the required revenue to operate the gas system in a safe and efficient manner in accordance with local, state and federal law. To that basis, the monthly total cost of gas from the supplier shall be added. The resultant combined rate will represent a per MCF charge for gas. 
    The minimum bill shall be seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50). The minimum bill for gas customers outside of the city limits shall be nine dollars and thirty-five cents ($9.35) per month. 
    All utility bills shall be due on the seventeenth of each month. All accounts remaining unpaid after the seventeenth of each month shall incur a delinquent penalty of ten (10) percent of the net amount due. All accounts remaining unpaid after the twenty-seventh of each month shall incur an additional delinquent penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The utility manager shall discontinue utility services to all accounts not paid by the twenty-seventh of each month. Utility services shall not be restored to disconnected utility accounts until all outstanding bills, fees and delinquent penalties have been paid. 
(Code 1965, § 13-14; Ord. of 10-14-74; Ord. of 1-9-78; Ord. of 9-28-81; Ord. No. 2414, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 2812, 2-14-05) 
Sec. 20-21. - Unlawful to connect, alter, tamper or injure system. 
    No connection with a gas main shall be made by any person other than an employee of, or any one (1) person authorized to do so by the utility department, nor shall any person alter, tamper with or injure any part of the city's gas supply system without authorization of the utility department. 
(Code 1965, § 13-5) 
Sec. 20-22. - Moving of existing meter; fees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move, relocate or tamper with any meter connected to the gas supply system, except by an employee of, or any person so authorized to do so by the utility department. 
(b)  A fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) plus all costs shall be charged for any gas meter moved or removed by the utility department, provided that the city shall move or remove any meter installed in an improper position or through an error on the city's part at no charge. In addition, any meter, which is no longer in use by the customer, shall be removed at no charge, either by request of the customer or at the discretion of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 13-6; Ord. No. 2629, 4-24-00) 
Sec. 20-23. - Resale of gas forbidden by an applicant. 
    No gas shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the city gas supply system to any premises other than that for which application has been made and the meter installed. 
(Code 1965, § 13-7) 
Sec. 20-24. - Meter to be furnished by city. 
(a)  All premises using the city gas supply system must be equipped with an adequate gas meter to be furnished by the city and installed by the city, provided that such gas service may be supplied by the city at a flat rate of charge if no meters are available. 
(b)  Multiple meter installations shall be plainly marked by a metal tag or other permanent means attached by the utility department, designating the building or the part of the building being supplied. 
(Code 1965, § 13-8) 
Sec. 20-25. - Meters must be accessible. 
    All gas meters shall be placed in an accessible position and shall not be concealed by any plant or other means. 
(Code 1965, § 13-9) 
Sec. 20-26. - Meters to be read monthly. 
    Gas meters shall be read monthly by a duly authorized employee of the utility department and bills shall be issued monthly at such times as may be directed by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Code 1965, § 13-10) 
Sec. 20-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2632, adopted April 24, 2000, deleted § 20-27 which pertained to delinquent gas bills, and derived from § 13-11 of the 1965 Code and an ordinance adopted Aug. 25, 1980. 
Sec. 20-28. - Private utility unlawful. 
    No person shall be allowed to install, maintain or use any private utility such as a butane gas system, or utilities of a like nature within the city limits. 
(Code 1965, § 13-12) 
Secs. 20-29-20-40. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - SEWAGE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 5-116 et seq. 

Sec. 20-66. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall govern the use of terms as used herein: 
    B.O.D., denoting biochemical oxygen demand shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in parts per million by weight. 
    Building drain shall mean that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet outside of the inner surface of the building wall. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the point of connection with the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Chief plumbing inspector shall mean the inspector or other person appointed by the board of aldermen to administer the provisions of this article or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Garbage shall mean solid waste from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Industrial wastes shall mean the liquid waste from industrial or other technical processes. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or ground water. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers with no particle greater than one-half inch in dimension. 
    Public sewer shall mean a sewer controlled by the city to which owners of the abutting properties may have access. In general the public sewer shall include the main sewer in the street and the service branch to the curb or property line, or a main sewer upon private property and any sewers which are connected with the sewer system of the city. 
    Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and ground water are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage shall mean a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments together with such ground surface and storm water as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant shall mean any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage works shall mean all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain shall mean a sewer which carries storm and surface water and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial waste. 
    Suspended solids shall mean solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Watercourse shall mean a channel in which a flow of water occurs either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1965, § 13-41) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-67. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in an unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city, or any area under the jurisdiction of the city or into any sewer which connects to the sewage system of the city any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city or into any sewer which connects to the sewage system of the city any sanitary sewage, industrial waste or other polluted water, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 13-42) 
Sec. 20-68. - Unlawful to construct, maintain privy, privy vault, etc. 
    Except as hereinafter provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain, any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for disposal of sewage. 
(Code 1965, § 13-43) 
Sec. 20-69. - Owners must connect to public sewer. 
    The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the city, is hereby required at his own expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within ninety (90) days of official notice to do so. 
(Code 1965, § 13-44) 
Sec. 20-70. - Old plumbing and building sewers. 
    All plumbing and building sewers heretofore installed shall be treated as new work. Before connecting to the public sewers an application shall be filed and an inspection made as required for new works, such portions being uncovered or removed as may be necessary for this purpose and the cost thereof being borne by the owner. Reasonable discretion shall be exercised in passing minor defects in old plumbing, however, building sewers must meet the following minimum conditions: 
(1)  Sewer pipes must be of approved material in good condition and not smaller than four (4) inches nominal size. 
(2)  Joints must be of approved material and properly installed. 
(3)  The pipe must be laid straight and to a minimum slope of one-eighth inch per foot. 
(Code 1965, § 13-45) 
Sec. 20-71. - Private sewage disposal. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 20-69, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system the owner shall first obtain written permit signed by the chief plumbing inspector after approval by the city and the parish health department. The application for each permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the chief plumbing inspector. 
(c)  A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the chief plumbing inspector, and the city and the parish health department. They shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction, and in any event the applicant for the permit shall notify the chief plumbing inspector when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within forty-eight (48) hours of the receipt of notice by the chief plumbing inspector, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excepted. 
(d)  The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all regulations of the city, and the parish health department. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than ten thousand five hundred (10,500) square feet. 
(Code 1965, § 13-46) 
Sec. 20-72. - Connection to public sewer when available. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewer disposal system, as provided in section 20-71, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(Code 1965, § 13-47) 
Sec. 20-73. - Private sewer disposal to be operated in sanitary manner. 
(a)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(b)  No statement contained in this article shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the city or the parish health department. 
(Code 1965, § 13-48) 
Sec. 20-74. - Building sewer connections. 
(a)  No person shall uncover, make any connection with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the chief plumbing inspector. 
(b)  There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service; and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
(c)  In either case, the owner or his agent, shall make applications on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the chief plumbing inspector. 
(d)  All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(e)  An inspection fee of five dollars ($5.00) and a connection fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid by the applicant for a permit to connect to the sewer system of the city, or to the sewer system of sewerage district no. 1, of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 13-49) 
Sec. 20-75. - Building sewer must be provided for each building. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one (1) building sewer. 
(Code 1965, § 13-50) 
Sec. 20-76. - Uses limited for old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the chief plumbing inspector, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 13-51) 
Sec. 20-77. - Building sewer specifications. 
(a)  The building sewer shall be vitrified clay sewer pipe, ASTM C-13, latest revision, or cast-iron soil pipe, ASTM-A-74, latest revision and approved joints shall be tight and waterproof. 
(b)  The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the chief plumbing inspector. In general, the building sewer shall be the same size as the service branch but in no event less than four (4) inches in diameter. The slope of the building sewer shall in no event be less than one-eighth inch per foot. 
(c)  Whenever possible the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be had parallel to within three (3) feet of any bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment in so far as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. 
(d)  In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(e)  All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the chief plumbing inspector. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specifications, C-12, latest revision, except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. 
(f)  All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Cast-iron pipe joints shall be firmly packed with oakum or hemp and filled with molten lead, federal specification AZ-1-156, not less than one (1) inch in depth. Lead shall be run in one (1) pouring and caulked tight. No paint, varnish or other coatings shall be permitted on the jointing material until after the joint has been tested and approved. All joints in vitrified clay pipe or between VC pipe and cast-iron pipe shall be made with an approved bituminous jointing material or a polyvinyl chloride compression joint meeting National Clay Pipe Manufacturer, Inc., specifications. Where a hot poured joint is used, the joint shall first be caulked with jute, hemp or similar approved material. The bituminous material for hot poured joints shall not soften sufficiently to destroy the effectiveness of the joint when subjected to a temperature of one hundred sixty (160) degrees Fahrenheit nor be soluble in any of the wastes carried by the drainage system. 
(g)  The building sewer shall be connected into the public sewer at the curb or property line, if a service branch is available at a suitable location. Where no properly located service branch is available, a neat hole may be cut into the main line of the public sewer and a suitable wye or tee saddle installed to receive the building sewer. The invert of the building sewer at such joint of connection with a wye saddle shall be in the upper quadrant of the main line of the public sewer. A neat workmanlike connection shall be made and the saddle made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. 
(Code 1965, § 13-52) 
Sec. 20-78. - Notification of inspection. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the chief plumbing inspector when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the chief plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 13-53) 
Sec. 20-79. - Excavations for building sewers. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard on streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1965, § 13-54) 
Sec. 20-80. - Use of public sewers limited. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface water, ground water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process water to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the public works manager. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process water may be discharged, upon approval of the public works manager, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(c)  Except as hereinafter provided no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described water or waste to any public sewer: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit; 
(2)  Any water or waste which may contain more than one hundred (100) parts per million by weight of fat, oil or grease; 
(3)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
(4)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded; 
(5)  Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, or any solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interferences with the proper operation of the sewage works; 
(6)  Any water or waste having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works; 
(7)  Any water or waste containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitutes a hazard to humans or animals, or creates hazards in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant; 
(8)  Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such a character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at a sewage treatment plant; 
(9)  Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance. 
(d)  Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the chief plumbing inspector, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients, except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the chief plumbing inspector, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(e)  Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperatures. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers, which, when bolted in place, shall be gastight and watertight. 
(f)  When installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(1)  Owners shall have the interceptors pumped and cleaned as often as necessary and a minimum of once each calendar year. 
(2)  Owners shall properly manifest all waste generated by this maintenance on a manifest provided by the City of Gonzales, which shall specify the generator, transporter, and legally authorized disposal facility. A copy of the manifest shall be submitted to the City of Gonzales within thirty (30) days of the maintenance event. 
(3)  All manifest and receipts evidencing maintenance shall be maintained by the owner for a period of three (3) years and made available for inspection by the City of Gonzales upon request. 
(g)  The admission into the public sewers of any water or waste having: 
(1)  A five (5) day biochemical oxygen demand greater than three hundred (300) parts per million by weight; or 
(2)  Containing more than three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight of suspended solids; or 
(3)  Containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in the above sections; or 
(4)  Having an average daily flow greater than two (2) percent of the average daily sewage flow of the city; 
shall be subject to the review and approval of the chief plumbing inspector. 
(h)  Where necessary, in the opinion of the chief plumbing inspector, the owner shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: 
(1)  Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to three hundred (300) parts per million and the suspended solids to three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight; or 
(2)  Reduce the objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in the above sections; or 
(3)  Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such water or waste. 
(i)  Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the chief plumbing inspector, the city, and the parish health department and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until such approvals are obtained in writing. 
(Code 1965, § 13-55; Ord. No. 2719, 2-11-02) 
Sec. 20-81. - Industrial waste specifications, survey data required. 
(a)  All users of the sewage system who discharge industrial wastes to the public sewers, shall fill in and file with the chief plumbing inspector an industrial waste questionnaire which shall furnish pertinent data, inclusive of quantity of flow and an analysis of the water discharged to the sewage works. 
(b)  When required by the chief plumbing inspector, the owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with the plans approved by the chief plumbing inspector. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(c)  All measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of water and waste to which reference is made in section 20-80 shall be determined in accordance with "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage" latest edition, and shall be determined at the control manhole as provided for above or, upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. 
(d)  No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to the payment thereof by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1965, § 13-56) 
Sec. 20-82. - Protection for damage. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the municipal sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under the charge of criminal damage to public property. 
(Code 1965, § 13-57; Ord. of 10-8-79) 
Sec. 20-83. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
    The chief plumbing inspector and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 13-58) 
Sec. 20-84. - Service rates. 
    All property upon which any building has been or may hereafter be erected having a connection with any sewer main or pipe which may be now present or hereafter constructed and used in connection with the city sewer system and/or sewerage district no. 1 of the city shall pay the following rates: 
(1)  All buildings billed for water usage. All residential buildings billed for water usage, shall pay a minimum sewer charge of five dollars and fifty one cents ($5.51), and thereafter pay a sewer use charge of one dollar and forty seven cents ($1.47) per thousand (1,000) gallons for each one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used. All buildings, including, but not limited to commercial establishments, small office buildings, churches, schools, industries and auditoriums shall pay a minimum sewer charge of ten dollars and fifty one cents ($10.51), and thereafter pay a sewer use charge of one dollar and forty seven cents ($1.47) per thousand (1,000) gallons for each one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used. 
(2)  All buildings not billed for water usage by the city. All buildings, including, but not limited to, single-and multiple-family dwellings, commercial establishments, and auditoriums, not billed for water usage, shall pay a sewer use charge as follows: for the plumbing fixtures listed below, three dollars and sixty eight cents ($3.68) for each of the first three (3) plumbing fixtures, one dollar and fifteen cents ($1.15) for each of the next six (6) plumbing fixtures, plus fifty eight cents ($0.58) for each additional plumbing fixture over nine (9): 
One (1) commode. 
One (1) lavatory. 
One (1) bathtub with or without shower head. 
One (1) shower stall without bathtub. 
One (1) urinal. 
(3)  Industrial wastes. Industrial wastes shall be accepted by special agreement only and charges shall be determined on each individual case, provided that such industrial waste does not injure the sewer system. 
(4)  Sewer service rates will be adjusted annually to reflect inflation as established by the U.S. Department of Labor Consumer Price Index. 
(Code 1965, § 13-60; Ord. of 6-13-83; Ord. No. 1810, 5-12-86; Ord. No. 2024, 2-12-90; Ord. No. 2125, 5-28-91; Ord. No. 2202, 7-27-92; Ord. No. 2310, 6-27-94; Ord. No. 2759, 5-27-03) 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, the fees were adjusted for inflation on June 1, 2005. 
Sec. 20-85. - Sewer service rate bills. 
    All bills for sewer service rates shall be billed in accordance with the policies set forth for gas and water service rates. 
(Code 1965, § 13-61) 
Sec. 20-86. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2632, adopted Apr. 24, 2000, deleted § 20-86 which pertained to delinquent sewer bills, and derived from Ord. No. 1828, adopted Feb. 23, 1987. 
Secs. 20-87-20-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STORM SEWERS AND DRAINS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 5-116 et seq. 

Sec. 20-101. - Permit required. 
(a)  Prior to the installation of any storm sewers or drains by any person other than an employee of the city, a permit for such work must be secured from the public works manager. 
(b)  Applicants for a storm sewer or drain permit shall furnish in writing on form furnished by city, any and all information necessary and requested by the public works manager to insure the proper flow of surface drainage. 
(c)  There shall be no fee for the storm sewer or drain permit. 
(Code 1965, §§ 14-1, 14-2, 14-4) 
Sec. 20-102. - Work to be performed under the supervision of the public works manager. 
    All necessary work in the installation of storm sewers or drains shall be at the expense of the property owner, and all work shall be under the direct supervision of the public works manager. The property owner in addition to bearing the expense of all necessary work shall pay for all necessary materials for the installation of storm sewers or drains and catch basins. The public works manager shall furnish the property owner the necessary grade for the assurance of the proper now of surface drainage. No such work shall be accepted which shall in any way be detrimental to the overall drainage of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 14-3) 
Secs. 20-103-20-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WASTEWATER FACILITIES IMPACT FEE 

Sec. 20-120. - Findings. 
    The city council finds, determines and declares that: 
(1)  The city must maintain and expand its wastewater facilities in order to maintain current standards of public health if new development is to be accommodated without decreasing current standards of public health. 
(2)  The imposition of impact fees is one of the preferred methods of ensuring that development bears a proportionate share of the cost of wastewater facilities necessary to accommodate such development. This must be done in order to promote and protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(3)  Connecting to the city wastewater system will create a need for the construction, equipping, or expansion of the wastewater facilities. 
(4)  The fees established in section 20-125 are derived from, are based upon, and provide for the costs of providing additional wastewater facilities necessitated by connections to the city sewerage system. 
(Ord. No. 3024, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 20-121. - Intents and purposes. 
    The purpose of this article is to regulate the use and development of land so as to assure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of capital expenditures necessary to provide wastewater facilities by the city. 
(Ord. No. 3024, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 20-122. - Rules of construction. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  For the purposes of administration and enforcement, unless otherwise stated in this article, the following rules of construction shall apply: 
(1)  In the case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this article and any caption, illustration, summary table, or illustrative table, the text shall control. 
(2)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary; the word "may" is permissive. 
(3)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular number shall include the plural, and the plural the singular, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary. 
(4)  The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for," "designed for," "maintained for," or "occupied for." 
(5)  The word "person" includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association, or any other similar entity. 
(6)  The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character. 
(7)  "City" means the City of Gonzales. 
(8)  "City engineer" means a civil engineer licensed to practice in the State of Louisiana, employed by, or contracted for, the city and charged with making engineering recommendations to the government. 
(Ord. No. 3024, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 20-123. - Definitions. 
    Capital equipment means equipment with an expected use life of five (5) years or more. 
    Commercial includes any unit or structure as defined in the Gonzales Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 22). 
    Connection to wastewater system means the physical connection of a building, structure, or developed land or lots to the city's wastewater lines, no matter if such connection is made through or by intermediate lines. 
    Feepayer means one who is required to pay a wastewater facility impact fee by this article. 
    Residential includes single-family or multifamily housing units as defined in the Gonzales Zoning Ordinance (Chapter 22). 
    Site-related facility means an improvement or facility which is for the primary use and benefit of a new development and/or which is for the primary purpose of safe and adequate provisions of wastewater facilities to serve the new development and for which the developer or property owner is solely responsible under subdivision ordinances and other applicable regulations. 
    Wastewater facilities means those facilities within the wastewater collection, transmission and treatment system already in place that may need to be improved to provide capacity for proposed land developments and shall include trunk sewer lines, pumping stations, and major wastewater treatment facilities that are part of the city wastewater system. 
(Ord. No. 3024, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 20-124. - Imposition of wastewater facilities impact fee. 
    After the effective date of the ordinance codified in this article, any person in either the incorporated or unincorporated areas served by the city's wastewater system who: 
(1)  Has subdivision improvements which are to be connected to the wastewater system and are accepted for maintenance by the city; 
(2)  Connects to the wastewater system; or 
(3)  Changes, modifies or expands the use of an existing connection to the wastewater system is hereby required to pay a wastewater facilities impact fee in the manner and amount set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3024, 10-28-13) 
Sec. 20-125. - Computation of the wastewater facilities impact fee. 
(a)  The amount of the wastewater facilities impact fee shall be determined by the following fee schedule:
