    Rubbish [means] nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans, grass and shrubbery clippings, wood, glass, brick, plaster, bedding, crockery, and similar materials and stripped motor. 
    Safety [means] the condition of being reasonably free from danger and hazards which may cause accidents or disease. 
    Substandard dwelling [means] any dwelling which does not conform to the minimum standards established by the City Code. 
    Supplied [means] paid for, furnished by, provided by or under the control of the owner, operator, or agent of a dwelling. 
    Meaning of certain words-whenever the words "dwelling" "dwelling unit," "premises," or "structure" are used in this section, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words "or any part thereof." 
(Ord. No. 2642, 6-26-00) 
Sec. 24-4. - License required. 
    The following requirements shall apply to licenses: 
(1)  No person shall rent any building or mobile home to any person for dwelling purposes without obtaining an annual occupational license and paying the fee required by section 18-16, et seq. of this Code. 
(2)  Applications shall be made to the city clerk, on forms supplied by the clerk. Each applicant shall provide the name and address of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation or limited liability company, the application shall name the principal officers of the corporation or the members of the members of the limited liability company and the registered agent for service of process for the corporation or limited liability company. If the applicant is a partnership, the application shall name the individual partners. The principal officers, the members and the individual partners shall be personally responsible for complying with this chapter. The applicant shall provide the address and apartment number, if any, of each dwelling unit on the application. 
(Ord. No. 2642, 6-26-00) 
Sec. 24-5. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  Whenever the building inspector determines that any premises or dwelling unit fails to meet the requirements set forth in this chapter, he shall issue a notice setting forth the alleged violations of this chapter. This notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Set forth the alleged violation of this chapter. 
(3)  Describe the dwelling or dwelling unit where the violations are alleged to exist or to have been committed. 
(4)  Provide a reasonable time, generally not to exceed sixty (60) days, for corrections to be made. 
(5)  Be served by registered or certified mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the owner at the address shown on his application for occupational license. 
(6)  In the case of grave public emergency, where the condition of the dwelling is such as to cause possible immediate loss or damage to person or property, the building inspector need not provide the notice described herein, but can immediately notify the governing authority of such condition and the governing authority may proceed as outlined in section 24-7 of this chapter. 
(b)  At the end of the period of time allowed for compliance, the building inspector shall re-inspect the premises or dwelling unit described in the notice and if he determines that conditions have not been corrected, he shall issue a written report recommending the revocation of the owner's occupational license required by this chapter. The mayor shall thereupon serve notice on the owner of the dwelling as listed on the application for occupational license requiring him to show cause at a meeting of the governing authority, regular or special, why his occupational license for rental dwellings should not be revoked. The date and hour of the meeting shall be stated in the notice which shall be served at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing. The notice may be served by registered or certified mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the owner at his last known address. The notice may also be served by the marshal of the municipality or by any sheriff, deputy sheriff, police, or constable having jurisdiction or power to serve legal process where the owner of the building or structure is found. 
(c)  After the hearing, if, in the opinion of the city council, the facts justify it, an order shall be entered revoking the rental dwelling occupational license of the owner. Upon good cause shown, the council may grant the owners additional time to bring the dwelling into compliance with this chapter, but in such case, the general nature of the work to be performed, the time thereof, and the defects to be corrected shall be specified in the decision of the city council. If, in the opinion of the city council, the dwelling still does not comply with the requirements of this chapter at the end of the period specified in the decision, the city council may revoke the rental dwelling occupational license of the owner. 
(d)  Once the rental dwelling occupational license is revoked, it shall be illegal for the owner to rent or lease any dwellings covered by his occupational license. 
(e)  If an owner's rental dwelling occupational license has been revoked, he may reapply for a license upon submitting the following: 
(1)  An application accompanied by the proper application fee. 
(2)  Payment of an inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per rental dwelling covered by the application. 
(3)  Written report from the building inspector stating that all dwelling units are in compliance with the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2642, 6-26-00) 
Sec. 24-6. - Repairs and other corrective action. 
    Whenever a grave public emergency, where the condition of the rental unit is such as to cause possible immediate loss or damage to person or property exists or when an owner of any premises or dwelling unit fails, neglects, or refuses to make repairs or take other corrective action as required by this chapter, and the delay for making those repairs or taking corrective action specified in the building inspector's notice has passed and the dwelling is in a dilapidated and dangerous condition which endangers the public welfare, the governing authority may proceed in accordance with the law relating to demolishing dilapidated or dangerous buildings. 
(Ord. No. 2642, 6-26-00) 
Sec. 24-7. - General requirements. 
    No owner or other person shall occupy or let to another person any rental dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit unless it and the premises are clean, sanitary, fit for human occupancy, and comply with all applicable legal requirements of the state and the city, including the following requirements: 
(1)  Maintenance of shared or public areas. Every owner of a multiple family dwelling or dwellings shall maintain in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or public areas of the dwelling and premises thereof. 
(2)  Maintenance of yards. Every owner is responsible for ensuring that each dwelling unit owned by him complies with the provisions of chapter 11, articles II and III with the provision that maximum height of grass not exceed six (6) inches. 
(3)  Pest extermination. Every owner of a rental dwelling or dwelling unit shall be responsible for the extermination of vermin and rodents on the premises. No owner or occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall accumulate fire wood, rubbish, boxes, lumber, scrap metal or any other materials in such manner that may provide a rodent harborage in or about any dwelling or dwelling unit. No owner or occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall store, place or allow to accumulate any material that may serve as food for rodents in a site accessible to rodents. 
(4)  Minimum exterior lighting. The owner of a multiple-family dwelling or dwellings shall be responsible for providing and maintaining effective illumination in all exterior parking lots and driveways and walkways. 
(5)  Minimum standards for basic equipment and facilities. No person shall let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking or eating therein, which does not comply with the following requirements: 
a.  Every dwelling unit shall have a space in which food may be prepared and cooked, which shall have adequate circulation area and which shall be equipped with the following: 
1.  A kitchen sink in good working condition, connected to an approved water supply including hot and cold water and also connected to an approved sewer system. 
2.  Cabinets or shelves, for the storage of eating, drinking and cooking equipment and utensils. 
3.  Stove, or similar device for cooking food and a refrigerator, or similar device, for the safe storage of food at temperatures less than fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit but more than thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit under ordinary maximum summer conditions. 
(6)  Toilet facilities. Within every dwelling unit there shall be a room which affords privacy to anyone within said room and which is supplied with a flush toilet in good working condition, connected to an approved water and sewer system. 
(7)  Lavatory sink. Within every dwelling there shall be a lavatory sink; said sink may be in the same room with the flush toilet or if located in another room, the sink shall be placed in close proximity to the door leading directly into the room containing the flush toilet; said lavatory sink shall be connected to an approved water system with both hot and cold water and also connected to an approved sewer system. 
(8)  Bathtub or shower. Within every dwelling unit there shall be a room which affords privacy to a person within said room and which is equipped with a bathtub or shower in good working condition. Said tub or shower can be in the same room with the flush toilet or in another room, shall be properly connected to an approved water system with hot and cold water and connected to an approved sewer system. 
(9)  Egress. Every dwelling unit in a one (1) or two (2) story building shall have at least one (1) means of egress leading to a safe and open space at ground level. Every dwelling unit in any other building shall have immediate access to two (2) or more means of egress leading to a safe and open space at ground level. 
(10)  Handrails. Structurally sound handrails shall be provided on any steps containing four risers or more. If steps are not enclosed, handrails with vertical posts spaced no greater than six (6) inches apart shall be provided. Porches, decks and balconies located more than thirty (30) inches from ground level or floor below shall have approved handrails thirty (30) to thirty-four (34) inches high. Stairs, balconies and porches exceeding thirty (30) inches from ground level or lower floor, shall have a protective railing thirty-six (36) inches in height, and if unenclosed, vertical posts shall be spaced no greater than six (6) inches apart. Alternate systems providing at least the same degree of protection shall be acceptable if approved the building inspector. 
(11)  Access. Access to or egress from each dwelling unit shall be provided without passing through any other dwelling or dwelling unit. 
(12)  Door locks. No owner shall occupy or let to be occupied any dwelling or dwelling unit unless all exterior doors of the dwelling or dwelling unit are equipped with safe, functioning lock devices. 
(13)  Habitable room ventilation. Except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the building inspector, every habitable room shall have at least one (1) window facing directly outdoors which can be opened easily. 
(14)  Other room ventilation. Every bathroom and water closet compartment, and every laundry and utility room shall have at least fifty (50) percent of the ventilation required in habitable rooms, except that no window shall be required if said rooms are equipped with a ventilation system providing at least equal ventilation. 
(15)  Electric service, outlets and fixtures. Every dwelling unit and all public and common areas shall be supplied with electric service, over-current protection devices, electric outlets, and electric fixtures which are properly installed, which shall be maintained in safe working condition, and shall be energized by an approved source of electric power and in compliance with the applicable ordinances of the city and state. 
(16)  Minimal thermal standards. No person shall let to another for occupancy, any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living therein, which does not have heating facilities which are properly installed, and which are maintained in safe condition, and which are capable of adequately heating all habitable rooms in every dwelling unit at a temperature of at least sixty-eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit at a distance of three (3) feet above floor level and three (3) feet from any exterior wall at any outside temperature of twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit. Gas or electric appliances previously designed for cooking or water heating purposes, shall not be considered as heating facilities under this section. Portable heating equipment using flame and liquid fuel does not meet the requirements of this section and is prohibited. No owner or occupant shall operate or use any space heater or wood burning stove or fireplace that does not comply with all applicable city ordinances. 
(17)  Minimal cooling standards. No person shall let to another for occupancy, any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living therein, which does not have either a central air conditioning unit and/or window air conditioning unit(s) which are properly installed, and which are maintained in a safe condition, and which are capable of adequately cooling all habitable rooms in every dwelling unit at a temperature of at least eighty (80) degrees Fahrenheit at a distance of three (3) feet above floor level and three (3) feet from any exterior wall at any outside temperature of ninety-five (95) degrees. 
(18)  Exterior foundations, exterior walls and roofs. The foundation, exterior walls and exterior roof shall be substantially water tight and protected against vermin and rodents and shall be kept in sound condition and repair. The foundation shall adequately support the building at all points. Every exterior wall shall be free of deterioration holes, breaks, loose or rotting boards or timbers and any other thing that might admit rain or dampness to the interior portion of the walls. The roof shall be tight and have no defects which might admit rain. Roof drainage shall be adequate to prevent rain water from causing dampness to interior walls. All exterior wood surfaces, other than decay resistant woods, shall be protected from the elements and decay, by paint or other protective coverings or treatment. If twenty-five (25) percent or more of the exterior surface of such a wood structure is unpainted or unprotected or is determined by the building inspector to be paint blistered and in need of protection, it shall be painted or protected. 
(19)  Windows, doors, screens. Every window and exterior door shall be substantially tight and shall be kept in sound condition and repair. Every window other than a fixed window shall be capable of being easily opened. Every window, door and frame shall be constructed and maintained in such relation to the adjacent wall as to completely exclude rain, wind, vermin and rodents from entering the building. Every window or other devices with openings to the outside which are used or intended to be used for ventilation shall be supplied with mesh screen during the insect season. 
(20)  Floors, interior walls, ceilings. Every floor, interior wall and ceiling shall be adequately protected against the passage and harborage of vermin and rodents, and shall be kept in sound condition and good repair. Every floor shall be free of loose, warped, protruding or rotted flooring materials. Every interior wall and ceiling shall be free of holes, large cracks and loose plaster and shall be maintained in a tight weatherproof condition. Paints or materials that remain toxic after being applied and after drying or hardening, shall not be used. Every toilet room and bathroom floor surface shall be capable of being easily maintained in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(21)  Rodent-proof. Every dwelling and accessory structure and the premises upon which it is located shall be maintained in a rodent-free and rodent-proof condition. All openings in the exterior walls, foundation, basement, ground or first floors, and roofs shall be rodent-proofed. 
(22)  Safe buildings. Every foundation, roof, floor, exterior wall, interior wall, ceiling inside and outside stairways, every porch, balcony and every appurtenance thereto, shall be safe to use and capable of supporting loads that may be anticipated to be placed on them in normal use. 
(23)  Facilities to function. Every supplied facility and every piece of equipment or utility and every chimney and flue shall be installed and shall be maintained so that it functions effectively in a safe and working condition. 
(Ord. No. 2642, 6-26-00) 
Sec. 24-8. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 2642, 6-26-00) 
Sec. 24-9. - Nuisance, injunction. 
    Any violation of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance. In addition to any other relief provided by this chapter, the city attorney may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any violation of this ordinance. Such application for relief may include seeking a temporary restraining order, temporary injunction or permanent injunction. 
(Ord. No. 2642, 6-26-00) 
Chapter 25 - SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS 

Sec. 25-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, a glossary of pertinent words and phrases found in this chapter shall be placed on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-2. - Construction standards and sign requirements-All signs. 
(a)  Compliance with building code. All new signs shall comply with the most recent approved Louisiana State Uniform Code Council IBC International Building Code. 
(b)  Sign height. No sign shall exceed the height of twenty-five (25) feet, with the exception of those signs located: 
(1)  Along Interstate 10 as permitted per federal regulations; 
(2)  Along Highway 61; 
(3)  Along Highway 30, west of Highway 44, to the city limits; and 
(4)  Along Highway 44, south of Highway 30, to the city limits. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  Wind pressure and dead load requirements. All signs and billboards that are constructed to more than thirty-two (32) square feet in area and with a height greater than ten (10) feet shall be designed and constructed to withstand a wind speed greater than one hundred eleven (111) miles per hour by an approved Louisiana licensed engineer. 
(e)  Materials specifications. Permitted signs shall be constructed only of the following materials: 
(1)  Incombustible materials. Corrosion resistant metal or other incombustible materials. 
(2)  Fiberboard. Highly compressed fiberboard which weighs not less than sixty (60) pounds per cubic foot and is not less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch in thickness. 
(3)  Plywood. Exterior grade plywood not less than three-eighths ( 3/8 ) inch in thickness and bearing the stamp of an approved testing agency. 
(4)  Approved plastics. Of a thickness and shape necessary to withstand the loadings specified in this sign code. Proper allowance or provision shall be made in connection to provide for thermal contraction and expansion. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this code, plastic materials which burn at a rate no faster than two and one-half (21/2) inches per minute when tested in accordance with American Standard of Testing Material D 635 shall be deemed approved plastics and may be used as the display surface material and for the letters, decorations and facings on signs. 
(5)  Glass. When glass is used for sign letters or transparent or translucent panes, it shall be at least double strength thickness for sign areas up to and including three hundred (300) square inches. When glass is used for sign letters or transparent or translucent panels for sign areas in excess of three hundred (300) square inches at least one-quarter (1/4) inch wire glass shall be used and maximum span between supports shall be four (4) feet. 
(6)  Wood structure. The framework or standards upon which the sign rests may be of wood. Any wooden portion of such structure in contact with the ground shall be either of redwood or any other wood which is a commercially available wood treated with an approved preservative. Sign supports may be no more than two (2) in number and shall be of sufficient strength and foundation to preclude the need for visible cross-bracing. 
(7)  Metal structure. All signs of one hundred fifty (150) square feet or over shall be of metal construction and shall have no more than two (2) structural supports. 
(f)  Surfaces of signs. All signs or billboards shall have a smooth surface, and no nails, tacks, or wires shall be permitted to protrude therefrom, except electrical reflectors and devices which may extend over the top and in front of the advertising structures. 
(g)  Movable parts. Any movable part of any sign or billboard shall be securely fastened by chains or hinges. 
(h)  Reflectors. If, pursuant to this chapter, a sign can be illuminated, the reflectors shall be provided with proper glass lenses concentrating the illumination upon the area of the sign so as to prevent glare upon the street or adjacent property, and all electrical components of the lights shall be properly covered to prevent persons or things from coming into contact with any electrical component of the sign. 
(i)  Internal illumination. The illumination of signs or billboards in which the light source is concealed or contained within the structure itself and which becomes visible in darkness by shining through translucent surface shall not exceed sixteen (16) foot candles of incident light measured at a distance of ten (10) feet from such structure. 
(j)  Flood light illumination. Signs or billboards illuminated by flood lights or spot lights shall be positioned in such a manner that none of the light spills over onto an adjoining property or glares or shines into the eyes of motorists or pedestrians. 
(k)  Erection standards and design requirements. Before any permit required by this chapter shall be granted, the applicant shall submit to the city building inspector a design and stress diagram or plans and elevations containing the necessary information to enable the city building inspector to determine that such sign complies with the regulations of this code. When necessary to make such a determination, the city building inspector may require engineering data certified and signed by a Louisiana registered structural engineer. 
(l)  Strength of parapet or wall. A parapet wall must be designed to have sufficient strength to support any sign which is attached thereto. 
(m)  Supports and braces. Supports or braces shall be of metal and shall be adequate for wind loadings specified in subsection 2(c). All metal, wire cable support and braces and all bolts used to attach signs to brackets, or brackets and signs to the supporting building or structure, shall be of galvanized steel or other equivalent material. All sign support shall be an integral part of the sign design. 
(n)  Sign anchoring. Signs shall be anchored to prevent any lateral movement that would cause wear on supporting members or connections. All ground signs shall be securely built, constructed and erected upon posts and standards sunk at least three (3) feet below the natural surface of the ground, and supported and braced by timbers or metal rods in the rear thereof, extending from the top thereof to a point in the ground at least a distance equal to one-half (1/2) the height of such sign, measured along the ground, from the post or standards upon which the same is erected. All wooden post, anchors and bracings used shall be treated to protect them from moisture by creosoting or other approved methods. 
(o)  Working stresses. In all signs, the allowable workable stresses shall conform with the requirements of the Standard Building Code (SBCCI). 
(1)  The allowable working stresses for steel and wood shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Standard Building Code (SBCCI). 
(2)  The working strength of chains, cables, guys or steel rods shall not exceed one-fifth ( 1/5 ) of the ultimate strength of such chains, cables, guys or steel rods. 
(p)  Posting on trees, poles, etc. No sign shall be allowed to be tacked, painted, posted, marked, or otherwise affixed on trees, utility poles, or other similar structures, or on rocks, the ground itself, or other natural features. 
(q)  Maintenance of signs and premises. 
(1)  Sign maintenance. Each sign which has been erected in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be maintained in substantially the same condition as when the final inspection was made and the sign inspection sticker was issued. Failure to maintain the sign, including exterior painting, shall constitute a violation of this chapter. The city building inspector may, after notice to the owner and a hearing before the Gonzales City Council, order the removal of any sign that is not maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section. Such removal shall be at the expense of the owner or lessee. 
(2)  Premises maintenance. All free standing signs and the premises surrounding them shall be maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish and weeds. 
(r)  Removal of certain on-premises signs. Any sign now or hereafter existing which no longer advertises a bona fide business or product shall be taken down and removed by the owner, agent, or person having the beneficial use of the building, structure, or property upon which such sign may be found within ninety (90) days after written notification by certified mail is made by the city building inspector. If the person so notified fails to remove said sign, such sign may be removed by the city building inspector at the expense of the owner of the property upon which it is located. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03; Ord. No. 2804, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 2965, 1-10-11) 
Sec. 25-3. - Auxiliary specifications. 
(a)  Obstruction to exits. No sign shall be erected so as to obstruct any fire escape, required exit, window or door opening intended as a means of egress. 
(b)  Obstruction of ventilation. No sign shall be erected which interferes with any opening required for ventilation. 
(c)  Clearance from electrical power lines and communication lines. Signs shall maintain all clearances from electrical conductors in accordance with the National Electric Code and all communications equipment or lines located within the city. 
(d)  Clearance from surface and underground facilities. Signs and their supporting structures shall maintain clearance and non-interference with all surface and underground facilities and conduits for water, sewerage, gas, electricity, or communications equipment or lines. Furthermore, placement shall not interfere with natural or artificial drainage of surface or underground water. 
(e)  Clearance of projecting signs. Signs projecting from a building or extending over public property shall maintain a clear height of eight (8) feet above the sidewalk and all signs shall be at least eighteen (18) inches from the curb line as measured toward the building. 
(f)  Signs at intersections. Free standing signs shall not restrict or impair visibility at the intersection of the right-of-way lines of two (2) streets or of the street and a railroad. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-4. - Electrical sign regulations. 
(a)  Electrical code. All electrical signs shall be built and installed in compliance with the National Electric Code and the Southern Building Code. All electrical wiring to signs shall be permanently installed and placed underground in approved conduits in accordance with the National Electric Code. 
(b)  Licensing. Electrical signs may only be wired by an electrician licensed or permitted by the City of Gonzales. 
(c)  Electrical sign permit. The following shall be required prior to the issuance of an electrical permit in conjunction with the erection of an electrical sign: 
(1)  Wiring schematic or plan for electrical service to the sign fully describing the electrical work to be done. 
(2)  Compliance with U.L. standards for electrical work to be done. 
(d)  Electrical inspection. An electrical inspection shall be required in conjunction with the erection of an electrical sign. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-5. - Unsafe and unlawful signs. 
    If the city building inspector shall find any sign or other advertising structure regulated herein as unsafe or insecure, is a menace to the public, is abandoned or in a dilapidated condition, or has been constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this article, he shall give written notice to the permittee or owner thereof or, if he is unable to identify such persons, to the owner of the property on which the sign is located. If the person so notified fails to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the provisions of this sign code, such sign may be removed or altered by the city building inspector at the expense of the permittee, sign owner or owner of the property upon which it is located. The city building inspector shall refuse to issue a permit to any permittee or owner who refuses to pay costs so assessed. The city building inspector may cause any sign which is an immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily without notice. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-6. - Signs permitted in residential zones. 
(a)  Construction project signs. One (1) non-illuminated construction sign may be permitted within residential zones subject to the following conditions and requirements: 
(1)  Such sign must not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in sign area. 
(2)  Only one (1) sign is permitted for each street frontage. 
(3)  The location of such sign shall be in strict conformance with all applicable set back requirements and other laws and ordinances of the city. 
(4)  Signs may not be erected more than sixty (60) days prior to construction and must be removed within a period of not more than ten (10) days after the completion of the project. 
(b)  Temporary real estate signs, banners and flags. Temporary real estate signs, banners and flags are permitted within residential zones providing they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  One (1) non-illuminated real estate sign permitted per street frontage. 
(2)  No sign shall exceed nine (9) square feet in sign area. 
(3)  Temporary banners and flags are only permitted to mark an open house and shall be removed immediately upon the closing of the open house viewing period. 
(c)  Political signs. Political signs are allowed within residential zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  Political signs shall not be illuminated. 
(2)  One (1) sign per political candidate or public or political issue or cause is permitted per street frontage. 
(3)  Signs shall not exceed nine (9) square feet in sign area. 
(d)  Not-for-profit signs. Not-for-profit signs are allowed within residential zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  Not-for-profit signs shall not be illuminated. 
(2)  One (1) sign is permitted per street frontage. 
(3)  Signs shall not exceed nine (9) square feet in sign area. 
(4)  Signs shall not be erected more than thirty (30) days prior to the event and shall be removed within three (3) days following the event. Upon the failure to timely remove such signs, the city may thereafter remove and dispose of any remaining signs at the expense of the organization advertising the event. 
(5)  Not-for-profit signs shall not be erected or displayed in any public right-of-way. 
(e)  Temporary yard or garage sale signs. Temporary yard or garage sale signs are permitted in residential zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  One (1) non-illuminated sign is permitted per street frontage. 
(2)  Each sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in sign area. 
(3)  Signs shall not be erected more than seven (7) days prior to the sale and shall be removed within three (3) days following the sale. 
(4)  Three (3) additional yard or garage sale signs may be placed off-premises on private property with permission of the property owner. 
(f)  Proposed project signs for subdivision developments of five (5) lots or more. Signs advertising new subdivision developments of five (5) lots or more are permitted within residential zones provided they conform to the following requirements and regulations: 
(1)  One (1) non-illuminated temporary sign announcing a proposed subdivision development may be erected at each dedicated street entrance to the new subdivision only. 
(2)  Each sign shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet in sign area. 
(3)  Each sign shall not be more than twenty-five (25) feet tall, nor less than three (3) feet above the ground. 
(4)  Each sign shall advertise only development at which it is located. 
(5)  A permit is required. 
(g)  Subdivision and apartment identification signs. Subdivision and apartment identification signs are permitted within residential zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  Each sign shall not exceed more than fifty (50) square feet in sign area. 
(2)  No sign shall be more than twenty-five (25) feet tall. 
(3)  Each sign shall be permanently anchored according to city specifications. 
(4)  One (1) sign is permitted at each dedicated street entrance to the subdivision only. 
(5)  Signs may be illuminated. 
(6)  A permit is required. 
(7)  Directory signs not exceeding nine (9) feet in sign area are permitted to indicate names and addresses of buildings or serve as directories for apartment occupants. 
(h)  Identification signs for churches, schools, hospitals, libraries and parks. Identification signs for churches, schools, hospitals, libraries and parks are permitted in residential zones provided that they conform to the following regulations and requirements. 
(1)  One (1) illuminated sign is permitted per street frontage. 
(2)  Each sign shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet in sign area. 
(3)  Each sign shall be solely for the purpose of displaying the name of the institution or its authorized business use and its activities or services. 
(4)  Each sign must be permanently anchored according to city specifications. 
(5)  Reserved. 
(6)  A permit is required. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03; Ord. No. 2804, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 3041, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 25-7. - Signs permitted in commercial and business zones. 
(a)  All signs permitted in residential zones. 
(b)  Monument signs. Monument signs are allowed within commercial and business zones provided they conform to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  One (1) illuminated sign is permitted per street frontage. 
(2)  Each sign shall advertise only the name and business within. 
(3)  All signs with a height of five (5) feet or less shall not be erected closer than five (5) feet of a public road or from the front property line. 
(4)  All signs with a height exceeding five (5) feet shall not be erected closer than ten (10) feet of a public road or from the front property line. 
(5)  No signs shall exceed ten (10) feet in height. 
(c)  Temporary real estate signs. Temporary real estate signs are permitted in commercial and business zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  Two (2) non-illuminated real estate signs are permitted per street frontage. 
(2)  No sign shall exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in sign area. 
(3)  No permit is required. 
(d)  Political signs. Political signs are allowed within commercial and business zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  Political signs shall not be illuminated. 
(2)  One (1) sign per political candidate is permitted per street frontage. 
(3)  Signs shall not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in sign area. 
(4)  No political sign shall be erected or displayed in any public right-of-way. 
(e)  Freestanding signs. 
(1)  One illuminated sign is permitted per street frontage. 
(2)  Each sign shall advertise only the name and type of business within. 
(3)  Each sign shall not exceed two (2) square feet in sign area for each lineal foot of the property frontage but shall not exceed two hundred (200) square feet in sign area per sign face. 
(4)  Each sign shall not exceed a height of twenty-five (25) feet above the curb level; however, signs located in the following areas shall not exceed thirty-five (35) feet above the curb level: 
a.  Along Interstate 10 as permitted per federal regulations; 
b.  Along Highway 61; and 
c.  Along South Burnside Avenue, south of Highway 30 to the city limits. 
(5)  Signs erected within one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet of an interstate highway right-of-way shall not exceed a height of one hundred (100) feet above the curb level, and shall not exceed two hundred eighty (280) feet in sign area per sign face. 
(6)  Signs erected along Highway 30, west of South Burnside Avenue shall not exceed a height of sixty (60) feet above the curb level. 
(7)  A permit is required. 
(f)  Wall or projecting signs. Wall or projected signs are permitted within commercial and business zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  One (1) sign is permitted per street frontage, with the exception that buildings in integrated shopping centers may have one (1) additional sign on an additional wall similar in design and no larger than the street frontage sign. 
(2)  Each sign shall advertise only the name and type of business within. 
(3)  No wall sign shall cover wholly or partially any wall opening, nor project beyond the ends or top of the wall to which it is attached, nor project away from such wall by more than eighteen (18) inches. 
(4)  All wall signs shall be safely and securely attached to the building wall by means of metal anchors, bolts, or expansion screws of not less than three-eighths ( 3/8 ) inch in diameter embedded in said wall at least five (5) inches; provided, however, that such signs may rest in/or be bolted to strong, heavy metal brackets or saddles set securely fixed to the wall as hereinabove provided. In no case shall any wall sign be secured with ware, strips of wood, or nails. 
(5)  Sign area shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the square footage of the business' building frontage. 
(6)  Projection signs shall not extend beyond forty-eight (48) square inches and shall be at least eighteen (18) inches from the curb line as measured toward the building. 
(7)  Projection signs shall have a minimum clearance of eight (8) feet from the sidewalk or public right-of-way. 
(8)  Signs may be illuminated. 
(9)  A permit is required. 
(g)  Roof signs. 
(1)  No roof sign shall have surface or facing exceeding twenty (20) percent of the frontage, nor have its highest point extended more than twenty (20) feet above the roof level. 
(2)  No roof sign shall be erected or maintained with a face that protrudes further than the edge of the outside wall toward which the sign faces. 
(3)  Any roof sign over forty-eight (48) square feet in area shall submit specifications or plans drawn by a licensed, professional engineer for approval. 
(4)  Every roof sign shall be thoroughly secured to the building by iron or other metal anchors, bolts, supports, rods, or braces. When erected upon buildings which are not constructed entirely of fireproof material, the bearing plates of said sign shall bear directly upon masonry walls and intermediate steel columns in the building. No roof sign shall be supported or anchored to the wooden framework of a building. 
(5)  No roof sign shall be placed on the roof of any building or structure in such manner as to prevent free passage from one part of said roof to any other part thereof or interfere with openings in said roof. 
(h)  Under canopy signs. Under canopy signs are permitted within commercial and business zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements. 
(1)  One (1) under canopy sign is permitted for each separate occupancy or separate entrance. 
(2)  Each sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in sign area. 
(3)  Each sign must have a minimum clearance of eight (8) feet from the sidewalk or public right-of-way. 
(4)  Each sign may be illuminated. 
(5)  A permit is required if the sign is to be illuminated. 
(i)  Signs for integrated shopping centers. Signs for integrated shopping centers are permitted in commercial and business zones provided that they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  One (1) free standing identification sign for each street frontage is permitted. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  Each sign shall not exceed a height of twenty-five (25) feet above the curb level; however, signs located in the following areas shall not exceed thirty-five (35) feet above the curb level: 
a.  Along Interstate 10 as permitted per federal regulations; 
b.  Along Highway 61; 
c.  Along Highway 30, west of Highway 44 to the city limits; and 
d.  Along Highway 44, south of Highway 30 to the city limits. 
(4)  Signs may be illuminated. 
(5)  A permit is required. 
(j)  Decorative outdoor installations. Decorative outdoor installations are permitted provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  Outdoor installation shall be affixed to a permanent pole of similar apparatus. 
(2)  Outdoor installations must be approved by the building inspector. 
(3)  If, in the opinion of the building inspector, an outdoor installation becomes tainted, faded, obtrusive, or otherwise in disrepair, the building inspector may order the installation removed within five (5) days. 
(4)  Outdoor displays advertising the pricing of merchandise is permitted on a seasonal basis or for special events provided the display complies with section 25-2 (e) of this chapter. 
(k)  Banner signs. Banner signs are permitted in commercial and business zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  All banners displayed along any street frontage shall be secured in a permanent, permitted metal frame constructed with post having a minimum thickness of three (3) inches. 
(2)  Businesses are limited to one (1) free standing banner frame per street frontage. 
(3)  Additional banner frames may be attached to a free-standing sign, provided that the total sign area, including the banner, shall not exceed two (2) square feet for each lineal foot of property frontage. 
(4)  Additional banners may be attached to a building, provided that the total sign area of the building front, including banners, shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the square footage of the business' building frontage. 
(5)  All banners shall be professionally manufactured. 
(6)  Banner installations shall be properly secured in accordance with building inspector requirements. Banners shall be bolted in place or secured with nylon rope, bungee cords, or a stronger material. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03; Ord. No. 2788, 5-24-04; Ord. No. 2789, 5-24-04; Ord. No. 2804, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 2829, 6-6-05; Ord. No. 2886, 4-23-07; Ord. No. 3076, 6-22-15; Ord. No. 4053 , 4-23-18; Ord. No. 4077 , 11-12-18) 
Sec. 25-8. - Signs permitted in industrial zones. 
(a)  All signs permitted in residential, commercial and business zones. 
(b)  Free standing signs. Free standing signs are permitted within industrial zones provided they conform to the following regulations and requirements: 
(1)  One (1) sign per street frontage is permitted. 
(2)  Each sign shall advertise only the name and type of business within. 
(3)  Each sign shall not exceed three (3) square feet in sign area for each lineal foot of the property frontage; however, no sign shall have surface or facing exceeding twenty (20) percent of the square footage of the business' building frontage. 
(4)  Each sign shall not exceed a height of twenty-five (25) feet above curb level. 
(5)  Reserved. 
(6)  Where street frontage exceeds three hundred (300) lineal feet, one (1) additional free standing sign may be allowed per three hundred (300) lineal foot increment. 
(7)  Signs may be illuminated. 
(8)  Permits are required. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03; Ord. No. 2804, 10-25-04) 
Sec. 25-9. - Billboards and off-premises signs. 
(a)  Billboards and off-premises signs are not permitted within the city limits with the exception of the following areas: 
(1)  Along Interstate 10 as permitted per federal regulations; 
(2)  Along Highway 61; 
(3)  Along Highway 30, west of Highway 44 to the city limits; 
(4)  Along Highway 44, south of Highway 30 to the city limits; 
(5)  Along Highway 30, east of Highway 44 extending seven hundred (700) feet; 
(6)  Along Highway 44, north of Highway 30 extending seven hundred (700) feet. 
(b)  Billboards and off-premises signs are not permitted within two hundred (200) feet from any residence. 
(c)  No billboard or off-premises sign shall be located within one thousand (1,000) linear feet, measured along and on the same side of any street or road frontage, of any other off-premises sign or billboard or, at street intersections, within five hundred (500) feet, measured radially, of any other billboard or off-premises sign. 
(d)  The maximum sign area of any billboard or off-premises sign located on a premise fronting or adjacent to any street right-of-way of a width less than two hundred (200) feet shall be three hundred seventy-eight (378) square feet. 
(e)  The maximum sign area of any billboard or off-premises sign located on a premises fronting or adjacent to any street right-of-way of a width of two hundred (200) feet or more shall be six hundred seventy-two (672) square feet. 
(f)  No more than one (1) off-premises sign face visible from any one direction of travel on any roadway may be displayed on any single sign structure. A total of two (2) signs, each of which may meet the maximum sign area permitted for off-premises signs or billboards, may be displayed on one (1) back to back or "V" type sign structure, provided that the angle between such signs not be more than sixty (60) degrees. 
(g)  No billboard or off-premises sign shall exceed fifty (50) feet in height from the road surface. 
(h)  Billiards may also display an on-premises sign on the same sign structure to avoid having two (2) sign structures located on the same premises. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03; Ord. No. 2903, 12-10-07; Ord. No. 4072 , 8-27-18) 
Sec. 25-10. - Prohibited signs. 
(a)  The following list of signs are prohibited within the city limits: 
(1)  Abandoned signs. 
(2)  Audible signs. 
(3)  Beacons. 
(4)  Flashing signs. 
(5)  Inflatable signs. 
(6)  Lasers. 
(7)  Parapet signs. 
(8)  Portable signs. 
(9)  Projected signs. 
(10)  Revolving or rotating signs. 
(11)  Search lights. 
(12)  Signs attached to trees, shrubs or any living vegetative matter. 
(13)  Signs resembling traffic control devices or emergency devices. 
(14)  Free standing signs which restrict or impair visibility at the intersection of the right-of-way lines of two (2) streets, or other street, or railroad right-of-way, or of the street and pedestrians or bicycle right-of-way. 
(15)  Snipe signs. 
(16)  Trailer signs. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-11. - On-premises signs allowable by temporary permit only. 
(a)  Flags, inflatable signs and beacon signs. Flags, inflatable signs and beacon signs are permitted provided a temporary permit is obtained from the city and provided that they are: 
(1)  Displayed in connection with grand openings and/or special events no more than once annually for any one (1) business entity or applicant. 
(2)  Not displayed for a period exceeding fourteen (14) consecutive calendar days Upon issuance of the temporary permit. 
(b)  Temporary changeable message signs. Temporary changeable message signs are permitted within the city provided they conform to the following requirements and regulations: 
(1)  Temporary changeable message signs may be displayed by church and/or civil organizations in connection with special events only. 
(2)  Such signs shall not be displayed for a period exceeding fourteen (14) consecutive calendar days upon issuance of the temporary permit. 
(c)  Temporary banners and signs displayed by nonprofit organizations. Nonprofit organizations may display signs promoting events provided they conform to the following requirements and regulations: 
(1)  Nonprofit organizations must obtain the permission of landowners prior to posting signs. 
(2)  Signs may not be displayed more than thirty (30) days prior to the event promoted by the sign. 
(3)  Signs must be removed within ten (10) days following the promoted event. Failure to remove the signs in a timely manner will result in the forfeiture of privileges to display signs and banners for future events. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03; Ord. No. 2787, 5-24-04; Ord. No. 2804, 10-25-04) 
Sec. 25-12. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a)  Compliance schedule. The effective date of this chapter is March 1, 2003. All nonconforming temporary signs existing at the time of adoption of this chapter, as determined by the city building inspector, must be removed, changed, or altered to conform to the provisions of this chapter before March 1, 2004. 
(b)  Notification of violation. If any sign is erected or maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter, the city building inspector shall give to the owner, agent or beneficial user thereof written notice by certified mail of such violation, said notice to include a brief and complete statement of the violations to be remedied. A copy of said notice shall also be forwarded to the police department for the purposes of enforcement. If the owner, agent or beneficial user of such sign is not known, affixing a copy of said notice to the sign or to the building on which the sign is erected for a period of ten (10) days shall be sufficient. 
(c)  Nondurable signs. Nonconforming signs made of paper, cloth, or other nondurable material, all temporary signs other than those permitted herein, and any signs that are not affixed to a building or the ground shall be removed within thirty (30) days of the date of enactment of this chapter. 
(d)  Replacement of nonconforming signs. A nonconforming sign shall be not replaced by another nonconforming sign, except that the substitution or interchange of poster panels, painted boards, or changeable copy on nonconforming signs shall be permitted through the period prescribed by this section. 
(e)  Maintenance and repair of nonconforming signs. Nothing in this section shall relieve the owners or users of nonconforming signs or the owners of the property on which nonconforming signs are located from any provisions of this sign code regarding safety, maintenance and repair of signs provided, however, that any repainting, cleaning or other normal maintenance or repair of the sign or sign structure does not materially alter or modify the sign. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-13. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions and regulations of this chapter shall not apply to the following signs: 
(1)  Signs eligible for characterization as "legally nonconforming." Any non-temporary sign located within the city limits prior to the enaction of this chapter, or located in an area annexed to the city thereafter which does not conform with the provisions of this code, is eligible for characterization as a "legally nonconforming" sign, if the sign was in compliance with all applicable laws prior to the effective date of this code or the date that the provisions of this code first became applicable to the sign, unless otherwise provided within this chapter. 
a.  Loss of legally nonconforming status. A legally nonconforming sign shall immediately lose its legally nonconforming designation if: 
1.  The sign is altered in any way, which tends to make the sign less in compliance with the requirements of this code than it was before the alternation; or 
2.  The sign structure is relocated; or 
3.  The sign face (except for copy on a sign permitted as a changeable message sign) is replaced with a sign face which differs in sign message. 
On the happening of any one of 1., 2., or 3., the sign shall be immediately brought into compliance with this code and a new permit secured thereof, or it shall be removed. 
b.  Maintenance and repair of legally nonconforming signs. Nothing in this section shall relieve the owners or users of legally nonconforming signs or the owners of the property on which legally nonconforming signs are located from any provisions of this sign code regarding safety, maintenance and repair of signs provided however, that any repairing, cleaning or other normal maintenance or repair of the sign or sign structural does not materially alter or modify the sign. 
c.  No legally nonconforming sign may be enlarged or altered in a way which would increase its nonconformity with the provisions of this sign code. 
d.  Should any legally nonconforming sign be damaged by any means to the extent of more than fifty (50) percent of its replacement cost at the time of damage, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
e.  No conforming sign or sign structure shall be permitted to be erected for the same occupancy with an existing nonconforming sign until the nonconforming sign has been removed or brought into conformance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Professional name plates not exceeding one (1) square foot in area. 
(3)  Residential name plates used to identify the owner or owners of a private residence. 
(4)  Bulletin boards not over eight (8) square feet in areas for public, charitable, or religious institutions when the same are located on the premises of said institutions. 
(5)  Memorial signs or tablets, names of buildings, and dates of erection when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other incombustible materials. 
(6)  Traffic or other municipal signs, legal notices, railroad crossing signs, and danger signs, and such temporary, emergency, or nonadvertising signs occurring on the public right-of-way as may be approved by the city; and 
(7)  Directional signs not exceeding four (4) square feet in area and with lettering not exceeding six (6) inches in height, designed to direct and inform the public as to the location of exit, entrances, service areas, loading and unloading areas, or other matter of a similar informational nature. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-14. - Penalties. 
    Any person found in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine as provided under section 1-11 entitled "General penalty, continuing violations." A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or upon which a violation occurs or is permitted to continue. All parts of this chapter shall be enforced by the City of Gonzales Police Department with the maximum fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days or both. Such fine and imprisonment shall be within the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Sec. 25-15. - Enforcement of the provisions of the sign code and penalty for violation. 
(a)  Permitting of conforming signs erected without permit prior to this sign code. The owner of the a sign that is found to be in conformance with the sign code but which was erected without permit may, for ninety (90) days from the effective date of the adoption of this article, apply for a permit and pay all required fees and, in such case, no further penalty shall be assessed. 
(b)  Interpretation and application. The provisions of this chapter are intended to supplement and to be read and applied in pari materia with all existing laws, ordinances and regulations of this city. In the event of a conflict in any particular circumstances between the provisions or requirements of this chapter and the provisions or requirements of any other law, ordinance or regulation of this city, the more restrictive provision or requirement shall apply unless a contrary application thereof is expressly directed or clearly intended by the context and language of the laws, ordinances or regulations in question. 
(Ord. No. 2774, 11-24-03) 
Chapter 26 - HOTELS AND MOTELS 

Sec. 26-1. - Purpose. 
    This chapter is remedial and essential to the public interest, safety, health and welfare. It establishes minimum standards for the continued use and occupancy of all hotels and motels and hotel rooms and motel rooms regardless of the date of their construction. Any references in this chapter to any ordinance, section, statute, or other law or portions of law, includes the cited law as it exists at the time this chapter becomes effective and includes all the cited law's successors. Each owner, operator, and manager of each hotel and motel, which may be used for human occupancy, shall comply with the provisions of this article in each hotel room and motel room under his or her control. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-2. - Definitions. 
    Contamination means the unintended presence of a harmful substance or micro-organisms. 
    Dangerous hotel or motel means a hotel or motel structure or building where conditions exist which may threaten the health, safety, or general welfare of a person. 
    Floor space means the total area of all habitable space. 
    Habitable space means the space occupied by one (1) or more persons while living, sleeping, eating, or cooking; excluding kitchenettes, bathrooms, toilet rooms, laundries, pantries, dressing rooms, closets, storage spaces, foyers, hallways, utility rooms, heater rooms, boiler rooms or basement or cellar recreation rooms. 
    Habitable room means a room or enclosed floor space used or designed to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, or eating purposes, but not including bathrooms, water closet compartments, laundries, pantries, foyers, or communicating corridors, closets, or storage spaces. 
    Hotel room means the portion of the hotel, which may be used by a guest as a permanent or temporary residence, including single rooms and suites. 
    Infestation means the presence within or contiguous to a hotel room or motel room of insects, rodents, vermin, or other pests. 
    Litter means garbage, refuse, rubbish, and all other waste material deposited on the ground or in any place other than in an approved garbage receptacle. 
    Manager means the person who has managing control of real property. This term includes landlord. 
    Motel room means the portion of a motel, which may be used by a guest as a permanent or temporary residence, including single room suites. 
    Non-food contact surface means a surface (including, but not limited to, a shelf, counter, fan, or an exterior part of equipment) that does not normally come into contact with food in the operation of a food-products establishment. 
    Occupant means any person over one (1) year of age living, sleeping, cooking, or having actual possession of a hotel room or motel room. 
    Owner means a person claiming, or in whom is vested, the ownership, dominion, or title to the real property, including but not limited to: the owner of fee simple title; the holder of a life contract for deed; a mortgage, receiver, executer, or trustee in control of real property; an agent of a holder in fee simple, holder of a life estate, holder of a leasehold, buyer, mortgagee, receiver, executer, trustee, landlord, lessor, or sublessor; and the landlord, lessor, or sublessor of a hotel or motel. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste (except body waste) including, but not limited to, garbage rubbish, ash, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial waste. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid waste consisting of either combustible or noncombustible waste, such as paper, wrapping, cigarette, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar material. 
    Sanitary means clean, healthy condition. 
    Swimming pool means any structure, basin, spa, chamber, or tank containing an artificial body of water for swimming, diving, or physical fitness, or recreational bathing and having a depth of two (2) feet or more at any point. This phrase does not include lakes or creeks. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-3. - Compliance with article provisions. 
    Each owner, operator, and manager of each hotel and motel, which may be used for human occupancy, shall comply with the provisions of this article in each hotel room and motel room under his or her control. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-4. - Bathroom fixtures. 
(a)  The owner, operator, or manager shall provide for each hotel room and motel room a flush water toilet and a bathtub or shower connected to the municipal water and sewer systems in compliance with Chapter 5, Buildings and Building Regulations. 
(b)  The owner, operator, and manager shall connect each sink, basin, bathtub, and shower in each hotel room and motel room with both hot and cold water lines in compliance with Chapter 5, Buildings and Building Regulations. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or manager is responsible for payment for water services for each hotel room and motel room and shall ensure that water service is provided at all times. It is an affirmative defense to this subsection that it is impossible to provide water services because of an act of God. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-4. - Water-heating equipment. 
    The owner, operator, or manager shall provide and maintain in compliance with Chapter 5, Buildings and Building Regulations, water-heating equipment and facilities for each hotel room and motel room and shall connect them with water lines to municipal water service. The owner, operator, and manager shall maintain them so that each heats water to such a temperature as to provide at all times an adequate supply of hot water to be drawn at each sink, basin, bathtub, and shower in hotel rooms and motel rooms at a temperature of not less than one hundred ten (110) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-5. - Egress required. 
    In each hotel room and motel room, the owner, operator, or manager shall provide and maintain safe and unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level and emergency exit ways in compliance with all applicable laws and in compliance with the Chapter 5, Buildings and Building Regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-6. - Heating/air conditioning facilities required. 
(a)  The owner, operator, or manager shall provide each hotel room and motel room with operable heating and cooling facilities which safely and adequately heat and cool air, in compliance with the Building Code in all habitable rooms to a temperature of at least twenty (20) degrees Fahrenheit measured at a distance of three (3) feet above floor level, at least five (5) feet from an exterior wall and not in a direct air flow. 
(b)  No owner, operator, or manager shall suffer, permit, install, or maintain in a hotel room and motel room any heating appliance which is connected to its fuel supply line and which is not connected to an exhaust vent that will safely exhaust carbon monoxide fumes to the outdoors. It is an affirmative defense to this subsection of the heating appliances in an unvented bathroom wall heater existing in the dwelling unit before January 1, 1979, is otherwise installed in compliance with all applicable laws and the manufacturer's instructions. The unit shall contain a UL approved carbon monoxide detector in proper operating condition in all hallways adjacent to any bedroom. 
(c)  Where fuel-burning appliances are installed and properly vented, the owner, operator, and manager shall connect them to their fuel supply outlets with AGA approved connectors and securely install them to avoid accidental displacement. No person shall replace an existing appliance without a permit issued by the city and without allowing the work to be inspected by a city inspector, should the permit for that work be required by state, federal, or local law. 
(d)  Portable electric or fuel fired heaters are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-7. - Maximum floor area and ceiling height. 
(a)  The owner, operator, or manager shall maintain each hotel room and motel room so that it contains at least two hundred (200) square feet of habitable floor space. 
(b)  At least one-half (1/2) of the floor area of every habitable room of a hotel or motel shall have a ceiling height of at least seven (7) feet. 
(c)  It is an affirmative defense to this section that the hotel room or motel room is in compliance with all codes applicable at the time of its construction. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-8. - Minimum responsibilities of owner. 
(a)  The owner, operator, or manager of a hotel or motel shall provide and maintain in structurally sound and operative condition, all installed systems including but not limited to: 
(1)  Plumbing, electrical, heating, and air conditioning systems; 
(2)  The structure; 
(3)  All water and sewer systems; 
(4)  All bathroom facilities including water closets, showers and tubs; 
(5)  All water-heating systems; 
(6)  All window panes; 
(7)  An adequate number of approved containers for garbage and refuse disposal in compliance with all applicable laws; 
(8)  Railings for stairs, steps, balconies, porches, and elsewhere as specified in the building code in effect at time of construction of the building. It is an affirmative defense to this subsection that if the railing, stairs, balcony, or porch has been rebuilt fifty one (51) percent or more, it is in compliance with the building code in effect at the time of construction of the building; 
(9)  Floors, walls, ceilings, and all supporting structural members in a sound condition, capable of bearing imposed loads safely, in conformity with the building code in effect at the time of construction of the building; 
(10)  Chimney flues and vent attachments; 
(11)  Screened cross-ventilation openings of not less than one and one half (11/2) square feet for each twenty-five (25) linear feet of wall in each easement, cellar, and crawl space or as required by the building code at time of construction of the building; 
(12)  Supply lines for electrical service to each room which may be used for human occupancy; 
(13)  Electrical circuits, wiring, switches and outlets in compliance with the edition of the electrical code in effect in the City of Gonzales at the time of construction of the building; 
(14)  Parking lots, fire lanes, and required paved areas with legible parking and fire lane markings in compliance with all applicable laws; 
(15)  Any vehicular or pedestrian access control devices in compliance with city ordinances; 
(16)  All fire and smoke detection systems, extinguishing appliances and systems, fire alarm systems, fire hydrants, and portable fire extinguishers in compliance with all applicable laws; 
(17)  Any swimming pool, spa, pool fences and gates in compliance with all applicable laws; 
(18)  Swimming pools shall not harbor or become infested with mosquitoes, vermin, or other pest, nor shall they harbor or support submerging or emergent vegetation; 
(19)  Floors, wall, ceilings, and all structural members of all structures; 
(20)  All fuel supply lines to each hotel and motel room that is heated by natural gas or has a water heating device or stove fueled by natural gas; 
(21)  Exhaust vents to the exterior of the structure for all water heaters and heating appliances in compliance with all applicable laws; 
(22)  Deadbolt locks, if any, on exterior doors that are operated from the exterior by use of a key, card, or combination and from the inside by a knob or level without the use of a key, card, or combination or that need special knowledge or effort to operate; no person shall install a deadbolt lock on a hotel room or motel room door that does not comply with all applicable laws. 
(23)  Approved security bars over windows and doors, if installed, that are equipped with approved release mechanisms which are operable from the inside without the use of a key, card, or combination and that do not need special knowledge or effort to operate. 
(24)  All sidewalks, ramps, bridges, parking lots, stairs, and steps. 
(b)  The owner, operator, or manager of a hotel or motel shall: 
(1)  Paint, waterproof, and repair each structure to prevent deterioration due to the element. Conditions requiring repair include but are limited to; loose siding with holes, excessive cracks, or rotted boards which may permit air or water to penetrate rooms; loose roof covering; holes or leaks in roof which may cause damage to the structure or rooms; and rotting, sagging, or deteriorating supports for steps, stairs, or porches; 
(2)  Maintain all hotel rooms and motel rooms so that they are free from rodents, insects, and vermin and free from conditions that encourage or harbor rodents, insects, and vermin; 
(3)  Cause all hotel rooms and motel rooms to be exterminated of insects, rodents and other pests at least a minimum of four (4) times a year by an exterminator licensed by the state; 
(4)  Repair holes, cracks and other defects in stairs, railings, porches, steps, and balconies that may cause injury to a person; 
(5)  Repair holes, breaks, and loose surface materials in or on floors, walls and ceilings that may pose health or safety hazards; 
(6)  Eliminate holes, excavations, sharp protrusions and other objects or conditions on the premises which may cause injury to a person; 
(7)  Securely cover or securely close wells, cesspools, and cisterns; 
(8)  Provide drainage to prevent and eliminate standing and stagnant water on the premises; 
(9)  Remove trees, tree limbs and branches that are reasonably capable of damaging a structure or reasonably capable of causing injury to a person or are within thirteen (13) feet, six (6) inches of a fire lane measured vertically from the surface of the fire lane to the lowest point of the tree limb or branch; 
(10)  Connect plumbing fixtures and heating equipment in compliance with all applicable laws; 
(11)  Connect to a chimney or flue each heating and cooking device that burns solid fuel that must be vented outside; 
(12)  Maintain the interior of a vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure free from rubbish, garbage, and combustible materials; 
(13)  Completely secure all vacant or unoccupied structures or parts of structures from unauthorized entry; 
(14)  Store pool chemicals in compliance with all applicable laws; 
(15)  Complete repair of all malfunctioning sewer systems within seventy-two (72) hours, complete removal of all residue, and complete treatment of affected areas with a suitable disinfectant within twenty-four (24) hours after written notice. Such notice shall be effective upon the earliest of any of the following: 
a.  Upon personal service; 
b.  Upon delivery to the person's office during normal working hours; 
c.  Upon posting such notice on the door to the person's residence or office; or 
d.  Seventy-two (72) hours after depositing the notice, enclosed in a postpaid, properly addressed wrapper, in a post office or official depository under the care and custody of the United States Postal Service. 
(16)  Provide and maintain on each building, hotel room, or motel room and on the property, street address numbers, room numbers, and any additional signage as required by; 
(17)  Maintain in compliance displayed immediately adjacent to or on the inside of every exit door from a sleeping room, a diagram depicting two (2) evacuation routes; 
(18)  Cause fire drills for staff members to be conducted quarterly for each shift (for staff members only); 
(19)  Cause records of fire drills to be maintained on the premises for review by the city in compliance with the fire code; 
(20)  Cause an emergency plan to be submitted to and approved by the fire department; 
(21)  Maintain the cleanliness of floors, walls, ceilings, mats, duck boards, fixtures, appliances, furnishings, liners and any personal care materials. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or manager shall furnish air conditioning as a fixed system, he or she shall ensure that: 
(1)  It is designed to cool the inside of the hotel room or motel room to a temperature at least twenty (20) degrees cooler than outside temperature; 
(2)  It cools the inside of the hotel room or motel room to a temperature of at least twenty (20) degrees cooler than the outside when the inside temperature is measured at a point not less than five (5) feet from an exterior wall, five (5) feet from the floor, and not in a direct air flow. 
(d)  The owner, operator, or manager is responsible for water, sewer, and gas as required. The owner shall ensure that electricity is provided to each hotel room and motel room at all times. It is an affirmative defense to this subsection that it is impossible to provide electricity because of an act of God. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-9. - Inspections authorized. 
    The building official and the fire chief are authorized to make inspections when necessary or expedient to determine the condition of hotel and motel rooms and the premises located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-10. - Inspections. 
(a)  The building official and the fire chief may routinely inspect: 
(1)  The exterior of the structures and all of the common grounds of all hotels and motels; 
(2)  Any or all unoccupied hotel and motel rooms and any and all occupied hotel and motel rooms with the permission of the occupant; 
(3)  Any or all storage areas, community buildings, swimming pools, athletic facilities, club rooms, equipment, and all other portions of the facility; 
(4)  Any portion of portions of the hotel or motel upon receipt of a complaint from any person, city department, employee, or division that any portion of the premises may be in violation of any applicable law; 
(5)  All hotels and motels in the city to determine whether they are inhabitable, dangerous, or otherwise in violation of applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-11. - Conditions constituting a dangerously damaged or deteriorated hotel or motel. 
    A dangerously damaged or deteriorated hotel or motel is one that has a structural condition presents a substantial danger to its occupants or adjoining property or persons and which has some or all of the following structural deficiencies: 
(1)  Walls or other vertical structural members, which list, lean or buckle in excess of one-fourth (1/4) inch horizontal measurement for each one (1) inch of vertical measurement. 
(2)  A supporting member, exclusive of the foundation, which shows thirty-three (33) percent or more damage or deterioration. 
(3)  A non-supporting enclosing outside wall or covering with twenty five (25) percent damage or deterioration. 
(4)  Parts that may fall and injure a person or property. 
(5)  A floor or roof that has insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose for which it is used. 
(6)  A foundation that is not so free of holes, cracks, buckling, crumbling and defects as to provide adequate support. 
(7)  A floor exterior wall, or roof that has holes, cracks, or loose, rotten, warped, or protruding boards that may injure a person. 
(8)  An interior wall or ceiling that has holes, cracks, loose plaster, defective materials, or structural deterioration that may defeat the purpose of the wall or ceiling or that may fail to protect the occupants of the structure from danger of collapse or from fire. 
(9)  Damage by fire, explosion, wind, vandalism, or elements of nature so that there may be a danger to life, safety, or the general health and welfare of a person. 
(10)  Any evidence of mold, mildew, or bacteria sufficient enough to cause injury or bodily harm, resulting from any evidence of moisture or water leakage. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-12. - Density requirements for hotels and motels. 
(a)  The maximum number of occupants per hotel or motel guest room in which the same group of occupants stays fewer than thirty (30) consecutive days is no more than four (4) occupants per each bedroom plus one additional occupant. For example: in a one-bedroom guest room, the density shall not exceed five (5) occupants; in a two-bedroom guest room, the density shall not exceed nine (9) occupants; in a three-bedroom guest room, the density shall not exceed (13) occupants. 
(b)  The maximum number of occupants per hotel and motel guest room in which the same group of occupants stays thirty (30) or more consecutive days is as follows: in an efficiency guest room, the density shall not exceed three (3) occupants; in a one-bedroom guest room, the density shall not exceed five (5) occupants; in a three-bedroom guest room, the density shall not exceed six (6) occupants. 
(c)  It is unlawful and a violation of this section for an owner, operator, or manager to permit or allow a violation of any of the terms of this section. 
(d)  It is unlawful for a guest to violate, or permit or allow any person or persons to reside in the guest's room in violation of this section. 
(e)  An owner may establish a more restrictive density for each guest room within his or her hotel or motel, provided the density is based upon the number of occupants per bedroom. 
(Ord. No. 2879, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-13. - Offenses. 
    It is unlawful for the owner, occupant, lessees, or manager of a dwelling unit governed by this chapter to: 
(1)  Permit a dwelling unit governed by this chapter to violate the minimum standards set forth in this chapter; 
(2)  Permit a dwelling unit governed by this chapter to exist in a dilapidated or substandard condition, or condition unfit for human habitation and a hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare; 
(3)  Permit a dwelling unit governed by this chapter to be unoccupied and unsecured from unauthorized entry to the extent that it could be entered or used by vagrants or other uninvited persons as a place of harborage, or could be entered or used by children; 
(4)  Permit a dwelling unit governed by this chapter that is boarded up, fenced or otherwise secured to: 
a.  Constitute a danger to the public; or 
b.  Have inadequate means to secure the dwelling unit from unauthorized entry or use in the manner described in the section above;
